text: Annoying . This book rubbed me the wrong way from page one . I hated the stilted childish talk and the self centered mother who forces her child to save them then abandons him by trying to commit suicide .

Do n't Waste Your Money . It was not my understanding when reading about this book prior to purchasing that it was 4 different stories . They were each very short and none really had the room for character or plot development . The first , " And the Angels Shall Sing " was a spin off of the Vigilante series and worked the best of any of them . For anyone who had not read that series though it would have not made very much sense at all . Of the four , the last " A Golden Tree " I thought made the least sense of all . The story was very disjointed and a lot of it just plain did not work as a story at all . I was kind of confused at the end of the story and it did not really did not explain the ending at all . As far as I am concerned it was a complete waste of money .

Unfortunately the author has followed the path taken by many . Unfortunately the author has followed the path taken by many mystery writers and once he has had success , his writing turns ordinary . I just started reading his first few stand alone volumes and was impressed with the way the author jumped from the past to the present following a few parallel story lines . It was very hard to figure out where it was going next . After 3 stand alone books I jumped ahead to the Jason Kolarich Series . These books are very linear and traditional . Both of the two books that I have read are just gangster novels with fisticuffs , sprinkled with sex and an ending that was telegraphed in the first 100 pages . My readings of Ellis novels has ended . I wonder how the Patterson collaborations turned out since Mr. P is a genius of the cookie - cutter novel . Maybe that 's was the original goal of Mr. Ellis - spend time on his first novels developing characters , plot and style . Then when he has a reputation , start churning out the pablum .

Not the best . After reading 13 sequels to POTO this is one of my least favorite . Just not an exciting enough story for me .

Vintage Beauty ! This book is a must have for any baby boomer , or for that matter anyone who wants to relive the fabulous golden era of slot racing . Philippe de Lespinay is the premiere authority on vintage slot cars and proves it with this beautiful collection of well photographed and rare items . What is even more interesting is the collection of cars pictured here with the original art work packaging ! This is usually the first thing to be thrown away and as such , rarer than most of the cars . I went nuts just looking at the beautiful photos of Cox , Russkit , Classic , BZ , AMT , Revell , Model Products Corp. and many other lesser known companies like Internatonal and Industro - Motive . There is even a section on brands and types of motors . While the book is 96 pages of great slot car memories , it still was n't enough for me . I ca n't wait until his next book comes out !

Julia must be turning in her grave . This book should be titled'A Reinterpretation of the Life of Julia Child by a Disillusioned Feminist with an Enormous Chip on Her Shoulder . 'This book assumes that the reader already knows all the salient facts about Julia 's remarkable life , and then attempts to recast them in the light of Ms. Karbo 's cynical , self - absorbed , and ultimately , pathetic world view . If you love Julia , by all means read her enchanting autobiography " My Life in France,'as well as Bob Spitz'remarkable and thoughtful'Dearie . 'In such company , Karen Karbo is a lightweight , and her'Julia Child Rules'is nothing more than the kind of female'magazine ry'that she claims to despise .

Good Workbook for Word Problems . The best thing about this workbook is that it is designed to present a math word problem per day as part of a practice regiment . It covers a wide range of math problems at the second grade level . It is 36 weeks of grade - level math concepts such as addition , multiplication , fractions , logic , algebra , and more . Another place that thinks about teaching math differently is the Beestar website . It is nice to see that teaching math has changed somewhat since I was a kid . Part of a series of workbooks . Note You will need both the teacher and student editions to get the most out of this workbook program .

Small . When I received this product , I thought to myself , this is very small , it contains 8 tattoos of sharks for , what , 1 . 50 . Ok , it was cheap , so , no worries . But , then on Christmas morning when I gave it to my daughter , she said , " thanks , but , it 's really small . " I felt vindicated . I think that this package is really neat , marketed for shark - lovers specifically . It might be a neat product as a completing project for a section on sharks , home schooners , shark loving children . It 's easy to wash off . They claim that it 's safe but I ca n't comment either way on that . I give everything a grade , and this product I give a solid " B " . If it were made with finely designed sharks or larger sharks or more sharks or it contained a couple of pages of information about various types of sharks , then I would have given it a solid " A " .

These Books are Not Worth 3 . 49 . I bought two books by this author for 3 . 49 each and they are not worth the price . The pages are made of paper no heavier than regular copier paper and the cover is not much thicker . The whole book is only 8 pages long and is bound if you want to call it that by two tiny staples . I have bought books of better construction at the dollar store . On the bright side , the rhymes are cute and the illustrations are lovely but in the hands of my 5 - year - old nephew I do n't expect it to be long before the books fall apart .

Better at the end . I agree with other reviewers that this book was a hard sell at first but became tolerable toward the end . There are essentially two main characters , one who is a charming hero and one who is so stereotypically shallow , abhorrent , and one dimensional that I could n't stand reading about him . I found myself skipping over his chapters just to get back to the other guy . That said , slog through the first 50 of the book and you 'll find the plot picks up and the characters and dialog become more interesting , at least enough to finish the second half .

Earnest Fusion of Musical Traditions . Yuval Ron is a wonderful musician and storyteller . Attend one of his concerts if you get a chance ! This book is a mixture of transcriptions of his stories with rather " New Age " chapters about music . Unfortunately the stories are less powerful in print than when told . And his writing about his music is a colorful mishmash of mysticism , speculative research , and historical conjecture . If you love Ron 's music , buy one of his wonderful CDs instead !

Legitimately wretched . I 've never been on the Kyme hate wagon , but this is terrible . It is massively overwrought it the writing . Love her , did n't like anything about this book ! I love Nora Roberts and have read many of her books multiple times . I fought my way through this one and kept thinking that if I just kept going it would get better . It did n't . The characters were not well developed and there were so many things that were unexplained . I do n't need things spelled out for me , and know how to read between the lines , but there was just so much missing , and so much jumping from here to there trying to connect characters ! This will be the first of her series books that I wo n't purchase the second or third . I always look forward to her books , but this one just was too much like fighting your way through quicksand . I will always love Nora Roberts , and authors are always free to chart their own paths , but this path was a mistake .

me ! I love baseball , and I understand the impact that analytic has had on the game in recent years . Wonderful concept , needs improving . The book is a cute idea that I totally support . I like how the author carefully explains the participle and it 's roll , and then illustrates the incorrect and correct way to use one in a sentence . I was really hoping this would be an awesome supplemental material for English class , while it is useful in that role , the book is awfully short 20 pages ! and most of the sentences feature a passive voice something we try to teach children to avoid ! Most of the double - spread pages each contain only one sentence - with an excellent illustration of the sentence on the spread . This is a book I recommend you check out of your library , because it is useful , but it 's slim nature along with the frequent passive voice just does n't warrant purchasing it . I received a complimentary book in exchange for my honest review .

DeMille Does It Again ! Nelson DeMille is one terrific writer ! He is also a superb analyst of social order as he has demonstrated in other novels . In this superb book , he tells a great tale while educating the reader on the history and sociology of Long Island 's Gold Coast , the mafia and the FBI . Although very little actually happens in the first half , this book is almost impossible to put down . John Sutter 's narrative is both educational and amusing , and it is clear that something big is going to happen . In the second half , that something big does happen . Throughout , Sutter 's narrative is extremely clever in a very sophisticated way . In my opinion , Sutter is a much more enjoyable character and narrator than the " in your face " sarcastic John Corey of " The Lion 's Game " and " Nightfall " who was also excellent . This is a great effort by DeMille . It is informative and well written , and it proudly takes its place as one of the best crafted novels I have read .

not realistic . Stuffing Kong 's does not solve house training . The idea that house training has to have zero accidents is insane . This book is an advertisement for Kong products and Dunbar 's other publications . Do n't bother with this book . Instead , look online for better and more comprehensive house training techniques .

Dated but revenant with emphasis on cashflow . The author makes several good points however , this being a near 20 year old edition it is quite dated . Some of his cash flow concepts were the thinking of the day but have since proven incorrect . Given the low price offered for used copies I would recommend the purchase of this book for someone with a financial background that would allow separating the good from the financially inappropriate advice . If you are new to finance I have mixed feelings about recommending the book .

A little too heavy on the " hard science " . I basically liked the story in " Darwin 's Radio " -unique plot , well written characters , interesting take on government society 's reaction to the strange different but I also felt that I had to work a little too hard to get to that story . Some science background in a book can be interesting even educational but I really do n't want to feel like I 'm back in college slogging thru microbiologist to get to the meat of the story . Unfortunately that 's how I felt in long stretches of " Darwin 's Radio " . If you enjoy that level of hard science then this book is for you but , for me , it just brought the story to a screeching halt .

Unreal . I really wanted to like this book , I liked the characters although they are somewhat misled politically , but maybe that 's from being in a deep part of Texas where only Fox News is heard . I was a bit appalled as to hoe the political stances are skewed . Of course there are extreme liberals who would probably behave somewhat like some of the characters in the story , and there are probably far right - wingers who think this is the issue , the crazy liberals and the crazy right . But this is not the true issue , most Democrats are intelligent people who care about the people and the original philosophy of democracy . And there were many honorable Republicans at one time who had great input as to conservative ideas . There was a balance . If the world is really like what William Johnstone paints , then there will be no coming back .

Milton Friedman and the Free Market are the problem ? This book had some mildly interesting anecdotes , although there is nothing pleasurable about this read . And very little accuracy from what I know . No one and nothing is perfect , but this indictment of is the equivalent of junk science . Hints of facts interspersed with a raging and disillusioned perspective , in my opinion . My recommendation Skip it .

" Let 's not read this one again . " . My 4 - year - old loves the Miss Spider 's Sunnypatch world , so we were excited to see this brightly colored book about one of my son 's favorite things - cars . But the story turned out to be disappointing . My son had zero interest in seeing Miss Spider and Holley shop for a car . He did n't understand the concept , and the words did not help . To him , there was no story , no plot . He was disappointed that none of Miss Spider 's kids were in the book , and the illustrations were not clear enough to get him interested in the vehicles . I think we were both expecting a family adventure in a new car . At the end of the book he said , " Let 's not read this one again . "

It 's alright . American Girl is really good at doing lots of different crafts that helps kids be creative and maybe learn something and have fun with their dolls . However , I do n't know if this one of their best craft books . There are materials that you 'll need that are not included and maybe are n't around the house on a regular day . But I did think the book is packaged very nicely . The pictures are really cute .

Weird people in a beautiful place . This is my first Palmer - Jones mystery and I must say it was quite good . Ann Cleeves should work for the Ministry of Tourism , she makes me want to visit these places around the UK and in this book , the Scilly Isles seem to be a great place to vacation or even to live . The story was good and I did n't get it until around the end who the murderer would be - it 's got to be those silent types ! Oh , and the twitches , what a cultural phenom they must be .

Waste of paper . I was assigned this book for my into to sociology class and I find it to be a lot of blustering with inaccurate information given the price . The book discusses the dualities of conflict and order in society , though you only need to read a few chapters in to realize the book is nearly completely biased to the conflict paradigm . They also like to reference themselves throughout the book but on certain " historical facts " and " observations " there are no citations as to where they obtained this erroneous information . Some of the claims the book makes are rather blatant and sometimes incorrect . My personal favorite was the political system in the United States is fair to everyone . Seriously ? If you have any knowledge of American history candor politics , I think you will be disgusted you wasted 122 . 00 to buy this .

Cute Storyline ! A Great Start for the Series ! I found this book to be a quick read , easy to follow and an enjoyable way to pass time in an airport or at home . The lead character , Georgie , is sweet , easy to like , and a person you want to get to know better . Her immediate family is just eccentric enough to hope Georgie always gets the last word in . And of course her royal relatives seem fairly true to form . Rhys Bowen uses some real people and places , but not quite enough for my tastes . Hopefully they will play a bigger part in her coming novels . I also hope in the next novels in this series Georgie has a little more spunk . All and all I do recommend reading this novel .

Not that interesting . Probably my mistake , but I thought this book would be much more about geology , oceanography , maybe even some chemistry or mineralogy . Mostly about archaeology . I love archaeology and history , but this book was not very exciting . I did love the section on Phoenix , AZ that I was not aware of . But canals and aqueducts and Archimedes screw , and paddle wheels and foot pumps , et . are all pretty familiar and it gets rather boring . Some people might rate the book higher , but 3 is as high as I can go on this one .
If you like F - bombs you will love this book . Has a heads up the authors idea of humor is how many and how many times he can use very fowl language . no pun intended . Buyer beware .

Entertaining . This book had some interesting plot twists but did n't hold together . A very personal and emotionally - honest book of survival ! I recently had the privilege of meeting Reanne and her husband , Don and knowing absolutely nothing about her book beforehand . This book was written in such a way that you almost feel as if YOU'RE experiencing everything - you feel like you 're in Reanne 's mind during the whole adventure . I could n't put the book down . This book gets into the brutally honest nitty - gritty psychology of how people react to each other during normal times as well as life - and - death crises . Reanne tapped into and shared her most intimate thoughts during the most critical time of her life . Reanne told me that when she tried to get this book published years ago , the publishers wanted to her fictionalize the story and that it was too emotional and too psychological . Wake up publishers ! Survival IS a psychological situation ! As a sailboat er , I totally admire and respect Reanne for what she went through and for " not selling out to the publishers " and sticking to the truth of their adventure , through her eyes . Reanne , you 're so awesome !

Resolutely superficial . Frederick Exley was perhaps the quintessential one - book wonder , though he did write a few decent magazine articles along the way . Then there is the assertion that " high capacity clips " which is another way of saying higher than ten round magazines cause more death . I am not exactly sure what his point about that was supposed to be because he melded it with his distaste for arming teachers then pointed out that had Lanza had to take time less than a second by the way to reload then maybe , just maybe , principal Hochsprung would have been able to overpower the skinny murderer . but that the AR-15 acted as an equalizer and ended in her death . the point that makes to me is that if she had been similarly equalized with a firearm then 30round man or no she could have shot Lanza dead instead , but he abandons logic at that point in favor of anti - constitution and bill of rights legislation . good read , but poor conclusion .

Not for beginners , not a quick reference . I 've been working with digital images for almost twenty years , and can create amazing images using programs other than Photoshop . However , because Photshop is THE standard , when the time came for me to buy and learn Photoshop , I also got this book thinking that it could provide me with basic reference help on the fly . I was wrong . This is not a practical guide . You ca n't look up " Text , placing in image " and get step by step directions for adding text to an image . Instead , this book deals with the concepts of and the theory of of the topic . My biggest fault with this book is that its title is misleading . This is more an introduction to digital image theory and Photoshop program set ups than it is a practical guide to making photoshop work for the causal user . If you are looking for a book that you can use on the fly , when time counts , do n't bother with this book .

Disappointed . Update After partially completing 20 puzzles , I threw this book in the trash . It was horrible and I recommend that you do n't buy it . I was desperate for a crossword puzzle book . For some reason , most of them are shipping in about 3 - 4 weeks despite the fact they are " Prime " . I guess it 's because of COVID 19 but home entertainment media is more important now than ever and should be bumped up a notch on shipping priority . Anyway , this book was available in 5 days and looked ok . It arrived on time but is not what I expected . Basically , the 2 puzzles shown in the heading are not indicative of the average . And , the " From the Publisher " description displays a puzzle which is obviously from another publication and incorrectly describes the book . Every single one of the first 10 puzzles relies heavily on 11 letter words . There are no themes and the intersected clues are poor . Obviously , I 'm disappointed . Sunday NYT puzzles are too hard for me so maybe I 'll try weekday NYT or USA Today .

Artwork Straight out of All Hail Megatron . I rather expected a little higher quality from IDW Publishing . Paper is fairly light weight and images are all straight out of their " All Hail Megatron " arc . Which is amazing , but I would have hoped for maybe some new art , or a little more variety . Also , image quality is a little grainy in some spots . Kinda comes off as a well - done bootleg , to be honest . That said , IDW 's artwork never ceases to impress , and the images are well - selected and cropped . Color fidelity is excellent . Overall conclusion as a monster Transformers fan , I love it . Had I held it in my hands and observed it more closely before purchase , I might not have spent so much on it , though . Will probably wait on a'deal'on next year 's calendar .

Cranked out . I first have to say I 'm a big Stephen King fan . Although his books have not been consistent as to quality . You can tell when he 's in a zone and the words just suck you in , such as " The Stand " , " Christine " and " The Gunslinger Series " among others . Unfortunately he has written stinkers too . Books where you know he cranked one out because a deadline was due . This is one of those . The language is good , plotting is good , but the characters are cardboard . not Garwood 's best effort , but still worth the read . I 've been a fan of Garwood 's work for years , and rate several of her novels as among the best ever written in the genre . I love The Secret and was eager to read this sequel and to learn more about Ramsey and Brodick 's quest for true love . Unfortunately , for me at least , this book fell pretty flat . The plot was needlessly complicated I feel like a lot of explanatory details were left on the cutting room floor and I think would have worked best as two separate stories . The entire Ramsey - Bridgid plot had a lot of potential , but to me was never satisfactorily fleshed out . A separate book would have allowed for some explanation of Gideon 's motives , of Ramsey 's rise to power , and of Bridgid 's early life I think they and we deserved that story . Ransom deserves 3 . 5 stars oh Amazon , give us half stars and even a lukewarm Garwood is better than many of the other romance novels out there . Her trademark humor and steamy scenes make this novel well - worth the read , but I recommend following it up with some of her earlier , 5 star works The Bride is my personal favorite .

Running With the Demon . I decided to read this series because it is technically a prequel to Terry Brooks'other large series . I was n't quite ready to delve into that monstrous series , and I 'm usually a fan of urban fantasy , so this seemed like a great place to start . Unfortunately , Running With the Demon is more like a Stephen King novel then an urban fantasy . The magic is at a minimum and the suspense and action is practically non existent . The plot is very simple , if an angel type character does n't stop a demon from touching a girl then the world will end . There is a creature trapped in a tree , emotion sucking monsters , and a talking stick figure , but not much else . I found myself skipping over how people were planning on sabotaging a company , how the main character met the stick figure , and other such things . There was simply not enough substance in this book . The plot was predictable , the characters were uninteresting , and there was no depth to this tale . I managed to finish the book , but now I 'm wondering why I really bothered .

Unfortunately the author has followed the path taken by many . Unfortunately the author has followed the path taken by many mystery writers and once he has had success , his writing turns ordinary . I just started reading his first few stand alone volumes and was impressed with the way the author jumped from the past to the present following a few parallel story lines . It was very hard to figure out where it was going next . After 3 stand alone books I jumped ahead to the Jason Kolarich Series . These books are very linear and traditional . Both of the two books that I have read are just gangster novels with fisticuffs , sprinkled with sex and an ending that was telegraphed in the first 100 pages . My readings of Ellis novels has ended . I wonder how the Patterson collaborations turned out since Mr. P is a genius of the cookie - cutter novel . Maybe that 's was the original goal of Mr. Ellis - spend time on his first novels developing characters , plot and style . Then when he has a reputation , start churning out the pablum .

Great book for beginning adult coloring . There are many beautiful designs in this book . Many are somewhat complex and even challenging . There are also some fairly easy ones with large spaces to color and fewer intricate loops to follow . Some lend themselves beautifully to the 3 - D challenge . I like the variety . The designs are easy to follow or to change in many different ways to make them more interesting and creative . This would be an excellent book for someone new to adult coloring books . It has such a variety from easy to intermediate designs and allows for a lot of individuality . It 's a very good starter book . Lots of pros and only one con for me - too many simple designs . I would recommend this book .

Enjoyed very much . I was pleasantly surprised , after reading a couple negative reviews , to find I liked this book quite a lot , though I did like The Traitor 's Wife and Hugh and Bess more than The Stolen Crown . I read this book in just a couple days , and found that it had a good pace , interesting characters , and natural dialogue or what I assume is natural for the time period . I especially liked the first few chapters when Kate and Harry were young - quite amusing . I also enjoyed seeing some of the same events from 2 different perspectives . I admit though , that if one does not know a basic outline of this time period War of the Roses then it will be extremely hard to keep up with the many characters , many of whom have the same name . I appreciated that the author tried to be clear about who each person was - referring to titles and relationships , as well as names , to differentiate all the Richards , Edwards and Margarets . I would recommend this to someone that is interested in that time period and likes historical novels , but not to someone that wants a simple historical romance which I do enjoy sometimes .

Lovely read . shone MgGonagle is a middle aged librarian who is suddenly offered a mission that includes time travel , but it is not made clear just what the mission is , only that she will know when the time comes . Unfortunately she is wrong about everything . But you have to give her credit , she never gives up and eventually things fall into place . I did n't find it as funny as other reviewers described , but it was a charming read . I kept thinking Shona was kind of like Inspector Clueso sp ? in the Pink Panther Movies she could n't see the forest for the trees . But that is part of the charm of the story . I hope there are more stories in this series as I am looking forward to them .

Is this for real ? It 's hard to muster much sympathy for Sarah Giles , a woman with a caring boyfriend , an exciting lover and the world at her feet . Sarah is engaged to a Catholic banker named Paul , who is repressed in more ways than one . At the same time , she embarks on an affair with notorious womanizer , John Wayne , who is never quite developed . We see most of Sarah 's relationships develop via text messaging , and if this is realistic , the state of romance today is in peril . The title itself focuses on the fact that Sarah is engaged to be married , although the details of the actual event are sketchy . Sarah 's wedding comes and goes with little fanfare or drama , and the love triangle is poorly developed . Perhaps this is indicative of Sarah 's character ? I ca n't be sure . I found the story to be slow and annoying at times . There are several issues that could have been developed that would have made this story more poignant , but the plot falls a bit short . There are much better books in the Red Dress Ink series .

A gem of a publication ! Like the author , I also learned about Guy de Maupassant 's writings during my trip to Sicily and Palermo . It was quite extraordinary that almost all of the places described by de Maupassant were also on my itinerary . I learned a lot about the island and its places from reading this guide . I can not wait for my next trip to the island and see , experience and reexperience many of the sites and places referenced in the work . The author 's translation and commentary are excellent , and his introduction provides important context for de Maupassant 's work . The impressions , sites , and feelings that de Maupassant describes for us paint a wonderful picture of Sicily , its peoples and its cultural heritage . Another " home run " for Italica Press !

Sadly poorly done . granter is an author for whom I have a lot of respect , but this is pretty much nonsense . His claim that Sir William Douglas generally known as the Knight of Liddesdale refused to fight the English after his capture and release is totally wrong . Tranter had to know that After that event , Liddesdale captured Edinburgh Castle from the English and took part in the assault on the English held city of Perth in which he was seriously injured . He was captured by the English when taking part with King David in the Battle of Neville 's Cross . Parts of it are historically correct , but since the entire plot depends on that claim , the novel falls apart . The fact is that Tranter was desperate to excuse inexcusable acts by Liddesdale . He did later swear fealty to the King of England which led to his being killed by his cousin , the Lord later earl of Douglas .

Not a Great Story , But Great Fun For Dug Fans . Our five year old is a big fan of Dug , one of the characters in ASINB001KVZ6FW the recent Pixar movie , Up . She was delighted to get this book . Other young fans of Up or Dug would be too , but most other kids would probably find it a little dull . Using simple , cute artwork that resembles cutout collages , this book basically tells the story of the first two - thirds of the movie as seen through the eyes of Dug . Over the course of the story , Dug , a loveable but underestimated dog , meets the other main characters , befriends them , and helps them to make their first escape from the villain and the other dogs . As I said , my daughter is a Dug fan and loves having a story about Dug to go with her ASINB0029UC6AQ Dug plush animal , but I could n't give the book more than three stars . First , the writing is a little basic . Second , given that they were retelling the movie , I 'm not sure why Disney did n't just add 3 or 4 pages and finish the story . In my opinion , both of those would have added a lot .

DO NOT BUY - This is an'abridged for children'edition . This is an abridged for children edition , and of no use students past high school level . A Mystery That Forgets It 's a Mystery . It 's a Prologue to GRAB you , starting with , " Big Jake liked to poke danger with a stick . But now the slam of his heartbeat against his chest told him he should 've waited for his student instead of attempting this dive alone . " The student who is n't around when Big Jake kicks the bucket is Brad Pope . Pope is our narrator , 35 years old , a psychologist who moved back to Whitecross , Florida , for no reason he can really figure out . Several locals create a shrine for the dead man , but Pope does n't participate . He knows Big Jake was the devil incarnate . So it 's not really a surprise when the police determine that Big Jake was murdered . You could say there are a lot of suspects . The first half of " Limestone Gumption " is good . The pace is brisk , the murder interesting , and the environs nicely described . Unfortunately , after that , some characterizations approach caricatures . Then the plotting swerves sharply away from murder mystery into drama and the mystery plot comes to a halt . At least for me . I thought " Limestone Gumption " was a better than just OK , 3 . 4 stars rounded down to 3 . Watch out for the Women 's Preservation Club ! Happy Reader

I 've read about half of the stories so far , and none of them are all that magical or well - written . There are a few cute retelling , but overall the quality of the stories is pretty poor . A psychological thriller I finished in one sitting . I really liked the Silent Patient , so I was really excited for this one . I feel a little bit let down though , though I love psychological thrillers . From the first chapter of this book , I knew Edward Fosca could n't be the murderer because that would be way too obvious and anticlimactic . The reveal of the killer was completely random - I felt like there were no clues or hints or anything leading up to the revelation that Zoe was orchestrating this entire thing . I was suspecting Elsie for a bit and then Fred , and I could tell it was Zoe a few pages before it was revealed . Although I was surprised about Sebastian 's involvement - I feel like that was a good revelation . That being said , I did read the entirety of this book in just one sitting , and it was definitely a page turner for me . I also loved the connections with the Silent Patient and seeing Theo mentioned again was awesome . I did expect more from Alex Michaelides , but I would recommend this book to others .

Take this one on a Journey ! This book is , by far , one of the best books I 've read in a very long while . Max Zimmer , novelist extraordinaire , tells the story of Shake . The craziness of parents anyone parents . The joy of your first job and first hard earned money . The chores . The laughter . It 's everyone 's lives told so eloquently and poignantly that I laughed and cried . The Morman religion is described in such a way that I 'm not surprised this novel is being touted as the " Great American Morman novel " . This is the kind of book you can read over and over , one that wo n't end up at the yard sale or the book drive . Read it ! Enjoy it ! More are coming , I can hardly wait !

STRANGE ENDING AFTER PLODDING THRU ALL THE DESCRIPTIVE DETAILS . An engaging story that somehow ends up very different from what I expected . The ending seems to happen all at once and sort of convenient to end the book - out of character with the rest of the book and it 's detailed progressive story . Surprisingly , I was truly confused about the ending tragedy but after reading through it again , I realized how it happened . Although it jumped around between all the different characters , I did n't have a problem following the story with them . It was the ending that seemed to jump out all at once , more than the characters . All through the book , Tom Bailey wrote in great descriptive detail , but then when he got to the day of the first hunt of the season , he sort of dropped off his style of writing . This edition had a " Reader 's Group Guide " and I would have trouble truly answering all the questions presented ! I feel that I wasted my time with going all the way through this novel to such a quick and strange ending . With all the reviews , I expected something totally different than what I read .

Unfortunately the author has followed the path taken by many . Unfortunately the author has followed the path taken by many mystery writers and once he has had success , his writing turns ordinary . Both of the two books that I have read are just gangster novels with fisticuffs , sprinkled with sex and an ending that was telegraphed in the first 100 pages . My readings of Ellis novels has ended . I wonder how the Patterson collaborations turned out since Mr. P is a genius of the cookie - cutter novel . A cut far above the normal fantasy genre . Not for everyone , but definitely for me . The Blade Itself is powerful in its building of characters and the deeply flawed antiheroes in its pages . Very pretty patterns and some very useful techniques . The only reason I did n't give this product 5 - stars is a personal one - I'm the type of knitter who always seeks to avoid sewing , and a lot of the projects in this book contain seams . That said , Folk Bags is still a keeper for me , and I 'm very glad I purchased it . Aside from the stranded color knitting which I do like , some of the projects are so interesting that I may actually take down my guard and try my hand at seaming up a few . The author 's inclusion of two particular techniques used in the bags - working entrelac flat , while joining the ends in a tube as you knit , and embellishing with a crochet needle instead of traditional embroidery - set this book apart from others of its kind for me .

Entwined . Audrey Niffenegger gives readers over 400 pages of finely written prose in her novel , Her Fearful Symmetry . I found myself mesmerized by this odd story of two generations of twins whose lives and relationships are entwined . A supporting cast of characters provide plot movement and opportunity for Niffenegger to display her skill in character development . Readers with low tolerance for the paranormal will be overwhelmed by how much of the novel is outside the world we can see and feel . Readers willing to suspend disbelief and allow the novel to proceed will be rewarded by the behavior of character that disclose fundamentals about the ways we relate to one another . I suggest any reader sample some pages before committing to this unusual novel . Rating Three - star Recommended

I look forward to reading more from this author as I thought it was well written . Her writing made an ordinary summer become extraordinary . Carey does n't repeat himself . I got a little excited to hear Mike Carey was delving back into a world of ours filled with demons . Aston is a good lead , a detective that spoiler , spoiler and ends up getting deep in to the underbelly of the world of the SHAITAN - basically people who agreed to demonic possession but are ultimately overtaken by the demon . There is a very good exploration on the theme of racism , it 's important to the story , making you think during the break neck investigation and exploration of this alternate now that Carey has crafted . My only complaint is that of the 6 issues , there are two issues devoted to a flashback stories and there is no resolution yet ! But this is a good start , and it already feels like the world building Carey excels at could continue into a much greater tale by the end .

If you are going to read this book , you have to read it all . It is a hard book to read , especially for a Christian and a white woman . There is open misogyny and sexual content as well as naked hostility towards Whites and Christians . Parts of this book made me angry , parts made me nod in agreement , parts of it disgusted me . Almost all of it made me think . It was recommended to me by a black man as a good book for my 12 y. o. black godson to read , and that advice does not impress me , it is not at all appropriate for a 12 y. o. But almost against my will , Malcolm X himself did impress me . I wish he had lived .

Boxes too small on two puzzles per undersized page . I have n't had such an eye strain problem since someone once sent me a trash bag full of mixed up pieces from three 1000 - piece jigsaw puzzles . After two card tables and two days I made it to the eye doctor , luckily without running into a tree or heavy traffic . This books puzzles , two to a page , have tiny boxes to hold the possible as well as final numbers and my crosscut lines . I do n't see light pencil lines well and use ink for all puzzles also avoids getting eraser dust on the breakfast toast . I tried two Sudoku puzzles , and each time everything went fuzzy from eyestrain after just a few minutes . The multi - grid Samurai puzzles , fun idea , have even tinier boxes and fuzzier out with a headache in five minutes flat . I bought this for the spiral binding to use at breakfast no need to hold down pages plus pen and toast . I can not recommend it for anyone with a tendency to eyestrain and am very disappointed about wasted time and money .

humberto 's story preserves essential experiences for us to reflect upon . I found the story of Umberto 's early years representative of many who were raised in war torn WW2 Europe . As that generation passes I am grateful for the author , and Umberto , for preserving the generational experience of the main character and the supporting casts of Nuns , peers , family , mentors , antagonists and so many more . The devastation of war leaves so much destruction but to live and maintain a zest for life , as Umberto did , leaves a legacy we all need to live through in the reading of this book . During my reading , my minds eye was easily influenced as the writer brilliantly made everything pictorial in such vivid emotional reality that I can easily imagine Sinatra 's Tailor , being made into a movie . I was left wanting to read the sequel of Umberto 's career and life after arriving in America . His ingenuity , productively manipulative personality , and hard - work ethic would have been intriguing to follow as he must have interfaced with many unique characters in addition to Sinatra . Kudos to the Author , Mark Thompson , and Umberto for making this read delightful and real , for generations to come .

Nice into book . I love the " For Dummies " line for almost everything but computer hardware related stuff . It is n't that I do n't like it , but more that my expectations when it comes to hardware is high . Maybe too high . I note that at the beginning of review as a sort of a grain of salt warning . I selected this book because I got a new laptop for Christmas . My first laptop in years because my last one drove me nuts . It is Windows 10 and just seems a bit wonky at times so when I saw this book become available , I decided to take a look . Upon review , there are some things that were new to me . Like I realized that I had the monitor at the wrong angle and I did like the power saver information . For a beginner , this is a good book for overview . If an intermediate to advanced I 'd put myself firmly at intermediate , the content may seem redundant . For example , I do n't really want to know the history of the laptop . " Laptops for Dummies " is a nice into book but I was expecting more .
Returned . Returned . Was not an old publication .

The funny side of being tormented in the Retail Profession ! I just reviewed another book about retail with negative results . that book only had 2 stars because it was boring and depressing . In contrast , Pretending You Care by Norman Feuti is a tongue in cheek take on working retail . He shows you the ins outs of working retail , letting you know that no matter what you do , you 're trapped . But he does it in a humorous way , sharing stories along that way that make you laugh . If you 're going to buy any book about retail , I would suggest this one . Norm also writes a comic called , of course , Retail . If you have ever been a retail employee , are currently a retail employee , or are thinking about becoming a retail employee are you insane ? ! then I suggest reading both the comic and this book . At least if you 're trapped in a job you hate , you can find ways to laugh about it !

A slow story with boring characters . Ugh . Pass .

Confusing Read . I am an avid fan of the Mitford books . In face , I loved all the Father Tim tomes . However , this one missed the mark for me . It was extremely confusing with the constantly shifting point - of - view characters - even within the same scene . Ms. Karon 's habit of not identifying in whose head the narrative is playing out with only pronouns made it even more difficult to determine . I was often several paragraphs into a scene before it became clear who was speaking . I believe all books should be able to stand alone , but if a reader has not read the earlier books , the sheer number of characters and relationships would be overwhelming and nearly impossible to follow . Several plot points seemed too coincidental and forced . Ms. Karon is at her best when she focuses on one or two characters and fully creates their immediate world . This one was just too complex and confusing .

Is it a travelogue or a travel guide ? While this book definitely has entertaining moments , I found its dual nature as both travel guide and travelogue distracting . I would have preferred the specifics of where they stayed , et . in an appendix at the end . The best parts are those that give brief glimpses of how life is conducted in the locales visited . At times the supercilious attitude of the author toward other tourists is more grating than funny . Paul Theroux , she is not . The book falls into an awkward gap It does not have thorough , detailed information about tourism options on the Out Islands as a true travel guide would have , and also does not present itself as a polished travel account . Perhaps in trying to be both , it fails at being neither ? If you are planning a trip to the Out Islands , this book would make an entertaining , if short , read .

Grammar anyone ? I used this textbook for a late - start community college course . What bothers me the most about this textbook are the numerous grammatical mistakes and incomprehensible sentences that occur throughout the text . One in front of me right now pg 395 discusses " payments to Philippine customers officials " . I 'm guessing this should have been " custom officials " ? While I do n't pretend to have perfect grammar myself , I often find my concentration broken by syntax errors in the text . As other reviewers have also mentioned , the chapters seem overly - long and dry and the text is entirely black and white with no colors or pictures . What also stands out are certain organizational issues , which include certain topics popping up every chapter rather than just having one chapter address the subject . Another issue is the authors citing academic research without providing enough context such as not even providing the scholar 's first name . I also take issue with their over - reliance on the ethical models of Rest and Kohlberg while only giving token acknowledgement to criticisms of these models .

Taste Specific . There are some unique and creative projects in this book I especially liked the baby crib bumper that doubled as a fabric ABC 's book . The instructions are very clear and the author 's tone welcoming and cheerful . That said , I was a little surprised to find that only about a quarter of the patterns were actually for quilts . Pot holders , trivets , sewing machine covers , scarves and other miscellanea accounted most of the book . These are not bad , but perhaps not what everyone is looking for . The author 's personal style is also rather taste specific - she embraces improvisation and , although they lend themselves well to intimidated beginners or makers of scrap quilts , her patterns and practices will not be appreciated by everyone . I would definitely flip through this at your library or local bookstore before ordering to make sure its a good fit for you .

And I will never - ever understand why she got back with Joe . So this book is just okay . A fast read . That 's about the best I can offer .

Very Readable Formula Read . I opted to read the Hunting Party after reading The Guest List , which I really enjoyed . The Guest List was my first Lucy Foley novel and I was intrigued . Sadly , The Hunting Party was a repeat of the The Guest List though perhaps it 's better to say the The Guest List was a repeat of the Hunting Party since it 's the and book . An assorted group of old friends gather for New Years Eve in a remote Scottish estate . They are marooned by a massive snowstorm and one is murdered . Just as in The Guest List , the victim is the " Golden Person " who appears perfect but is actually a very unpleasant human being . The Hunting Party has to many characters - it was quite apparent that both the victim and the murderer were coming from the inner circle of 6 of so characters . The couple with the new baby added nothing to the story and the estate odd job man subplot was n't really necessary to the story . The story was readable and good page turner to pass the time during a cold , rainy quarantine day

I Lay Reading Baby Doll . Let me start by saying I had a very different review planned for this book . And that I really hate it when this happens . Because I honestly liked Baby Doll . It probably would have gotten a 4 from me . Is it The Next Gone Girl ! ? No . But its a great thriller , and a solid view of PTSD and recovery . However , sometimes my write the review immediately after reading the book policy will bite you in the ass . Because this happened in the Epilogue , two minutes before the close of the book " She loved each and every ounce . She was n't a'fatty . ' " There is absolutely no reason to fat - shame there . Zero . Its completely out of character for Lily . The scene is supposed to prove how strong she is , how far along her path of recovery she has come . She s also a grown woman . While I understand her abuser degraded her , I still think it should have been shown in another way . That sentence could have been removed completely . Reading that shatters all illusions I have about Lily and the world she lives in . Nope . Book ruined , just by that sentence . Does nt that suck so hard ?

This author needs a fact checker . Jeffrey L. Rodengen is a writer publisher who specializes in small circulation corporate ego books , with such sleep - inducing titles as " The Legend of Litton Industries " and " The Spirit of AMD . " His company boasts of " meticulous research , " and that one of Jeff 's specialties is " advanced technology . " The book acknowledges " accurate and resourceful " research assistants . These folks produced a book about phone system maker Inter - Tel now selling at Amazon for 41 cents , that is filled with easily - avoidable errors . For example , Jeff claims that in the early 1970s , " there were no domestic phone system manufacturers except ATT , " inexplicably ignoring GTE with roots going back to 1892 , Stromberg - Carlson 1894 , ITT 1897 , and Northern Telecom founded in 1895 in Canada and operating a US factory since 1972 . Jeff also misspells company names , and confuses intercom systems with phone systems . The book is very frustrating because it has a lot of material that is interesting to its intended audience but errors put its authority in doubt . Readers who might know more than the author does about some things , do n't know what they can believe .

Nature writing and storytelling at its finest . Spoiler alert This book has a happy ending . But , that did n't stop me from crying almost the whole way through . Educational - nature and a lot of nature terminology is introduced in a fun and alive wayland telling a story that is as contemporary today as it would have been 100 - 200 or more years ago . This is by far the best children 's book I have ever had the delight of reading , rereading and soon to be purchasing for all the children in my life . The long life of Red , a red oak tree , of course . and a story of how he was almost destroyed by racism and hate and how those sentiments were reversed by the love that saved his life . Thank you Katherine Applegate .

This author needs a fact checker . Jeffrey L. Rodengen is a writer publisher who specializes in small circulation corporate ego books , with such sleep - inducing titles as " The Legend of Litton Industries " and " The Spirit of AMD . " His company boasts of " meticulous research , " and that one of Jeff 's specialties is " advanced technology . " The book acknowledges " accurate and resourceful " research assistants . These folks produced a book about phone system maker Inter - Tel now selling at Amazon for 41 cents , that is filled with easily - avoidable errors . For example , Jeff claims that in the early 1970s , " there were no domestic phone system manufacturers except ATT , " inexplicably ignoring GTE with roots going back to 1892 , Stromberg - Carlson 1894 , ITT 1897 , and Northern Telecom founded in 1895 in Canada and operating a US factory since 1972 . Jeff also misspells company names , and confuses intercom systems with phone systems . The book is very frustrating because it has a lot of material that is interesting to its intended audience but errors put its authority in doubt . Readers who might know more than the author does about some things , do n't know what they can believe .

When I went back to it I was glad I did , but then the horrors started again more ! and the ending was disappointing and abrupt . Bizarre Tale . This story definitely qualifies for the term " bizarre tale " . From beginning to end it 's unique mysterious . These qualities keep you reading up until the most suspenseful page of all - the last . However , the last page leaves something to be desired . At times this tale that is woven for a baby of a sister , is hard to grasp . Other times things seem to come into focus . Through out all of the stories of sisters , brothers , mothers fathers , the ending is looming and is what the reader anxiously awaits - in order to get some clarification on events . Unfortunately , I felt that clarification never did come . I enjoyed the book , but was extremely diss apo in ted with the ending . I felt like I was left hanging , waiting for answers that never came . I do n't think I would recommend this book to anyone . The only reason I gave it three stars was because I did enjoy the stories so much and the suspense . But overall whatever the author was trying to pull off did not work for this reader .

Not for everyone . The book has a lot of problems , that 's true the writing is subpar , the graphic scenes are unmotivated and the dialogue is pretty bad . Like someone read some Jon Athan and Matt Shaw and thought they would make a Law Order episode . It 's juvenile . There are also numerous triggers , of every kind detailed descriptions of chopping up alive a six - year old boy with a chainsaw , raping an eleven year - old girl , killing violently a baby . It turns out , however , that the story picks the reader 's curiosity it picked mine , at least and one wants to finish the book . Not every book can achieve that . So there has to be something good in there , though not the crappy violence . The monologues are too unrealistic , but they carry a message of gritty realism , cynicism and nihilism one can identify with . A lot of the message is superficial moaning about the justice system , the police , et . Teenager stuff . But some of it rings true . I can not recommend the book , go read some Athan instead . But if you persist , you wo n't regret it .

There 's one section concerning the experiences of a Native American woman that is so badly written I could barely get through it . Many of these books appear to be self - published I can understand why . Why do n't these authors use editors to read and revise the material before they publish for the market ? Jack Lapseritis apparently has a Masters of Science degree . That begs the question , From which University ? I 'd certainly like to read his Master 's dissertation . The best material I 've read is part of a book titled , Enoch . The author who also writes poorly but whose mother also had experiences with Sasquatch and is a much better writer uses the works of a man who habituated with Sasquatch in Florida . I could read his journal excerpts all day .

Awkward language . I have a masters degree in engineering so I do understand geometry . I found the language used in describing the spine tilt to be awkward . However , I read the book again to clarify the ideas presented . I found that I hit the ball further and more consistently using this swing method . The traditional pro swing , wherein the weight shifts from one foot to the other , requires precise timing of body movements . Even though the pro player constantly practices , even they play inconsistently from week to week . For the amateur , this stack and tilt method is less demanding of timing precision and allows for more consistent contact with the ball . The method has certainly improved my ball striking . Buy the book it 's worth the price . But read it over again as the language is torturous in my opinion .

Journey . Ours is a period of time during which the destination reached quickly becomes more typical than the joy of a meandering journey . In a novel titled , The High Mountains of Portugal , suited for long TSA lines and congested traffic , Yann Martel offers ideas on our search for meaning , the importance of journey , and our relationships with other animals and with the natural world . Structured as three linked stories , the novel offers patient readers finely written prose and a very slow journey from beginning to end . Along the way there are lots of distractions and digressions , and it is in those that key ideas are discovered . Slowing down during the Summer can offer enrichment for many busy people . Consider reading this novel as part of your process of slowing down on your own journey . Rating Four - star I like it

Really ? Mediocre at best . The hype on this book is completely insane - pun intended . It is mundane and even boring at times . Anyone giving it four or five stars has never read a good mystery by a talented writer - e. g. , Jane Harper , Ruth Ware , Louise Penny , even David Baldacci . I only gave it two stars because the plot has some merit , but the execution thereof is sadly lacking . The main character wanders around fluctuating between self pity and revenge . His final action defies logic . And then there is the silent patient who has been ostensibly traumatized , not spoken for many many years , and has been heavily drugged on and off during that time . And yet , when she finally does speak , she becomes completely lucid in a matter of days and has the presence of mind to formulate a rational approach to her situation . And her final act also defies logic . The whole book is a rambling , boring mishmash of the main character 's actions . Again - go read a really good mystery by a really good author . Sorry I spent money on this one .

Poor execution . While I 'm sure that Gorilla Garage will have tons of initial appeal to young story listeners , I did not admire the execution of the story or the illustrations . Gorillas that work on your car ? Should have been a sure winner , but instead I felt that Gorilla Garage fell far short of the mark . The text is flat and predictable , making this not much fun to read aloud . The illustrations are just too cartoony and do n't add much to the story . They have absolutely no energy and do n't provide any added dimensions to a slim tale that fails to take advantage of its many opportunities for humor and charm . I also did n't see the point in an ending that sends all sorts of wrong messages . Both the author and illustrator have done much better work . Even though the thought of a Gorilla Garage might bring about a few chuckles from your preschooler , I doubt if this one will have much staying power among car fans or gorilla lovers . Check out some of this author and illustrator 's other work to get a real feel for their talents and pass the Gorilla Garage on by .

This is a Christian mystery . I expected a lot of things out of a new Ryan Sayles novel , but what I did NOT expect was a Christian mystery . I mean , it 's a really smart , well - constructed novel that is explicitly meant for people who share a certain set of values . If you believe that creating and nurturing life is the utmost calling of mankind , you 'll recognize yourself in the protagonist Norm who is protecting his Christian family against a hollow , malevolent usurpator who hijacks his values to fulfill her psychopathic urges . Norm is a spiritual warrior fighting a losing battle against a predatory secular society . It 's extremely well made for what it is , but it you do n't buy into the values right off the bat , you might wince at the lack of nuance . It also means this book was probably not meant for you .

Full of errors and inconsistencies . I had high hopes for this book , and I love the spirit behind it . It is cheerful , exuberant and the Latin spin on old classics is refreshing and new . BUT the book is full of errors . There is nothing more annoying than finding inconsistencies , errors and oversights in recipe after recipe . In one recipe , coconut and quinol is added to the dough , but then the instructions tell you to sprinkle those same ingredients on top instead . One recipe tells you to add toasted seeds to the dough , but the photograph shows a thick layer of seeds coating the bread - the recipe makes no mention of this . One recipe instruct you to bake the bread in a loaf pan , but the photograph shows a rustic , oval artisan loaf . It would n't be impossible to improvise , or to figure out what was really meant , but that defeats the purpose of learning from the authors expertise . Repeatedly , the photographs do not reflect the actual recipes . Its confusing and unhelpful . I really wanted to love this book , but the sloppy production and lazy editing make it very difficult to use .

Out of fear , enemies are born . halo returns full of doubts , and confesses all to his lord , who purifies Haplo through pain . Cold once more , Haplo is sent on to Chelestra , the last world where he finds a vast ocean , where sea moons float in bubbles of air . The story quickly switches to the mensch dwarves , elves , and humans , who have managed to form a lasting peace . They are about to migrate to a new sea moon , until a new enemy appears , demanding a sacrifice to stay their hand . The story continues the transition that began in Fire Sea , humanizing Haplo through a series of quick subplots as he struggles to reconcile who he is with who he thinks he should be . This brings the characters much closer , but also serves as a stalling tactic , postponing the main conflict until other plots have a chance to catch up . The story manages to create some touching moments , but ultimately proves anticlimactic , leaving characters and audiences waiting for the next installment . Strong CharactersStrong SettingWeak main plot , strong subplots Some interesting ideas - Anticlimactic Ending35

Only 5 pages of instruction , the rest is all practice pages . I ca nt for the life of me understand all the great reviews . I checked this and numerous other hand - lettering modern calligraphy books out of the library , and compared to the others , this is a joke . Its about 90 practice pages , which is great for practicing , but there is barely any instruction . This would be better thought of as a workbook to accompany an actual instructional guidebook . I enjoyed it , but feel kind of guilty about that . I found this an incredibly light read , enjoyable in the way that a guilty - pleasure beach book would be . I liked learning about the stones themselves . However , anyone with even a passing interest in history or a decent high school level education would know the history presented , and like other reviewers , I sincerely doubt that jewels alone were the major catalysts in the historical events presented . I also took exception to the author 's sometimes - arrogant style and the habit of presenting the Catholic Church as arch villain over and over again while no one argues the point that there are shameful episodes in the Church 's history , do we really need " clever " comments like " this puts the pick in Catholic " ? Juvenile . And I was put off by the plethora of spelling errors du Berry ? du Barry ? " fluorescence " or " florescence " ? et . I also do n't understand why the author found it necessary to footnote items of generally accepted historical truth . There are times when these unnecessary footnotes are about on the level of footnoting something like " Columbus sailed on his first voyage in 1492 " . Really ? Where 'd you get that information ? Cite it !

Not up to Jennifer Saint or Madeline Miller . After having read Jennifer Saints magnificent Ariadne and Madeline Millers laudable Circe , this is a disappointment . Miller also made the mistake of trying to include every god , demigod , and mortal of the classic age , but she knew how to get to the heart of Circe and Odysseus . Haynes never gets there . Using Calliope and Penelope as the Greek Chorus , two women who were not involved in the Trojan War , she never finds a focal point . Although she presents women we want to care about e. g. Iphigenea , Hecabe , Briseis , Andromache , unlike Saints approach with Ariadne and Phaedra , they are not on stage long enough for us to become involved . As I read the chapter on Briseis I had no idea if we were at the start of the war or the middle . Why was the story of the golden apple near the end of the book , when it was responsible for starting the war ? And there were other chapters that felt irrelevant . Many other better retelling .

Over the course of the story , Dug , a loveable but underestimated dog , meets the other main characters , befriends them , and helps them to make their first escape from the villain and the other dogs . As I said , my daughter is a Dug fan and loves having a story about Dug to go with her ASINB0029UC6AQ Dug plush animal , but I could n't give the book more than three stars . Sociologists and other social scientists , notably political scientists need to learn how to work with existing climate models or a sub set of the many now existing in conjunction with plausible models of FUTURE humans'responses to what those climate models are predicting . This book fails miserably in that respect .

If your primary interest is in a picture book on calligraphy you would do better to search the topic on Pinterest at least there you might have a better chance of actually having a caption associated with the images . Ms. Lach disappoints in her limited approach to compiling images for this book . There seem to be as many images of'things'script is fashioned after than there are images of actual script . What is most disturbing is that she neglected to add captions that could offer a description of the script portrayed . There is so little for the student of calligraphy to glean from the pages of this book money would be better spent looking specifically for an historical summary of the craft . Do n't get me wrong I love the images it 's just that I would have really loved to read captions describing them .

A fun read to pass the time . " Breath of Yesterday " is Emily Bold 's second book in her The Curse Series , which apparently first came out in German . Taht probably accounts for some odd transitions here and there from translation but overall , I found the story of Samantha Watts and her time traveling Scotsman , Payton MacLean , to be an enjoyable read while riding the bus . There were a few times when I wish I had read the first book but I think overall I was able to get right into the narrative where Sam and Payton are totally in love and all that but something is wrong with him is n't that usually the case ? true love never runs smooth . While he is getting sicker , Sam must find a way to help him . It is over the top love and sometimes it gets to the point that I had to roll my eyes a bit but it is all in good fun . Again , it is an enjoyable read . Maybe not a great one but a fun one that helps while away the time .

It was as if the author had not decided who the killer was and went back to fit in the reasoning . The killer went from highly organized killer to a disorganized one , too quickly . If you really want solidly written books with more believable killers then try Baldwins Cassidy and Spencer book series .

A great first entry . This review is based on an Advanced Reader 's Edition provided as part of the Amazon Vine program . This is Cherie Priest 's first foray into the world of Modern Dark Fantasy . On the surface , it 's pretty typical . Female vampire protagonist . Did I mention she 's a thief private investigator , and hot ? It has a few twists . The first is that the client is a vampire , a blind vampire . The other odd thing is that its written from the first person . To be honest , I found this to be pretty refreshing . You get to really experience the story from Raylene 's point of view . There are a couple of other real twists to the story , which I really did n't predict . I really enjoyed this book , and will be looking for future Raylene Pendle novels .

Old School Baseball . I came away from 3 NIGHTS IN AUGUST with more respect for Tony LaRussa . Here is an old school manager that anyone who loves the game of baseball can appreciate . LaRussa in action and philosophy is not the pure antithesis of MONEYBALL . A better description would be a heartfelt antagonist . MONEYBALL ca n't measure the heart , and that is what LaRussa is looking for in addition to talent . Some have talents , others have heart , but the special ones , the winning ones , have both . A enjoyable read , but Bizzinger continues to be a little out of his element when he collaborates with others . A PRAYER FOR THE CITY and FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS both had his distinctive voice ringing through them . This feels more like a book written and then showed to LaRussa , and then rewritten , which makes it a bit long in the tooth by the end . Still quite good , and Bizzinger is a talent with heart , even if sometimes a little hot headed .

SHOULD HAVE BEEN NAMED " GERMAN MADE DIFFICULT " . I had high hopes for this book . I just wanted to know the German pronunciation of the word " ice " so I could sing " Komm sussed Tod " without sounding ignorant . I have consulted at least a half dozen sources and have at least four different answers . Is it ike ? Is it eek ? Is it is ? Is it mesh ? Is it something different ? I still do n't know , so I still do n't know how to sing it . This book is written strictly for the intelligentsia . For one thing , only the international symbols are used for pronunciation . This means that you have to learn a new language before you can even attempt pronouncing German . I did n't expect to have any trouble . After all , I was an " A " student in college . I minored in French and took English Phonetics , but I still found this book too difficult to be practical without the guide of a very learned teacher who speaks perfect German .

Sadly , this is a family tall tale and not true . When tracing genealogy , whether Native American or Black or white , one starts with the nearest ancestor in the case of the Cherokee people , born between 1890 and 1940 and trace back . There are many documents , especially of the Cherokee - both the tribal records and US government census reports and other documentation . One can not just say , " I 'm a descendent of . " it just does n't work that way . The book fails in both departments - as a method of tracing Native ancestry and as a history of the author 's supposed Native American Cherokee heritage . Sadly , while this is a wonderful family story , it 's just another of the many tall tales of Native heritage . Nearly all are false , spawned by misheard , misunderstood , misremembered family stories . If you 're seeking your Native AmericanCherokee ancestry , please do n't waste your money .

Disappointed . Update After partially completing 20 puzzles , I threw this book in the trash . It was horrible and I recommend that you do n't buy it . I was desperate for a crossword puzzle book . I guess it 's because of COVID 19 but home entertainment media is more important now than ever and should be bumped up a notch on shipping priority . Anyway , this book was available in 5 days and looked ok . It arrived on time but is not what I expected . Basically , the 2 puzzles shown in the heading are not indicative of the average . And , the " From the Publisher " description displays a puzzle which is obviously from another publication and incorrectly describes the book . Every single one of the first 10 puzzles relies heavily on 11 letter words . There are no themes and the intersected clues are poor . Obviously , I 'm disappointed . Sunday NYT puzzles are too hard for me so maybe I 'll try weekday NYT or USA Today .

Leave This Version of Jonathan on the Shelf . This is a version that includes a lot of material edited out of the original . Not pedagogical as should be . I am pretty disappointed with this book . It starts of with set theory and logic like most discreet proof books . However I felt that the proof sections of this book lacked explanation for proof exercises when needed most . I also found there where problems at the end of the chapter that did n't really mean much to the material that was covered . One example being a chapter going over GCD and LCM which should Euclids algorithm . but there were problems at the end of the chapter that did n't even use GCD concepts at all . also I feel very underwhelmed with the hints given for certain proofs because a lot of the time they just leave you with more questions on how to solve the proof . It really feels like the author was just lazy and instead of fully finishing the proof she just threw some suggestions at you . I feel underwhelmed with how this book prepares you for proofs and overwhelmed at solving them . Would not recommend . Get " Book of proofs " or " How to prove it " before you use this book .

Can I Get a Refund ? I was going to wait to finish this thing before I wrote a review , but I do n't know that I 'll make it that far . Ready Player One was great . This . I was so excited to read it , and then I got this . Honestly , at the 25 mark I could n't help asking myself when Kline was going to get to the point . I trudged on , but getting beat over the head with the author 's politics did n't do anything to make the story more enjoyable . At all . Valuable for teachers , parents and anyone concerned about education . Despite its somewhat silly title , The Queen of Education by LouAnne Johnson is a no - nonsense , hard look at education in the United States , what is wrong with it , and how to fix it . While much of what Ms. Johnson says in not new , she says it based on her first hand experiences as a teacher and the book combines specific examples with general advice . Among the important points that Ms. Johnson makes is that kids are often labelled and see themselves in negative terms as a result . Teachers need to understand their students and treat them with respect . The book is written in a manner that lay persons can understand rather than in the technological babble that is too often the case for education books . If your child is having problems in school this book may well help .

The book started off really well and I was thinking " This is going to be a good Hillerman novel " . My review should actually be 3 12 stars . The book started off really well and I was thinking " This is going to be a good Hillerman novel " . Then suddenly Chee is investigating a possible homicide with no obvious clues and , without what I would call roadmaps , he comes out of somewhere and solves it . I found that part to be unsettling and rather hard to take . I am not going deeply into the storyline because I want others to get the book and decide for themselves whether it deserves a " TONY " . Having an officer in uniform but not wearing a sidearm is totally contrary to every law enforcement SOP I know . I recognize that the story needed an unarmed officer , soooooooo . How the officer survives the danger is what takes this and attempt down to 3 stars . So - a good 4 stars in the beginning then down and down to 3 , leaving a 3 12 average . Now , Anne , I want to see a solid 5 with your next outing and I would like to have The LT involved .

The best book in an overrated series . I did n't dislike this as much as the first one . On the other hand , I did n't like it as much either . And while I 've heard this described as a police procedural and an espionage thriller , it would be more accurate to call it an anti - detective or anti - spy novel . It 's a bit silly how even the well - meaning minority of the police ca n't do anything without the help of crusading journalist Blomkvist but then Blomkvist is clearly supposed to be the author 's fantasy version of himself , willing and able to lay any and every woman who crosses his path . And the intelligence agents are portrayed as inhuman monsters willing to do literally anything to maintain their own illusion of their continued relevance . This is the best book of the series , but really , I do n't see what all the hype is about . just good marketing , I guess .

Essays Biased Right Wing Propaganda . I thought this would be a spectrum of articles both pro and con - however , they are not only all " con " but they are the most outlandish collection of assertions on this topic . I teach a segment on political correctness at the college level , and did n't see that this book was put out in 1994 . I give it two stars because it will be helpful to see how political correctness is distorted by its opponents . No wonder so many people are against political correctness if they believe that supporters have this agenda . They assuredly do not . Some of my students think there are laws requiring political correctness . There are not . If there are legitimate arguments against political correctness , they wo n't be found in this collection of propagandists'essays .

Should be called Summary of Fut Sao Wing Chun . Its a good book in that it provides an overview of Fut Sao . I was fortunate enough to study under one of Henry Leung 's students who is not mentioned in the book so I absolutely love the techniques of the system . I had heard of James Cama before along with a few of the other students who studied under Henry Leung , They were all very good and intimidating in many regards . To say the book is satisfactory is not to do the author or the subject an injustice . I just expected more based on the title . They glossed over the system and provide in depth pictures for primarily the first form . They also discuss Chi Sao a little . So I would say my only disappointment is that the second and third forms were not really elaborated on just mentioned along with a few other things unique to the system . Either way , Its a good book and deserves to be purchased . I just felt like with an opportunity to discuss such a rarely heard of style , more would be put into it .
