Another chapter in history of WWII that everyone needs to know . There are not enough words to describe how much I loved this book and learning about Odette Samson . The author tells the story in such a gripping , fantastic way . A page turner from start to finish . It is astounding that after many years of reading about this war this was the first time I 'd ever heard of Odette and what she endured . What an astounding piece of history , especially for any interested in the history of women , of spies , and the depravity of the German SSNazis . A special light in heaven shines from the presence of Odette , a light that was first lit during the life she led in this world .

This boring bunch of mechanical studies is what it claims . This is extremely tedious technical mechanics for classical guitar . It claims to be that and does n't pretend to be expressive . It covers a lot of advanced techniques and is relatively thorough . It is hard to imagine that with all the amazing music to study in the world that it is worth anyone 's time to go through this . I did once , and I was intrigued by some of the things that were new to me at the time . However , I 've since seen more musical and expressive books that introduce these ideas much less rigidly . I ca n't recommend that anyone bother with this - but partly that is because I feel that absolutely pure technique is not a valuable pursuit in general . The book succeeds at its intended purpose .

Great read and historical context ! I have been practicing martial arts for nearly 35 years , served as head instructor at a highly successful school with over 400 active students , and now work in higher education where research is an essential component of my appointment . I can say without reservation or hesitation that McCarthy sense 's contributions to classical karate are among the most profound . I have been acquainted with some of the documents in this text in the past having them all together in one place makes for an indispensable reference and resource for any serious learned wanting to understand the anthropology , ethos , philosophy , and theoretical framework from which this rich tradition was forged . In addition , it is just a darn good read !

Terrible Book from a Terrific Show . Our 2 - year old son likes Little Einsteins and watches it occasionally , so I decided to get him this book as a potty - training incentive . What the heck ? ! Instead of hurting her , why did n't the writers make the witch learn her lesson and start being nice ? This story has no moral to it and does n't help your kids in any way . Bad Trip . I 'm a huge fan of PKD , but this is not a novel I find palatable . It starts out innocently enough , with a protagonist and a problem Are the mass migrations sponsored by a huge conglomerate to a new world real or a hoax ? Our hero sets off to find out , but is shot with an LSD - laden dart at the other end of his journey . If you 've never taken LSD , and want to know what a bad trip is like , read on . The story disintegrates here and becomes an acid - washed jumble of characters reflecting on the nature of the reality , or unreality , they live in . It ties together at the end , but the middle chapters are as ugly as LSD flashbacks .

Once again , we see love is not all you need , especially when you are a parent . Rosie and Rex are somewhat star - crossed lovers , and their differences bring them together even while they keep them apart . While living in the blush of love , they bring two children into their marriage , and they do n't know how to keep it all together , despite desperately wanting to . I got very angry at these parents for keeping their mouths shut when they should be talking , being rigid when they should be bending , and not setting their feet down when that was absolutely required . This was a tearjerker , but it ends on a positive note . Even when we are n't quite sure how to love someone , if we are willing to be vulnerable , uncomfortable , and try though we 're sure it will cause us torture , we are all better for having walked openly through the pain .

Do n't bother utterly annoying . I 've tried several times to slog through this needlessly incomprehensible book . While I agree that it has a David Lynch - esque quality to it , the enjoyment of that characteristic is completely overshadowed by the disjointed manner of storytelling . It never grabs you and pulls you in like a good story it hops around from past to present before one has a decent grasp of the characters or the proper investment in finding out where the story is going and what 's going on . I gave it two stars because the author 's turns - of - phrase are evocative and his sentences , as individual entities , are well - crafted . It 's just a shame that to enjoy those qualities , one would have to meander through vague references , and turn back and forth to tell who 's who and what he 's talking about . I do n't have that kind of interest or time .

Lazy Construction . 1 . A forwarding chapter on specific needs for men that outlines the challenges faced in adapting traditional grooming products would have been useful . Others have noted that there is no information on what beard type , skin type or problem type each of the recipes is trying to address . I have seen product descriptions for things like " patchy beard " , " african beard " , " scratchy beard " . The authors do not include this information so it 's up to the maker to try and figure it out . 2 . Another person said product photos would have been helpful and I agree . I have multiple books from other authors within the same price point and all of them have beautiful photographs of completed recipe 's . 3 . Not including a'Total Yield'on each recipe in grams or ounces is supposed to be offset by a chapter " Spec Sheet " that gives average yield and cost to make . Problem is , that spec sheet does n't specify if the yield is are or post cure . No mold size is specified either . What could have been a magnificent guide has been relegated to mediocre . It 's clear that keeping cost to publish down lost to presentation . I am unlikely to purchase anything else from these authors .

Cats in Paris . Cats in Paris captured my eye because of the pretty cover . I am a cat lover so I hoped that this coloring book would be for me , sadly though I was n't really impressed . The pages are thick and double sided which sometimes made it a bit hard to color . I also did n't like how the design ran right into the center of the book making it very difficult to color . Another thing that was a negative was that the pages were n't perforated , so if I want to remove them to hang or share with others it would be very difficult . One thing that did impress me was that the back of the dust jacket can actually be colored . While I liked the various scenes and as a cat lover really enjoyed that there are various felines to color overall I found this coloring book a bit lacking . Really just OK in my book , probably not a coloring book that I would purchase . A complimentary copy of this book was provided for review .

Terry no longer writes good books . It 's unfortunate because he used to be my favorite author . Terry has a habit of regurgitating the same information over and over again in a novel , in a very redundant manner that has the reader skipping through pages because it all becomes so similar . The first four or five Sword of Truth novels were excellent , but the next seven or so suffered this same fate . It 's almost like he is just trying to hit a word quota . The other issue is he goes down political tangents that take us out of the action and into topics we are trying to steer clear of in fantasy and suspense . I ca n't recommend this book when there is much better fantasy available elsewhere .

Not Constructive . If you collected all the one - or two - line helpful hints tucked into cookbook page sidebars or cooking magazine write - in columns and categorized them roughly by type of food they related to , you would have this book . There appeared to be very little rhyme or reason as to the order suggestions appeared in or what made each one more worthy of inclusion than any other tip or trick . The jumble of italics , blue type and bold - ed print was distracting and did nothing to make the pages feel more organized or less random . There are no pictures , charts , illustrations or anything else that one might understandably expect to see in a cooking guide . There 's nothing wrong with any of tips offered and in a different context many of them would probably be useful . As it is , they will be difficult to find when you want them and pointless unless you have a photographic memory and can pull them up on demand when cooking .

Dull and ponderous . The prose is lovely , but this book is maddeningly repetitive . The grandfather and grandson meander in circles through time , chasing women , drinking , and having fistfights . They are also very speedy travelers the only fast thing about this book , leaving Nebraska and arriving in Minnesota or New Mexico after a brief reminisce about a sexual encounter . Upon arrival , nothing much happens , and whichever character is doing the traveling conjure up some more sex memories and then is miraculously back where he started . The zillion layers of flashbacks are confusing . There is no plot , and the reader is merely kept hanging by the suspense of the grandson discovering his biological history . I blame the editor for not reducing the 446 pages to half that or fewer . Forcing the author to tighten up the stories would have greatly improved the flow of the book .

High Hopes . I wanted to like this book , but I began shooting holes through the plot early into the story . How can a woman who has run a farm , raised and shown cattle for most of her life , be so amazed and dazzled about how a turned calf is pulled ? Huge round bales of hay are not stacked in a barn . How can she be violently sodomized and be so anxious for a romantic encounter a few hours later ? And , of course , the bad guys are one political party , the good guys , the other . Yup , yup , if I may be permitted to use the frequently overused phrase in the story .

Disappointing read . I liked the idea of the story , but it could have been fleshed out and edited better . The battle at the end was at least one third of the entire book . It was too long , too unbelievable , and left too many loose ends . I can suspend disbelief for the sake of a good story , but when the ending is as bad as this one , it makes all the plot holes that much more glaringly apparent . Also , the Morgadorians are a little too similar to dementors for my taste . I agree with another reviewer who stated that Sam and Henri were the only interesting characters . I felt no connection to John , Sarah was flat , and Mark was nothing more than a stereotype . True he changes at the end , but why ? It 's never adequately explained .

The flaps are not well secured . The writing is great . The illustrations are wonderful . I love space books for kids . My complaint is the flaps . The paper is flimsy and not well secured to the board pages , which can be a problem for a toddler who grabs and pulls before you can stop him .

Really , a nice Dragon . The basic idea is the main character is looked down upon by his clan and is scheduled for possible termination because he is too nice . He has brothers and sisters who range from feeling disgusted with him to feeling sorry for him and sometimes he gets a hand from one of them . Meanwhile , he spends his time in human form taking courses at the university . But his mother is fed up and is about to terminate him and gives him a task which she is sure he ca n't complete so she can just terminate him - problem of useless dragon son solved . In addition , she takes away his ability to shift into his dragon form . To everyone 's surprise he completes the assignment , albeit not in the way the family would have expected . I flip flopped around about how I felt about the story but it grew on me and I liked the end . Will try the next .

Nicely Done . If you have n't bought Signature Wounds yet , do . More importantly , he 's given me the inspiration to write through the hardships that I 'm experiencing now .

Lots of Simplistic Examples . I have used Excel for well over 35 years , just after I got rid of Lotus in the mid 80s . I have written books on writing business plans , I have prepared hundreds if not thousands of financial models , I have done over 35 start ups as investor or CEO . Thus I know Excel from the business perspective . However every once in the while I want to use some function I have not used and need a quick reference . I thought this would be one on Kindle . However this is a highly disorganized random set of simplistic examples and in the Kindle format near impossible to find anything . I guess it is classic Microsoft . The prime example is if you forgot a " what if " model better just go to you tube and fish around . Do n't try this . The examples are all too simplistic and the overall approach leaves one wondering how best to do a financial model . It is not with this book .

Graphic and Disturbing . I 'll start this review with a warning . The Girl in the Road contains some very graphic scenes in terms of both sex and violence . While that 's not my cup of tea , I can handle it up to a point . Unfortunately , this book went far beyond that point there is one brief but highly disturbing scene involving an adult engaging in sexual acts with a young child . For me , that is just too much , and it is not anything I ever want to read in a book . That being said , if you can handle extremely disturbing sexual situations and violent scenes , you might find you really enjoy this book . Up until that particular scene I mentioned above , I was quite happy with The Girl in the Road . There is an intensity in the narration that draws the reader in , and the skyrocketing levels of desperation and urgency make it difficult to put the book down . The story was unique , compelling , and addictive , but the content was n't right for me . Without the incredibly disturbing scene , I would have given this 4 stars , but with it I 'm bringing it down to just 2 .

Too Much in Too Little . " Ellen Foster " is the tale of an eleven - year - old girl who is forced into adulthood all too early . After her mother 's death , her abusive father neglects her and she dreams of ways in which to kill him . She eventually goes through a series of foster care situations hence the last name of Foster , and suffers the abuse as well as the kindness of strangers . The novel is a brief read and perhaps that is part of its downfall . Kaye Gibbons tries to cram too much into too little . People have commented on old Ellen 's actions and what befalls her . Yet some of what occurs in her life is too fantastical to believe , even for a southern novel . She suffers so much at all times , that after a while , the reader is bogged down with no chance of breaking the surface . While Gibbons is able to weave vivid characters such as Ellen 's poor " friend " and her elderly aunt , she does n't ground them in reality and they remain unbelievable .

A fun read . I 'm a fan of Lindsey Davis , Saylor , and Maddox Roberts . I 've picked up a lot of Roman history from reading their mysteries . And , a recent visit to Rome to view archeological sites gave me a good feel for the streets and houses , forums and temples , that these authors describe . I did enjoy this mystery although it 's not as well written as the Falco stories . Flavia seems too modern in attitude to be believable as a daughter of a Roman citizen . The plot is okay , but not exciting and puts no demands on the reader . The history on which the story is based is interesting however , and the festival scenes are amusing . I look forward to reading the future adventures of Flavia .

vow . 6 Wildcat Mr. Terrific Weak art alert ! This particular collection is of interest to fans of the JSA because it contains the stories that give Wildcat and Mr. Terrific their memberships . A Sad Excuse for an Explorer 's Guide and Prima Publication . I purchased this because I was super excited about SWTOR and it was the only publication for the game released at the time . I just want to point out that I DID realize it was an atlas explorer 's guide and not a strategy guide beforehand . I gave this two stars because it is a horrible excuse for an atlas . I 'm not sure if the authors had enough hands on time with the game while they were compiling this or if they did n't have a large enough staff team to do it correctly but there is absolutely too many things missing from these maps to make it helpful to a player . The only thing this does is give you a vague look at each planet , provides a bit of background information , and the location of some random . RANDOM . useful NPCs and areas . I 'd recommend using the money you 'd spend on this to add some game time to your account or purchase something else all together .

So ends the Elementals trilogy . So ends the Elementals trilogy and it was satisfying and much fun . Amie Kaufman created such a whimsical and rich world that focuses the most on family and togetherness . Battle Born did a great job wrapping up everything while still enriching us , the reader , with more to learn and see . One of the best aspects of this series has always been the characters and this finale was no different . Every character had a purpose , a drive , a reason to help . It was so heart warming to watch this found family take on so much together . I will say I was still left wanting a little more from this world . It seems so massive and we only just scraped the surface , so I really hope we get to discover more in the future . The Elementals was Amie 's first venture as a solo author and she executed it wonderfully . Here is hoping we get more stories from Amie , just Amie . That 's not saying I do n't want more of her collaborations with other authors because I do .

Ok but not for everyone . This story uses examples of generosity that may or may not work for all families ages of children . While some of the scenarios it presents are great like sharing your time with a friend to cheer them up when they are sad others did n't work for us . Some examples being generous by sharing cookies from your lunch would get you in trouble in our school where there is a no sharing rule due to allergy concerns , my child is n't old enough to be saving money to buy a toy , and being generous by watching a to show you do n't like does n't work well in our house since we are tv - free . I would recommend previewing this to make sure it fits your child 's ageyour families activities . Even if I had found the examples better for our situation I would probably just check this out from the library as the text is fine but not especially compelling and the book uses rather sterile stock photography that gives the book the feel of being cheaply produced . I will be looking for other books to teach generosity .

Not terribly useful . All in all , there 's not much to recommend about this book . It has two sections , one dedicated to using the Manga Studio EX software , and the other giving general tips about creating Manga comics . Both sections are terribly light , with basic instructions but lacking the kind of depth or detail that other art books often offer . This is especially true of the section about creating comics , which is generic in its content - it really repeats basic comic advice that can be had in a dozen other books , without offering anything new . The software itself a trial comes with the book seems an awful lot like Photoshop with a lot of preset custom brushes and such , but then lacking the versatility that PS offers to do more than Manga . Perhaps if the book had been dedicated solely to the program , and gone on from the basic - basics into highlighting tips , tricks , and tools more , I would see more value in it . As is , I could n't recommend it .

A labor of love about a totally irrelevant subject . The writer clearly knows what he is talking about , and he is a respected auto racing journalist . However , this book is boring as hell sometimes . It is overlying and tedious . I simply do n't care about men in suits going around battling about stock market , power games , et et . Yes , it was and is important due to jobs involved . But , ti race fans , I do n't care at all . The end result of this mess was a spec series without any fun , with some teams so powerful that they can put FOUR cars on the grid every race . And one of the team owners even BOUGHT Indianapolis Speedway ! The business men , as almost always , destroyed the sport due to sheer greed disguised as " we want the best for everyone " .

Fake money is a really mean trick to play on servers . I 've known a few waiters and waitresses , and getting fake money like this as a tip ALWAYS makes them angry . Even when using a comically large denomination like this , it STILL looks like actual cash as the wait staff approaches the table to clear it . This is n't " spreading the word . " This is a cruel joke played upon people who are already working largely for tips . If you leave garbage like this as a tip , you are a jackass and an embarrassment to Christians everywhere . I know two people who leave fake money tracts as a tip when they eat out . One is a cheapskate who uses the tracts as an excuse to not tip , and the other is an atheist who is deliberately trying to make Christians look bad .

Way too long for what it is . 40 - something male reader This book easily could have been half the length that it is but for whatever reason the editor decided to let Doctorow be as discursive as he pleases . It tested my patience as an adult and I 'm sure it will test the patience of the young adult target audience . Also , for adult readers with an iota of knowledge about economics , be prepared to sit through a lot of spoon feeding of basic principles for the young adult audience . As other reviewers have commented , it is a soup of characters without any strong lead . And once the basic conflict is set up it kind of plays out as one very long chase sequence in slow motion . Doctorow was trying to set up some grand global web that would ultimately coalesce but he overreaches and under delivers . The conclusion of the book is the very definition of anticlimax . I enjoyed " Down and Out in the Magic Kingdom " and have n't read any others of his since . This book was a disappointment . Ca n't recommend it for anyone young or old .

Contains the original illustrations . I recently purchased this book for my nephew , because I remember reading the Weekly Reader version when I was a kid . It also has some good messages about not being afraid of things you do n't understand and not making assumptions about people . It might not have the best stranger danger advice , however , as the protagonist enters a stranger 's home while trick or treating , but to be fair , the protagonist is also a talking anteater , so . Murder , Mystery , and Twist . Rage leads the American reader into an interesting world of Poland 's criminal investigation and prosecution laws . A skeleton is found in an old WW II underground shelter . At first believed to be the skeleton of a forgotten body from the war , forensic investigation reveals it is the skeleton of a very recent murder . As Prosecutor Teodor Szacki learns more about the identity of the victim , he discovers an intricate web of events that seem unrelated , but actually have a common motive . The plot was believable , the characters credible , and the setting fit the storyline - gray , dismal , and despairing . Some scenes were very disturbing with graphic descriptions of violent crimes , which is to be expected in adult mystery detective literature . I am only rating this a 3 because there were times I was not sure which character 's perspective was into play when the storyline transitioned from one scene character to another . Perhaps something was lost in the translation - I am not sure . The novel sets a grim tone from the beginning to the end , as Prosecutor Teodor Szacki finds himself investigating a murder whose criminal motives penetrate the rigidity of investigative law with which he has barricaded himself throughout his career .

Poor word choice taints excellent book . Even in 1974 when this book was written , the use of the N word was clearly objectionable . This is also the first time I have encountered the word in a British historical book . Usually , people of color regardless of ancestry , are referred to as Moors , regardless of the accuracy . TBH , this is one historic detail I can live without . Besides that unnecessary unpleasantness , I enjoyed the writing of this author . His prose is detailed but crisp . I find nothing dated , overwrought or drawn out like many works of that time period . There was a great twist and satisfying conclusion . Really entertaining . I will try a second book , but if the use of racial slurs is a common occurrence , I will not be supporting this author . In this time period , black people were known by several monikers . The author made a deliberate choice to choose the most hateful and disparaging . I 'm just not okay with that .

Author not credible . Jeffrey Feinman obviously did a lot of work compiling information and quotes about Christie and her work - I appreciated that effort very much . He does work to quote people to back up his statements - some of the time . I think to write a credible book that includes sweeping opinions on the work including specific books of the most successful author of fiction of all time - the writer should establish some sort of credibility to do so . This particular writer has written a book on how to win at bingo and then this one on Christie - not credible .

Solidly entertaining ! Traditional Bentley Little ! This is another novel by Little that I really like . It was a bit more scary than the last couple of his that I read and that probably helped me to like it even more . The novel centers around Gregory Tomasov and his family as they move back to the small town in which Tomasov grew up . This move was made possible after Tomasov won the lottery . But what they do n't realize is that the house they move in to is haunted , and pretty soon it becomes the whole town that is haunted . The spooky events and frights slowly build up and become quite chilly especially when major characters start getting killed . I 'm always a sucker for having a major character that we have grown to know and like suddenly getting killed it 's so much more shocking and thrilling than a minor , nearly nameless nobody biting it . One of the other things that I liked about this novel was how the Molokan religion was a key part of the story but at the same time it was n't thrust on us . The religion was just part of the story and not the " moral " that so many other authors make it instead .

Mudbound The Best Book I 've Read In Years ! This is an exceptional book . I wo n't talk about the story much , as many have done that before me . I have recommended it to 14 friends . I was moved , shocked , amazed , entertained , given new knowledge in a way that made me laugh and broke my heart . I ca n't this book more than 5 stars I would give it 10 if possible . Buy it , enjoy it , learn something wonderful and terrible about our country . Hats off to an author who gives us a beautifully written book , with interesting characters we love and dislike intensely . Always the characters act appropriately for their place in the story and in ways that surprise us , delight us , and repel us . In the end I felt as if I was living in the story . Yes , an exceptional book . I am most grateful , and will read it again and again .

I think that children in first through third grade will definitely enjoy this book .

Good , but Abby can get annoying . This is Christopher Moore 's newest and probably last entry into his vampire series Bite Me . It had to be the shortest book of his yet and it felt that way in many respects . The first 75 pages or so was basically a recap of the previous books that I could have done without , which was mostly voiced by Abby Normal the teen goth minion of the main characters from the first two books . Abby 's voice was a bit of a roller coaster ride for me . She was definitely funny and sparky in a good way , but too repetitive with her dialogue and actions . Still , Bite Me was a hilarious Moore novel that probably ranks in the middle of all his books with Lamb being him in top form and Fluke near the bottom for me . The ending also felt too rushed , but there are plenty of vampire kitties and enjoyable dialogue to push all the right buttons . Bite Me also made me realize how much I missed the Emperor of San Francisco . If you are a Moore fan this will be a must for you .

me . Younger fans of Twilight fan - fiction will probably like this . I like urban fantasy , and typically love reading books like this one . It was n't a bad read , it just seemed kind of predictable and it did n't pull me into the story . Also , there did n't really seem to be any sparks flying between Xoe and Jason , which made their romance a little improbable . Maybe this was the author 's first book . If so , it was a valiant first effort . However , I do have a few notes for her . First , less shark in your descriptions . There would be sections where Xoe would be telling us about something from her perspective , and then get defensive . Then she would say things like " Do n't judge us . " OK . Next , less telling your audience what 's happening . More showing . Finally , I think your main character was a little too accepting of what was going on around her . Suddenly . her friend is a werewolf and she is ok with it . Suddenly . Zoe is a half - demon with fire power dating a vampire and she is ok with that too . It just seems unreal .

Half Great , Half Not So Much . I started out very impressed with this book . The illustrated instructions for cooking and presentation techniques with beans , grains , porridges , et . were excellent , if slightly dated . This would have been a great resource to get my hands on as a new cook or when I was trying to master new techniques . The second half of the book , unfortunately , is a collection of densely packed recipes all squished in together . That poor formatting makes them surprisingly anti - user - friendly , especially in comparison to the first half ! I would definitely recommend getting your hands on a copy of this to look through before purchase if at all possible if you 're buying for the recipes . As a technique reference , however , it is a great investment !

If you are looking for an overview and personal medication . If you want an overview and personal meditation , then this book is for you . If not , then you will probably be disappointed . Clearly , in so short a book , one does n't expect to find excessive detail , but very much was missing from this book . Add to this a dullish style , and there is n't much to redeem the book . The bright sides of the book were the sections on Joan 's virginity and the review of how Joan was portrayed by various authors and in various films . But this is not enough to make up for an otherwise tepid book . I do n't think the book measures up to the others in this series that I have read to far on St. Augustine and Mao Tse Dung .

It was okay , but would 've been so much more . This was an okay ending to an okay series . I saw a glimpse of Robert 's voice in this one , so whoever ghostwrote this one did a little better job mimicking Roberts than whoever wrote the latest In Death book Indulgence in Death . The plot was okay , the pacing was okay , almost everything was just okay . The problem was with the details - we were immersed in every detail of every cake , every dress , every flower , every photo , every bride . until we really did n't care what happened to Parker and Mal as long we did n't have to sit through one more event . There was no tension , no sizzle , and almost no characterization amidst all those details . And that 's too bad , because their story would 've been awesome . Roberts , I sincerely wish you were n't tired of writing . your readers miss you .

Hen Party Gone Wrong . Beautiful and magnetic former dancer and party girl Lexi is engaged to be married to a seemingly perfect partner , Ed . Her hen party UK equivalent to a bachelorette party is set in Greece with some of her closest friends , sister - in - law , and MOHs girlfriend . What was supposed to be a good time basking in the Grecian sun , swimming in the crystal clear sea , and consuming too much feta , is turned into a weekend of drama and a death . Lexi does n't know the people that surround her as well as she thinks she does . Every single one of the girls at that villa , and Ed , is holding on to a secret , including her . What happens when they all begin to air out ? I really enjoyed this one . Normally I would complain about super slow lead - ups to have all the drama packed into the last little bit of the book , but here it was necessary for character development , the plot , and the twists . I did n't see any of it coming ! The author also did a fantastic job of balancing and developing six different alternating viewpoints , a hard feat for readers to usually follow along with . The chapters were also deliciously short . Solid 45 stars .

I was pleasantly surprised , after reading a couple negative reviews , to find I liked this book quite a lot , though I did like The Traitor 's Wife and Hugh and Bess more than The Stolen Crown . I read this book in just a couple days , and found that it had a good pace , interesting characters , and natural dialogue or what I assume is natural for the time period . I especially liked the first few chapters when Kate and Harry were young - quite amusing . I also enjoyed seeing some of the same events from 2 different perspectives . I admit though , that if one does not know a basic outline of this time period War of the Roses then it will be extremely hard to keep up with the many characters , many of whom have the same name . I appreciated that the author tried to be clear about who each person was - referring to titles and relationships , as well as names , to differentiate all the Richards , Edwards and Margarets . I would recommend this to someone that is interested in that time period and likes historical novels , but not to someone that wants a simple historical romance which I do enjoy sometimes .

The Greatest Story Ever Told . Many people believe that the greatest story ever told is an ancient myth that has survived the ages . My vote for this distinction is Miracle In The Andes - a true story about 16 beautiful young men who survived a plane crash in the early 1970s . The theme is transcendence - of nature , of the human condition , of personal limitations and of cosmic bad luck . It makes you nearly as breathless as those who were stranded for 72 days at 12 , 000 feet with their injuries , the corpses of family members and friends , no food , no warm clothing or enclosed shelter . But the book does n't leave you breathless . At the end , the mature memoirist reflects on the meaning of the ordeal and teaches a lesson about love that may surpass anything you ever learned in sunday school ! The writing is flawless , as brilliant as the Hope diamond . Imagine the literary qualities of Primo Levi 's If This Were A Man combined with Maurice Herzog 's Annapurna , and you begin to get an idea of this book 's majesty .

Gripping story overrides format errors . When I bought the first three books for my Kindle , I did n't realize there was a fourth until I finished book 3 last week . And lo , there it was in my recommendations . I loved the story Men and women kicking butt and taking names , the dead get a chance to have the final word before going to their just reward , and all the major players get pretty much what they deserve . Martin makes it clear that Happily Ever After is n't always going to be all kittens and rainbows , but she does end the story at a satisfactory point . The biggest problem I had with this eth book was the rough file proof only one paragraph in 3 was free from missing spaces , and all the em - dashes were hyphens . There was a bit of extra space between paragraphs , and the italics coding looked like it was botched in a few places . I do n't claim to be the most perfect writer , but I 'm the sort of person who gets knocked out of a story when I see a grammatical error . Despite all the bumps in the road , I still maintained my excitement over the journey I took with these characters .

Older woman finds confidence to love again , with a lot of help from the younger generation . This review is based on an exclusive ARCA Dragonfly 's Whisper is another of the author 's Water Skipper series of modern fairy tales where individual insects are carriers of magical properties . In book 1 water skippers have saved Eden . In this volume , the Dragonflies will save Nora from her own reluctance to love . Nora was the older housekeeper of Kyle in the first book and this book picks up from the end of that book as her longtime beau Roman decided on finally to make an honest woman out of her , and enlisted all the kid 's help to mount the perfect wedding . She was hesitant as she did not believe she can love Roman because she gave her heart once to Aiden , her first love . But can she believe in herself again ? As in the first book , this is about sweetness , and fairy tales , with little emotional stakes and conflict . It 's even YAChild friendly except for the innuendos . If you want to experience heartaches loss , then redemption this is not the book for you .

I find myself wondering what to say about this . This book just does n't seem to have left much of an impression which surprises me because it had an epic " Man against an empire " start with a good foundation and characters that might have been great . I think what diminishes this book is the age of many of the characters . The hero is centuries old , as is the empire and as are many of the leading villains . And they feel old in the reading about them . There is a poignant sadness to their actions and relationships that just drags the book . It makes too many sections maudlin . Its not bad , although the action scenes get disjointed more than once , and the power levels of main characters turns battles into massive 1v1 fights rather than tactical and strategic contests . which is n't uncommon in fantasy tales , but it just seems too obvious here , for some reason . I liked this tale , but at the same time , I just did n't care about the characters , the situation or what is to come , and that 's not exactly good . 3 stars for now . Review of book 2 might not happen .

Not a Great Story , But Great Fun For Dug Fans . Our five year old is a big fan of Dug , one of the characters in ASINB001KVZ6FW the recent Pixar movie , Up . She was delighted to get this book . Other young fans of Up or Dug would be too , but most other kids would probably find it a little dull . Using simple , cute artwork that resembles cutout collages , this book basically tells the story of the first two - thirds of the movie as seen through the eyes of Dug . Over the course of the story , Dug , a loveable but underestimated dog , meets the other main characters , befriends them , and helps them to make their first escape from the villain and the other dogs . As I said , my daughter is a Dug fan and loves having a story about Dug to go with her ASINB0029UC6AQ Dug plush animal , but I could n't give the book more than three stars . First , the writing is a little basic . Second , given that they were retelling the movie , I 'm not sure why Disney did n't just add 3 or 4 pages and finish the story . In my opinion , both of those would have added a lot .

Buyer Beware ! At first glance this appears to be a very appealing book for children to teach them about the historic battle of Gettysburg . However , I caution all parents that there is a nasty hidden agenda within these seemingly innocent pages . See attached photo . What on earth do Gay rights have to do with Gettysburg ? Totally inappropriate and off topic to include and mention this as well as the montages on pages 58 and 59 . Can we just stick to the given topic for once without pulling in all these modern day agendas that have zero to do with the historical importance of the Civil War ? When I look at these modern books I am grateful my children have a classical education with old and accurate books that do n't alter history . This could have been such a fun way for children to learn about one of the most important and sad battles of the civil war . It is a shame it was ruined by unnecessary and off topic modern day agendas . What would Lee and Grant say ?

Bitter Blather . While the work is verbose and literary , it is annoyingly simple and repetitive . The juiciest parts of the book are the near - sci - fi bursts of Idiocracy , where social media has warped everyone into imbecilic attention - whore children . Eventually , this same set of jokes and satire grow stale by books end . The heart of the plot concerns a pair of unlikely lovers navigating their turbulent relationship with each other . The lack of imagination and odd circumstances to this meandering affair can be attributed to this story being largely modeled after the writers own love life in this semi autobiographical tale . The observations and humor simply grow tired by story end , offering nothing new by the end that had n't been ruthlessly flogged earlier in the book . Much like a nouveau Philip Roth , this book is filled with suppressed rage , pseudo - academia and sexual frustration which dominates the narrators black and bitter perspective .

No part sufficient for a whole to develop . The overall sense I received from this work is that Catherine Whitney is more interested in speaking of herself without so much as answering the question of why she suddenly shifted from would - be religious Sister to unbelieving radical feminist . The anecdotal information about several Sisters in the earlier chapters seems a promise of real development later , but this promise remains unfulfilled . Half stories , some of which seem flavored by stereotypes and prejudiced assumptions , are profoundly unsatisfying , particularly since the natural presumption to which the early chapters would lead was that depth , development , and understanding of the various Sisters'situations would follow . It did not happen . There is a sampling of moments from various Sisters'lives not , as the subtitle implies , a chronicle of a year in the life of an Order , but no insight into anything .

well - crafted but not exactly an easy read . Yes , this book is haunting and lyrical . It is as much poetry as it is prose . The writing is bare - boned and sparse , each word carefully chosen . I think this would appeal to some readers , but from my perspective , it was a bit too unadorned . I could n't quite tell where it was set Africa ? the US ? desert or vacated suburbia ? , I had a hard time keeping track of who was narrating , I found the descriptions from the dog 's perspective to be odd and confusing , and I did n't know enough details about the characters to find them particularly compelling . My sense is that this would be a good book for classroom reading , providing fodder for thought and meaningful discussion , but I 'm not sure I would n't recommend it to someone looking for a breezy , entertaining read . The ending is a bit of a downer , and the whole book is humorless and somewhat slow - paced . I felt like I was plodding through a parched dessert when reading it . The book is quite well - crafted , so I do n't have much criticism of the book itself - I just think it has limited appeal .

Started with a Bang , Ended with a Fizzel . I was very cautious when I began reading this book . There are sweeping claims made by Bell , and the reader is expected to take Bell 's word for them . There is some scriptural references , but not enough to substantiate Bell 's claims . I liked the tone , cadence and style of the writing . The claims of empire building in the church are not new to me , and I agree . What I did not like was the misplaced guilt trip and the secular humanistic qualities of the book . Loving and caring for the poor in this world , is NOT the focus of Jesus ministry or the Gospel , as Bell claims . It is certainly important to show Jesus love and care for humanity in practical ways , as almost every one who names the name of Christ does . This message of the arrival of the spiritual kingdom of God is the Gospel . NOT attempting to end the poverty of spirit by a radical demonstration of who Jesus is , yet seeking to implement some form of socialism is a misguided humanist line of thinking .

Lots of terrific recipes , great story . This book is terrific . The concept brings tears to my eyes , and the recipes are fantastic . The first weekend I had this cookbook I made 5 recipes from it the chicken salad , the Better than Better Cheddar , the Spaghetti and Meatballs , the Creole Mustard and the Creole Mayonnaise . All of them were delicious . I 've been looking for a basic chicken salad recipe with specific quantities listed for ages and this is a very good one . My husband is over the moon for the mustard , while the Better than Better Cheddar is my personal favorite . It 's a delicious change - up from pimento cheese and would be PERFECT fare for a baby shower bridal shower I 'm from North Carolina , and I 'm pretty sure some form of chicken salad or pimento cheese is a legal requirement at showers here . I would buy this book for that recipe alone . At any rate , it 's too darn hot to make a lot of the recipes in the book right now , but come fall I plan on trying out every gumbo recipe in it .

We are shown no over all purpose for why this is being done - It 's more like a game to see who can accumulate the most psychics . One recruits them willingly , one against their will . Solid Victorian Stuff . Gerard Freeman , the hero of the book at a very early age in Australia , growing up with his mother , realizes something is wrong with her and with him . He falls in love with a pen pal , who is going to undergo surgery and can become paralyzed . Such is the beginning . True to Victorian times , a large part of the book is spent in Gerard reading old manuscripts , nice short ghostly tales somehow never reaching the finesse that Ms. Byatt achieved in Possession . Perhaps Mr. Harwood did borrow , albeit unconsciously from that book , perhaps not . It is so well written that time and pages fly quickly . Ultimately , everything is neatly tied in with a rather unbelievable climax . Still , a very tidy book . Good ghost stories are hard to come by and the last one was also from Australia , Richard Adams'Watership Down The Girl On The Swing . That was a real spine tingler . This one could have been a stunning novella , in the manner of The Turn of the Screw . Expanding it to a novel length has robbed it of much needed intensity . The author has promise and I look forward to his new book .
Five Stars . A excellent guide .

Then , I was so disappointed by the last half of the book that I did n't even bother to pick the second one up . Like some other reviewers I thought the detail on PTSD was way overdone , seemed just like page filler to me . I do n't mean to sound insensitive about it , but we all know what it is and how devastating it can be . It just did n't warrant so much weight in a novel about really bad guys and various scary , ancient spirits . And speaking of scary stuff , that was my other problem with the novel Way too many bogeymen ! Geez ! You needed a scorecard to keep track of all the weirdo characters . So the bottom line is that the book could have been a lot more entertaining with less information about PTSD , and fewer bad guys to keep track of , human or otherwise . Well , unless you use a scorecard .

I read it after meeting my husband and hearing about his lively , lovely children . Having grown up with Cinderella stories and the notion that stepmoms are necessarily evil I know it 's not true . MY mom was a stepmom and she 's a great one i was hesitant to become the instant baddie in this story . I was relieved to see that someone was brave enough to detail her life , feelings , mistakes , and insecurities for everyone to see - and lived to write another day . Izzy 's blog website has a lot of valuable information for all of us stepmoms and dads out there . I highly recommend it .

Watchers by Dean Koontz . If you are fairly intelligent , you wo n't be very impressed by this book . As others have said , the characters are one - dimensional . The hero is too competent . The dog and the human stalker are by far the most interesting characters , and they are the reason why you may not be able to put the book down . Koontz does have the ability to make you want to keep reading , and that 's why I rate this 2 stars instead of just 1 . The story has good flow , but the ending is truly awful It 's way too brief and unsatisfying , and it 's far too predictable . What a shame . And I thought , " this is it ? talk about a banal plot ! " So an enraged baboon is on the loose - who cares ? Even the title is stupid and undecipherable . The whole book is so underwhelming , except for the dog . The dog deserves a miniseries !

I enjoyed following Danas story and discovery throughout the book . Dana grew up questioning everything and ultimately the government decided to assign her to work in an incinerator plant . There she struggles to survive and ultimately find a way to fight back against her dystopian society . This was a quick , enjoyable read . I enjoyed following Danas story and discovery throughout the book . It has a little bit of a Hunger Games vibe in that most of the county is uninhabited and there are isolated , controlled areas that produce specific goods resources for the government . I did find some of the other characters to be fairly one dimensional and there were a few grammatical errors in my copy . The world is n't too deep or thought provoking , but following a sanitation worker is a novel idea . The pacing was very good and its a good start for a series I look forward to reading . Same old tiresome harangue . Edit this OUT of your reading list ! The War of Northern Aggression was never over slavery . Had the issue actually been slavery , slave labor would not have continually been used to construct federal buildings in Washington , DC , well into the War ! Slavery would have been immediately abolished in every state it was not . Lincoln would to have offered to " let " the Southerners keep their slaves in exchange for not seceding which he did ! This book seems to have been written to be sensationalist , rather than to reflect historical significance . This kind of gratuitous writing is revolting . For a much better read , try Heroines of the South , which is an actual compilation of letters and diary entries by Southern ladies during the War .

An " OK " series so far . I found the first book " When the Heart Cries " to be terribly depressing . In the second book , " When Morning Comes " , many of the opportunities that come Hannah 's way just would not happen in real life . I work in a clinic and I can say first hand that a girl with an eth grade education and no work experience would never be hired , nor would she be asked to assist in delivering babies or put in charge of running a support group with absolutely no education or experience . it just does n't happen in real life . In the short two years Hannah was in Ohio , she got her GED , license , and completed her nursing certificate . again . that would never happen in real life in such a short period of time . Unpleasant experience . This book is really unpleasant . I used it for an introductory mathematical statistics class . Stay away if possible , or borrow from a friend or the library .

Do n't believe the blurbs on the back . I really wanted to like this book . After reading the author 's later work , " The Orphan of Cemetery Hill , " I rushed to the library to get this one , but was sorely disappointed . The writing was good , but after reading almost a third of the novel , I was bored out of my mind and gave up . Nothing much was happening plot - wise and I could n't relate to any of the characters . The atmosphere and setting were reminiscent of so many other works of this type . This was the author 's first novel and frankly I do n't understand how it got published . The blurbs on the back extolling the book 's excellence have made me wary of ever believing such hyperbole again . I 'm cynical enough to believe that the only reason well - known authors like Heather Graham allowed their names to be used to promote such dull drivel was to get their own books mentioned on the back cover .

Pleasant but nothing special . I chose The Girl Next Door because I had read and enjoyed The Reading Group by the same author . Unfortunately , I did not The Girl Next Door as much . This novel is comprised of intertwining stories of residents of a New York City apartment building . It was a pleasant read . But there was no " hook " here at all . Other than one emotional chapter , each story is mundane and predicable . The characters are one dimensional , almost stereotypes . There are so many characters , that we never feel invested in any of them . The writing is okay - but certainly not witty , insightful , full of attitude , poetic , or anything else that would make this novel stand out . It 's not bad , really . There 's just nothing about it that would make me recommend it to a friend .

A terrific read about conflict ! Whether an experienced mediator or just working within an organization , Courageous Conflict is a excellent read . I highly recommend the easy to navigate style that takes you from attitudes of conflicts to how our thinking , perceptions and assumptions make us dig in our heels through how we can find the strength , integrity and courage to change the patterns of how to view conflict more constructively . Throughout , the concepts are introduced straight forwardly with a coaching approach that includes thoughtful questions . Moreover , the all important emotional side of conflict is dealt with practically with straight forward strategies . I highly recommend this book as an addition to mediators ' , organizational development practitioners , and conflict coaches'bookshelves . Deborah S. Laufer , Director , Federal ADR Network

Enjoyable . I liked this book although I found it to be a rather odd amalgam of personal reveal and historic reporting . The historic reporting of the LA Central Library fire was intense and riveting , if in reality unsolvable . The personal reflections , were to me , somewhat insipid and pale . It is a positive thing that Orleans explains why libraries mean so much to her , I just did n't find that it did much to enhance the story . At worst it interfered with the rhythm . I also found that the short chapter format created a choppy narrative that bounced from theme to theme and was to me , less than optimal . Perhaps the format is more suitable to the unfolding of a mystery , this was not it . The title is a bit of a misnomer . It is really about Libraries , the sum of all books , rather than just one .

full of painful memories , she wants to have a normal life . 3 . 5 stars - this book was giving for an honest review by Bookstasters and Brady Stefani - Thank you ! Courtney , a fifteen - year - old girl , wants to be normal . With a scary past , full of painful memories , she wants to have a normal life - normal friends , boyfriends , party . but when she starts to dream about aliens visiting her in her bedroom , things get a little weird . or are they dreams ? All of the information is given little by little , so you get hooked on the pages up until the end ! This is an excellent teenage sci - fi book . Brady Stefani was able to get all the turmoil of emotions and particularities of a teenage girl which only a few authors can really do ! . It was a very pleasant surprise ! The only thing I did n't like very much was the relationship Courtney has with her mom . actually , anything related to her mom . It was very odd to see a parent behave like that . But he gets amazing points for making this book about sorority , girl power and specially , not letting turn into a teen romance ! It was refreshing ! Not my type of book , but I would recommend it for any teen that wants an emotional and intense read !

Full of errors including the title " Panjabi " . This book is a joke . Look at the title of the book in the picture . Panjabi . That is your first clue . The language is Punjabi not Panjabi . There are flash cards you can tear out in this book . I used 36 of them . I had a native speaker check these for me . 16 of the flash cards were correct and 20 were wrong . I did n't even bother tearing the rest out . I was told by the native speaker not to use this book at all because of all the errors and inaccuracies . I 'm so glad I had this book looked over before using it to learn . I ca n't imagine the embarrassment I would have experienced had I spoken some of these translations to people who speak Punjabi . I would have looked like an idiot . If you want to learn the language properly and learn the proper translation for words then do not purchase this book !

Revelations was the best story of all of them . The Inhuman Condition is another example of Clive 's vast and never ending line of macabre , erotic horror stories . Pleasant but nothing special . I chose The Girl Next Door because I had read and enjoyed The Reading Group by the same author . Unfortunately , I did not The Girl Next Door as much . This novel is comprised of intertwining stories of residents of a New York City apartment building . It was a pleasant read . But there was no " hook " here at all . Other than one emotional chapter , each story is mundane and predicable . The characters are one dimensional , almost stereotypes . There are so many characters , that we never feel invested in any of them . The writing is okay - but certainly not witty , insightful , full of attitude , poetic , or anything else that would make this novel stand out . It 's not bad , really . There 's just nothing about it that would make me recommend it to a friend .

The book was of no value to me . I really was n't expecting it to be that helpful , but it was even less thorough than I anticipated . I have a modest Ed . Wusthof collection going back to a few 1814 - 1895 knives , several 1895 - 1920 's , and then pre - WWII to present , roughly 100 knives total . The books coverage however , is abysmal . There are three pages on Anton Wingen , for example , that was in business 1888 - 1993 . For Ed . Wusthof , a company that is family owned for over 200 years , from 1814 to present day , there 's 34 of a page . That meager listing leaves out the 2 earliest company marks . With even my limited knowledge , I could list several pages of maker 's marks for the company , with approximate year ranges , designs , and materials . I wo n't try to return it because the seller did his job with speedy delivery , and there are no promises in the description as to what it will do for me . I 'm commenting just to warn other users to check it out a little more carefully , it 's far from a'bible'of German cutlery .

Keep Me Posted . I predict this fun book will find its way into many beach bags this spring and summer . A must read for anyone who is looking for a nanny ! I 'm in the process of hiring a new nanny and someone recommended this book . It 's been a lifesaver . I never really thought about the details and have sadly spent more time researching a car than who is going to take care of my children ! Tammy lays out exactly what to do and eliminates the anxiety around finding the perfect caregiving . For example , I always knew that references were important but I never thought to ask specific questions relating to my needs vs general questions . I also never thought of having a nanny contract - but now see how important it is so there 's no misunderstanding confusion . Lastly , Tammy does an amazing job of using her psych background to help get inside the nanny 's head and to understand what the nannies are thinking see things from their perspective . I 'm so happy I found this book just in time .

Resource must have for all managers . Jonathan Thomas McKee have provided a very effective resource for those that manage organizations that use volunteers . I owned my own business for 33 years , I was " The Boss . " Today I am honored to work with a 501C3 organization that only has 5 salaried employees and over 150 volunteers . I realized quickly that I had to be in the " Volunteer Development Business " more than just providing the economic support to our clients . The format of this book is wonderful . It is like you are at a seminar asking the authors personal questions and having them answer you as a friend . Do n't just buy this book for yourself , buy one for every member of your organization .

Waste of a couple hours . The premise could be interesting and fully developed but the author fails to do that . This book was a waste of time thankfully it 's a short read and can be read in one extended period . The author attempts to use the " less is more " adage but fails at connecting the reader to the characters . A suspenseful drama does n't need to include such detail that nothing is left unexplained , and I do think the author made good choices in not revealing too much detail . The chapters were so sparse , and the book is already so thin it did n't allow for a more fully developed storyline . The end of the book left me feeling very unsatisfied , somehow cheated by the cheap ended . It was as if the author had no vision how to bring closure , watched some Hollywood movie and came up with the ending after that . To me , it was a waste of time spend more time reading books like Under a Thousand Splendid Suns or other similar books if you are interested in a suspenseful drama where the characters are more developed and it begs the reader for a reaction .

A Pretty Interesting Story . This book was enjoyable and worth the read . The beginning was a little slow , but as the story progressed I began to be drawn in by the author 's villain . The world where this takes place Planet 1 is run by a maniac narcissist who is eager to have the Doctor destroyed and also delightfully paranoid . It was fun to have the Doctor come up against such a strong personality , and I think that 's why this book works . There are some " huh ? " moments where the reader will get lost , but I think it 's purposely written that way . You have to leave your confusion at the door at times and press on to get the answers . For some that can be annoying . Also , Donna seems a little bland . Her character is a strong personality who has a sharp and sarcastic wit about her but it does n't come across in the book . She does n't really spark with the Doctor in the story like she does in the show . The ending was the best part by far . The book is n't perfect and has a few faults but the good heavily outweighs the bad . Just know my opinion is it was a decent story .

Fast paced and fun . Enjoyable with a clever plot line . Good humor at the appropriate times . A super hero reporter gets involved with the bad guys in Washington D. C. and goes for a thrill of a ride . The downside was too many characters and trying to remember who was who and with whom . Thornton 's sidekick , the rich politician , would 've been less helpless . His ex - lover 's husband seemed too friendly with him . But , all in all it was a good read .

Well written , but depressing and predictable . If you are looking for a book that will depress you , House of Fog and Sand is the ticket . Compared to this book , the fiction of Thomas Hardy is comical . The story revolves around three people , all of who are problematic to begin with . The first half largely tells their story in split sections , focusing on Kathy and Lester for a few pages and then on Col . Behrani . It does n't quite work . The Colonel 's section has too many obscure references to Iranian culture and the author does not quite pull off the difference in language use between native Americans and the Iranian . The basis for the plot is also suspect . San Mateo County makes a mistake and sends a bill to the wrong person Kathy who ignores the requests and then loses her house . Not likely . But what makes the book problematic for me and apparently for a lot of other reviewers is the unrelieved misery and sense of impending doom . What happens really does not have to happen solutions could have been found , but things just go from bad to worse until the inevitable happens .

Politics and plot diversions spoil " thriller " about " The Boy " . Harlan Coben is certainly one of our A - list authors were devoured his entire booklist , well over 30 novels so far . While we like his Myron Bolitar series well enough , its these standalone thrillers that typically enjoy our highest ratings . However not so with either his just prior novel Run Away or this one The Boy . We liked the first hundred pages that focused on the boy , aptly named Wilde , and his past and current exploits concerning a missing high school gal . But then the plot descended into political rants about this crooked guy running for President , and some skulduggery and kidnappings associated with that . The story finally got interesting again during the last handful of the 40 chapters , suggesting a lot of filler in between . That said , some unanswered developments might just be a setup for a sequel . This book almost would have made a better novella . Take out the politics , focus on Wilde , and if you need a kidnapping , maybe stick with the girl and her story , and forget about the rest of the characters . We may be in the minority , but to tell the truth , we expected just a little bit better this time out .

I enjoyed the wine making details . The Vineyard at Painted Moon was the April selection for the Page - turners Book Club at the Kewaunee Public Library . Mackenzie has the job that she loves working at her husbands family vineyard . She blends delicious wines that attract a lot of customers . Her world comes crashing down when her husband wants a divorce . What should she do ? Stay and keep working for the vineyard or strike out on her own ? I usually love Mallerys novels , but while I read through this one quickly , I did n't love it . I enjoyed Mackenzies journey and her gumption to strike out on her own . I liked the story of the various family members . I overall though just felt sad for the destruction of the marriage . The novel started out happy with Mackenzies mother - in - law Barbaras engagement , and then Barbara turned into a one - dimensional villain . It was too drastic of a change to me . Mackenzies new romance was not very well developed and felt tacked on at the end . I did enjoy all of the details of wine making and thought that was fascinating . Overall , The Vineyard at Painted Moon was a so - so novel for me . Book Source Kewaunee Public Library . Thank - you !

Readable What - If Scenario . Aliens and Ice Cream is a title which does not convey much about the book itself . The aliens are a monolithic plot device serving primarily as the reason why people are confined to their homes , and ice cream is mentioned once in passing without any plot effect . We never learn why the aliens show up theories are presented with gaping holes in the logic or where things go from where it ends . Another note , technologies alien and human are all presented without a basic understanding of the physics or engineering principles involved . Suspend disbelief on that front in order to enjoy the story . Having said all that Michael James has written an entertaining , if not groundbreaking , story . The teenage characters are the most interesting , while adults and children seem to conform to shallow stereotypes e. g. abusive alcoholic , narcissist , teach nerd , good kid . Personally , I would have liked to see some sort of resolution or plot segue to close out the book , but even without it you wo n't regret the time spent . Disclosure I received a free copy through Veracious Readers Only

Much ado about a point unproved . I picked this off the shelf at a summer cottage when I ran out of books of my own . The book recounts a new theory of how the Titanic sank - rapidly and without splitting in two when the bottom literally fell off the ship - but ultimately failed to make the case . Nowhere did the author come right out and say it , and although the writer apparently had access to the archive of the shipbuilders , no documents are offered that definitely prove the case . As a result , the book ends unsatisfactorily following much ado about a point unproved . However , as a longtime fan of all things Titanic except the Cameron film , I enjoyed the 100 - plus pages he devoted to the why , how and who of the building of Titanic and her sister ships , Olympic and Britannic .

Sloppy Hack Work . How is this book getting such high marks ? Family and friends of the author ? It 's sloppily researched , unevenly edited and reads more like propaganda than history . And if that 's not bad enough , much of Kershaw 's writing is cringe inducing Panzer tanks ? Why not automobile cars ? And why the constant quotation marks to call out terms everyone knows the meaning of " piece of cake , " jolly good sport , " grim reaper " . And do we really need to know the telephone at the airfield was made out of Bakelite every time it rings ? That the Spitfire 's engines were made by Rolls - Royce ? The Messerschmidt 's by Daimler - Benz ? That the Spitfire 's canopy screen was made out of a type of plastic called Perspex ? It 's all so much word padding and it gets annoying fast . When it comes to the Germans Kershaw is so out of his depth he should of just stuck with the RAF pilots . Hans Guderian ? Really . An author writing about World War II does n't catch something that obvious ?

Commas missing everywhere but put in where they do n't belong , words misused in the narrative , not in the character quotesand overused . A few examples " . and a jolt of electricity jettisoned through his body . " It was a patient 's right to sign themself out of the hospital and there was n't much he could do . " He hung up the phone , debating for half a minute as to the veracity of calling her at home , but decided to go with his gut . " if the author does n't know the meaning of " jettison " or " veracity " , surely someone else on the publishing staff ought to ?

Grammar anyone ? I used this textbook for a late - start community college course . What bothers me the most about this textbook are the numerous grammatical mistakes and incomprehensible sentences that occur throughout the text . One in front of me right now pg 395 discusses " payments to Philippine customers officials " . I 'm guessing this should have been " custom officials " ? While I do n't pretend to have perfect grammar myself , I often find my concentration broken by syntax errors in the text . As other reviewers have also mentioned , the chapters seem overly - long and dry and the text is entirely black and white with no colors or pictures . What also stands out are certain organizational issues , which include certain topics popping up every chapter rather than just having one chapter address the subject . Another issue is the authors citing academic research without providing enough context such as not even providing the scholar 's first name . I also take issue with their over - reliance on the ethical models of Rest and Kohlberg while only giving token acknowledgement to criticisms of these models .

Out of fear , enemies are born . halo returns full of doubts , and confesses all to his lord , who purifies Haplo through pain . Cold once more , Haplo is sent on to Chelestra , the last world where he finds a vast ocean , where sea moons float in bubbles of air . The story quickly switches to the mensch dwarves , elves , and humans , who have managed to form a lasting peace . They are about to migrate to a new sea moon , until a new enemy appears , demanding a sacrifice to stay their hand . The story continues the transition that began in Fire Sea , humanizing Haplo through a series of quick subplots as he struggles to reconcile who he is with who he thinks he should be . This brings the characters much closer , but also serves as a stalling tactic , postponing the main conflict until other plots have a chance to catch up . The story manages to create some touching moments , but ultimately proves anticlimactic , leaving characters and audiences waiting for the next installment . Strong CharactersStrong SettingWeak main plot , strong subplots Some interesting ideas - Anticlimactic Ending35

Author not credible . Jeffrey Feinman obviously did a lot of work compiling information and quotes about Christie and her work - I appreciated that effort very much . What I found troubling , however , is that he seems to have no qualifications to be passing judgement on the works of Agatha Christie in particular and the entire mystery genre in general . He does work to quote people to back up his statements - some of the time . I think to write a credible book that includes sweeping opinions on the work including specific books of the most successful author of fiction of all time - the writer should establish some sort of credibility to do so . This particular writer has written a book on how to win at bingo and then this one on Christie - not credible .

Pleasant but nothing special . I chose The Girl Next Door because I had read and enjoyed The Reading Group by the same author . Unfortunately , I did not The Girl Next Door as much . This novel is comprised of intertwining stories of residents of a New York City apartment building . It was a pleasant read . But there was no " hook " here at all . Other than one emotional chapter , each story is mundane and predicable . The characters are one dimensional , almost stereotypes . There are so many characters , that we never feel invested in any of them . The writing is okay - but certainly not witty , insightful , full of attitude , poetic , or anything else that would make this novel stand out . It 's not bad , really . There 's just nothing about it that would make me recommend it to a friend .

Cool plot but desperate need for an editor . I quite liked the plot - the psychopathology here is well - described and pretty much believable . Even the characters are pretty decent . But the novel needs an editor . When I was in high school , my English teachers made much of correct use of tense and point of view POV . I never gave it much thought and generally regarded their instruction as fustian . This book is rendered nearly unreadable because the author does not adhere to common rules of grammar regarding the use of proper tense - it 's all over the place . Same for POV - the author never quite settles on where he 's standing as he relates the tale . And here 's why publishers hire editors - to make books readable . Overall , you can muddle through , but if you 're like me , it 's a tough slog . Too bad . It 's a cool premise .

Stating the obvious . The author proposes to reflect on the subject of biographies . There are some interesting thoughts in this novel , particularly when the author dwells on what a good biography should be like . He discusses the question of the biographer 's empathy with the subject or what subjects should be worthy of a biography , the question of its length and whether its role is to make the reader understand other people . Perhaps when reading a biography there is a desire to find out how one differs from personalities like W. H. Auden , Napoleon or Verdi . But is it worthwhile for the biographer to be tormented by the question of how many grains of salt his subject put on his eggs , as Ximenes Doudan was about Julius Caesar ? Is the Picasso of the blue period really the same man as the one who painted Guernica at the end of his life ? How can the biographer understand the subject 's experiences of which he himself has no experience ? Aside from such reflex ions - even though treated quite superficially - the book contains lengthy observations of the banal habits of a young lady called Isabel Rogers who lives in London and whose biography will interest very few readers indeed .

McDonald book 's , would just be another adventure for the same character . Wrong . While the protagonist share 's the same name in both book 's , the Alec Blume in the and book is a totally different character . The time span between the 2 book 's , is roughly 18 month 's and it 's almost as if the author did n't like the protagonist , he created in book 1 , so he decided to create a whole new personality for Alec , in book 2 . Do n't get me wrong , the and is just as good as the st but be ready to accept a totally redone detective . It 's worth reading , so I hope you enjoy . Have to give this one a 4 star for predictability and lack of continuity from book 1

What a fantastic , engrossing read . I could not go to sleep until I finished Welcome to the Hamilton . Nor could I resist the characters in the book . I felt involved in their lives from the start . Each personality seems well defined and yet as the story progresses you realize how much more depth there is to each person . Clara is the main character and youngest sister . She feels the weight of responsibility on her to care for her older sister and father after her mother 's death . When Clara finds out they are behind in their rent and that there is an eviction notice she becomes determined to find employment and save them from life on the streets . This is a wonderful story you will not want to miss out on . Along the way you will see what Clara finds out about herself and that others are not always as they seem to first appear .

Nora was the older housekeeper of Kyle in the first book and this book picks up from the end of that book as her longtime beau Roman decided on finally to make an honest woman out of her , and enlisted all the kid 's help to mount the perfect wedding . She was hesitant as she did not believe she can love Roman because she gave her heart once to Aiden , her first love . But can she believe in herself again ? If you want to experience heartaches loss , then redemption this is not the book for you .
