Mediocre book , dreadful customer service , abysmal publisher , Basic teacher resources withheld . It 's a decently written text on an increasingly rare subject . That 's the only reason it got a second star . Still , if you 're a teacher , administrator , or have any power in textbook adoption , run far and fast away from this book . Cengage no longer includes images in their powerpoint . Imagine teaching geography with no access to the maps , graphs , and graphics the textbook houses . It 's primitive ! They also no longer provides test banks compatible with LMS unless you want to waste literal hours with their cumbersome and time - wasting " cognero " farce . Cengage wants scholars locked into e - books and mindtap tools which I have not found to be of very good quality . If you want the most basic , normal teacher resources , look farther . This used to be a good text . It still would be if it was with a better publisher . Under Cengage management , teacher resources are far too scant for the extortionate price . Since I no longer get basic teacher resources anyway , I 'm moving toward an open textbook option for my students . It 's no more work for me , and my students will save a fortune .

Sweet Story ! I Wish There Was an Epilogue ! The Valets Secret was a delightfully sweet Regency novel . The romance that blossomed between Kenneth and Rebecca did so under false pretenses . It was frustrating to know that Kenneth had lied to Rebecca during two of their meetings , yet it set up the situation that they found themselves in and provided some good angst for this story . I wondered how they could ever overcome their differences in station and everything that Kenneth was expected to inherit . The chemistry between these two was spot on . They connected with each other deeply and were drawn to each other despite their differing places in society . I appreciated that Kenneth was a gentleman and that at no time did he ever consider the notion of carrying on some type of sordid affair with Rebecca . The way the author wrapped things up into a happily ever after for these two was nicely done , although I desperately needed an epilogue after the last chapter . I needed to see Kenneth and Rebecca living their lives happily together perhaps a year or two in the future . I received a complimentary copy of this book . All opinions are my own .

There are other better grammars than this one . The best Hebrew grammar book for new learners is Andrew Bartelt 's Fundamental Biblical Hebrew . Lambdin 's book is definitely not it . In fact , I rate Weingreen 's Classical Hebrew Grammar and Page Kelley 's Classical Hebrew way over Lambdin 's . Lambdin 's text is confusing and frustrating . I say that as someone who started off by teaching myself Hebrew - Weingreen was excellent , and Kelley supplemented where Weingreen fell short . I do have the Lambdin text , but gave it up in frustration . The one text that organizes and clarifies in a way that neither Lambdin , Weingreen , nor Kelley does , is Bartelt 's . That 's the text for the Hebrew neophyte , either with a teacher or a self - starter .

Solid Victorian Stuff . Gerard Freeman , the hero of the book at a very early age in Australia , growing up with his mother , realizes something is wrong with her and with him . He falls in love with a pen pal , who is going to undergo surgery and can become paralyzed . Such is the beginning . True to Victorian times , a large part of the book is spent in Gerard reading old manuscripts , nice short ghostly tales somehow never reaching the finesse that Ms. Byatt achieved in Possession . Perhaps Mr. Harwood did borrow , albeit unconsciously from that book , perhaps not . It is so well written that time and pages fly quickly . Ultimately , everything is neatly tied in with a rather unbelievable climax . Still , a very tidy book . Good ghost stories are hard to come by and the last one was also from Australia , Richard Adams'Watership Down The Girl On The Swing . That was a real spine tingler . This one could have been a stunning novella , in the manner of The Turn of the Screw . Expanding it to a novel length has robbed it of much needed intensity . The author has promise and I look forward to his new book .

Disappointing . This is about a boy who , after a near - fatal childhood accident , became an introspective poet . But I did not find it to be something that would pull me into the narrative or learn very much about the character . The book is small , the typeface as well . No photos other than that on the front . The narratives were detached , seemed to ramble on . This book seemed to be a series of vignettes which sometimes appeared to be illusions or dreams . I could not really relate to the child , nor could I relate to the writer who was more of a disembodied voice than a narrator , or a fly - on - the - wall . If at least there had been a photo of the child with his favorite dog as mentioned on one of the opening pages , perhaps it would have added some " body " to this book , but nothing here was really compelling . Nothing really brought us closer to the boy as a child and then a man . Cloudy writing at best .

Decent scary book for kids . I read this book with my eight year old son . The book is pretty fast paced and follows a boy and his sister and father into a haunted house they 've recently moved into . The boy seems the most susceptible to the haunted aspects of the house , but they are noises , electronics that turn on with no electricity and then a ghost coming out of a mirror . It is pretty spooky . My son had several questions as we read this book , so it does keep your guessing . He was n't too scared , but I could see some kids being a bit disturbed by some of the scenes with a skeletal hand grabbing an ankle and the mirror part . Author Preller does a good job writing a story that is n't too long at 97 pages , and the illustrations by Bruno are pretty good . I liked the black and white drawings that captured the spookiness of the environment . My son was a little sad at the ending , but fortunately no one gets truly hurt . He is definitely interested in reading more in the series .

I enjoyed the wine making details . The Vineyard at Painted Moon was the April selection for the Page - turners Book Club at the Kewaunee Public Library . Mackenzie has the job that she loves working at her husbands family vineyard . She blends delicious wines that attract a lot of customers . Her world comes crashing down when her husband wants a divorce . What should she do ? Stay and keep working for the vineyard or strike out on her own ? I usually love Mallerys novels , but while I read through this one quickly , I did n't love it . I enjoyed Mackenzies journey and her gumption to strike out on her own . I liked the story of the various family members . I overall though just felt sad for the destruction of the marriage . The novel started out happy with Mackenzies mother - in - law Barbaras engagement , and then Barbara turned into a one - dimensional villain . It was too drastic of a change to me . Mackenzies new romance was not very well developed and felt tacked on at the end . I did enjoy all of the details of wine making and thought that was fascinating . Overall , The Vineyard at Painted Moon was a so - so novel for me . Book Source Kewaunee Public Library . Thank - you !

It is the story of Jane Gagliardo 's legal battle with her disability discrimination case against a powerful drug company whose a. I was originally drawn to " Call to Witness " because it involved the pharmaceutical industry . It is that and much more . It is the story of Jane Gagliardo 's legal battle with her disability discrimination case against a powerful drug company whose arrogance oozes off the pages like a bad septic system . I was fortunate enough to meet both Jane and Rev. Sherry . I left our stimulating conversations feeling uplifted and knowing that doing the right thing can take incredible courage and stamina and that the truth is indeed a mighty sword . Their honesty and energy is what you will discover throughout the book 's pages . " Call to Witness " is a story that needs to be told . I admire Jane for sharing her experience so honestly and appreciate the author 's attention to facts and time - lines . As a resident of the Poconos , whenever I drive through Swiftwater I wonder about other " secrets " that have yet to be revealed .

Good writing , but disappointingly slow not much happening . A disappointingly trudging novel of England in the days of the blitz . The story of one small boy , Bobby , who is evacuated from war - torn London to a small Devonshire village and how he adapts and fits in with a gang of five boys whose fathers have all gone off to the war . Small effectively written portraits of the old woman who takes Bobby in , an old man who builds ships in bottles , and the boys themselves . Unfortunately , the story moves so slowly , without much happening , that I just lost interest . Gave up after reading more than a hundred pages . There are just too many other books out there waiting , and better ones . Sorry , Mr. Jackson , but you need to pick up the pace . Not recommended . two and a half stars - Tim Bazzett , author of the memoir , BOOKLOVER

A psychological thriller I finished in one sitting . I really liked the Silent Patient , so I was really excited for this one . I feel a little bit let down though , though I love psychological thrillers . From the first chapter of this book , I knew Edward Fosca could n't be the murderer because that would be way too obvious and anticlimactic . The reveal of the killer was completely random - I felt like there were no clues or hints or anything leading up to the revelation that Zoe was orchestrating this entire thing . I was suspecting Elsie for a bit and then Fred , and I could tell it was Zoe a few pages before it was revealed . Although I was surprised about Sebastian 's involvement - I feel like that was a good revelation . That being said , I did read the entirety of this book in just one sitting , and it was definitely a page turner for me . I also loved the connections with the Silent Patient and seeing Theo mentioned again was awesome . I did expect more from Alex Michaelides , but I would recommend this book to others .

Great book all the way through . This book was good from beginning to end . It only got better as it went along . I listened to the audio and the voices were perfect for the characters . I would n't want to get out of my car because I would want to hear what was going to happen next . This is the best Kristin Hannah book so far . I grew up on a reservation so I could relate to the challenges Dallas faced being of mixed race and facing racism because of that . Hannah 's use of language is so clever and unique that it 's what I like best about her writing . She can make you think too about things you would n't normally think about . This book made me imagine how it would feel being stuck in prison and then being in prison wrongly accused . She kept you wondering about Dallas'innocence until the end . The story line played out until the end and she did n't abruptly end the story with loose ends .

We travel to France every other year , so when I saw this book on the Amazon Vine list I went for it , thinking it could provide some insight to areas of the country we have n't been to yet . I was wrong - the book contains incorrect historical information , outdated restaurant and hotel info , and generally does n't contain anything that you could n't find easily online . While it is par for the course that any annually updated travel book will contain out - of - date information , this book was comically unhelpful . It seems that Fodors just phoned in their reviews of France 's various regions and attractions - don't waste your time and definitely do n't lug this book overseas !

Chilly . Choose a warm place to read the eighteenth NUMA files novel by the Clive Cussler franchise , a book titled , Fast Ice . So much of the action takes place in frigid conditions that you might feel the chills as the action propels readers from one cold place to an even colder one . The familiar NUMA cast is back , led by swashbuckling Kurt Austin and his sidekick Joe Zavala . All their skills and the expertise of other recurring characters are drawn into a race to defeat a finely drawn villain , Ryland Lloyd , who is in the final stages of implementing actions that will lead Earth into another ice age . While the formula of this series demands that the good guys win , its a close - run thing that will satisfy those readers who love fast - paced action novels . Rating Four - star I like it

Repetitive and TRITE . I 'd never read anything by this author , but a trusted reader - friend of mine gave me a copy and hailed it as nothing short of amazing . Well , it 's the kind of novel that one retreats to in hopes that something will actually happen this time I pick it up , only to find a scattered nugget or tiniest bit of insight - just enough to bait the reader for the next attempt at the novel . Even with the assistance of the Irish Dublin vernacular , French 's characters remain mostly flat and almost entirely featureless - which is a shame since the reader really WANTS to imagine these people and care about their lives . The story is told - rather than developed - and is anchored by shameless repetition . and not the good kind , either . Perhaps the author 's use of this device meant to reflect oral traditions in the tightly - compacted neighborhoods of Dublin , but the repetition never makes the story more compelling nor does it flesh - out the characters it merely annoys the reader . faithful Place _ became one of those novels that I forced myself to finish - but not out of anticipation .

Outdated - nearly worthless . I am surprised that Amazon still sells this book without posting a disclaimer that it is so outdated as to be nearly worthless . Again and again readers are advised to go to menus that do not exist , or to click on links " at the top of any page " that no longer appear anywhere , on even one page . To make matters worse , the index omits many essential terms , so when the text refers you to a nonexistent feature , there is no way to tell whether it is simply a misprint , or if the same feature is discussed elsewhere in the book . Some of the basic information is still usable , but for optimizing your use of Facebook , you would be far better off saving your money and putting your questions to random middle schooners on the nearest street corner .

Falls flat and has no meat as a story about Detroit . Detroitan American autopsy is a fitting title were it for a book about just that . Instead , this book represents a set of tabloid - style , heart - on - my - sleeve polaroid snapshots of Charlie 's adventures in a city in great decline . There 's very little meat to the story of Detroit and its people . Sure , there are some heartfelt moments those describing the fire department 's plight come to mind , but I quickly got tired of the " everybody loves Charlie " feel of the book except of course the bad guys . As the pages turn the author comes over as a man who is writing on quickly formed emotions , rather than as a man who is a reporter telling the story of a city . As an example , consider the moment where a German reporter looks at him the wrong way from a distance Charlie 's response on paper is to groan about the fact that the only thing worse than American reporters are foreign reporters . My reactions to off - topic comments like that were combinations of " how many pages are left " and " Is this guy really a reporter " . Anyone who wants to have an informed perspective about the history of the city of Detroit is encouraged to look elsewhere ,

Great history of the Baptists in America . This is a really good book and it is a book that was needed . While the author does cherry pick the history he chooses to write about , he chooses well all historians do this to one degree or another . This book presents another view from the popular view regarding American history . Popular history revolves around secular history candor perhaps around the Covenant theologists . This is a must read for any independent , fundamental Baptist . Southern Baptists would likely enjoy it as well . Perhaps even the spinoff brethren - the Church of Christers would get something out of it . Would n't it be great if people would spend more time studying true history and carefully filtering every thought and deed through the Bible . Perhaps some folk would see the errors of their wayward theology and would repent and make the necessary changes within their denominations or leave their assembly for a pure local church . This book tells of the suffering and death that was brought to so many of our forefathers so that we might have a pure theology .

Disappointing and repetitive novel . I did not finish this book . It was very repetitive and uninteresting . While I was looking forward to reading about Catherine of Aragon - books about Henry VIII typically focus on Anne Boleyn and ignore Catherine 's motivations - the execution was poor . First , there were significant implausibilities in the portrayal of King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella of Spain . Gregory portrays them as rather open minded and solicitous of Islamic practices . Catherine is portrayed as very appreciative of the Muslim legacy of Spain . This is absolutely ridiculous , considering the fact that Ferdinand and Isabella were brutal religious fanatics who sparked the infamous Spanish inquisition . Second , Gregory portrays the relationship between Catherine and Henry VIII 's older brother , Prince Arthur as a love affair . I suppose it is possible , but very unlikely in that time period . Gregory 's purpose , of course , is the key premise of this book - that Catherine of Aragon lied when she said that her marriage to Arthur was not consummated , which means that her marriage to Henry was unlawful under church law . However , the efforts to make this point are rather forced - the romance between Arthur and Catherine reads like a nauseating dime store romance

Worthless . Looking at the other reviews , I wonder if we read the same book . I bought this book to help my brother advance his career in IT . I was looking for specific information about who hires these people and what certifications are today , considered the most valuable . The goal is a simple one . Target the best states and localities for these types of jobs while obtaining certs that are in demand , then target specific companies in those regions for possible opportunities for career advancement . And this book very much bills itself as a tool toward that end . It falls FAR short of that . In fact , I tried to return it because I could not find a single shred of useful information in it . At best , it 's a " getting a job for dummies " book for those fresh out of college . But even at that , it falls far short of books that might have an actual title similar to that . Amazon basically refunded my money but said , keep the book . which I promptly tossed in the trash .

Go in looking for fun , not looking for substance , and it 's a pleasant diversion from the diapers .

Same old tiresome harangue . Edit this OUT of your reading list ! The War of Northern Aggression was never over slavery . Had the issue actually been slavery , slave labor would not have continually been used to construct federal buildings in Washington , DC , well into the War ! Slavery would have been immediately abolished in every state it was not . Lincoln would to have offered to " let " the Southerners keep their slaves in exchange for not seceding which he did ! This book seems to have been written to be sensationalist , rather than to reflect historical significance . This kind of gratuitous writing is revolting . For a much better read , try Heroines of the South , which is an actual compilation of letters and diary entries by Southern ladies during the War .

Maybe I was so enthralled with her book because I wish I could have been more like her . Whether you believe in the death penalty or not , you need to read this book . I found myself enthralled with each story . Each execution was different , yet the same . A crime was committed , a guilty , verdict , and death . As the book progresses , so do the feeling that Michelle has about her experiences in her profession . Michelle Lyons to me seems to be a strong woman who is very adventurous , free spirited , and has a zeal for life . I myself do not know many women that could have done everything she has done so far in her life . Maybe I was so enthralled with her book because I wish I could have been more like her .

Still read it . Anything by Spider Robinson is worth reading . The three stars are in reference to all the other stuff he has written , not compared to other books in general . Having said that , I was a bit disappointed with this work . It seems more like the first shot in a proposed series than a work finished in Robinson 's usual style . The premise is great , and it has Spider 's usual touch in pointing out how bad telepathy would be for anyone accursed with it . The villain is classic Spider , too . Someone so evil , just so sociopathic , that it makes you want to retch takes a master touch to accomplish . But I never felt like the book was really going anywhere . I felt like he got caught by a deadline halfway through his usual writing and had to finish before he was ready . The characters are beautifully crafted as usual , and so real you want to meet them , but the plot seemed to sputter . Anything by Spider Robinson is worth reading . His worst stuff is better than many authors'best . But I still felt like this was n't his best effort .

Horrible Microbiology Text . I have a lot of experience with health - based science courses . This book has been the worse textbook that I have read to date . The authors are long - winded and do n't explain concepts in a clear manner . Plus , the book is designed in a way that combines the characteristics of Viruses , Bacteria , and Fungi in every chapter . As a reader , I found that I had to " reset " by brain to identify which organism the authors had switched to . It was very disruptive and not conducive to learning . They would have been better off talking about viruses in one chapter , bacteria in another , et . , et . Note The online component was not arranged well either . It takes an average of 7 , very confusing mouse clicks , in order to navigate anywhere within the program . Plus , there were n't any actual Learning Tools integrated into the program no games , et . It was a complete waste of money , and I would n't have purchased it unless required by the course .

Best Friends Forever . I thought You Knew Me When was a wonderful heartfelt story about two best friends . Laney and Katherine met as young girls who quickly became best friends who were more like sisters . They did everything together and became apart of each others families until they grew up and grew in separate directions . The book alternated between the past and the present and really gave me a sense of just how this friendship worked . Dry diplomatic history . I eagerly bought this book because it 's probably the only one dealing with the Sino - vietnamese war of 1979 as its main theme . Although it contains a very thorough overview of the political and diplomatic relations of the two countries from 1947 to 1979 , analyzing many issues ranging from the Chinese community in Vietnam to the US - Chinese and Soviet - Vietnamese relations , the actual military operations of the war are covered in only 16 pages of a single chapter number 5 . The writing is also completely dry , reminding official diplomatic report . For someone who 's looking for a better military account I would recommend " PLA Warfighting " which is much more detailed on the subject , and also " Brother Enemy " by Nayan Chanda which has an easily read narrative , albeit it focuses on the Vietnam invasion of Cambodia December 1978 - January 1979 .

A fun read to pass the time . " Breath of Yesterday " is Emily Bold 's second book in her The Curse Series , which apparently first came out in German . Taht probably accounts for some odd transitions here and there from translation but overall , I found the story of Samantha Watts and her time traveling Scotsman , Payton MacLean , to be an enjoyable read while riding the bus . There were a few times when I wish I had read the first book but I think overall I was able to get right into the narrative where Sam and Payton are totally in love and all that but something is wrong with him is n't that usually the case ? true love never runs smooth . While he is getting sicker , Sam must find a way to help him . It is over the top love and sometimes it gets to the point that I had to roll my eyes a bit but it is all in good fun . Again , it is an enjoyable read . Maybe not a great one but a fun one that helps while away the time .

Neither Math Nor Physics . It is tough even for the most learned to become proficient in both mathematics and physics . Adding the ability to organize thoughts well , and illustrate them clearly by example is a talent reserved for a very few . Unfortunately , K. C. Cole is not that person . Her book is a random walk through the mysteries of both technologies , much too often poorly stated , if not entirely wrong . From the first page to the last , she seems to be as befuddled as the layperson . Richard Feynman in his later years took issue with the misconceptions that are being put into the textbooks for school children . Too bad that this award winning book is no better at getting the facts straight .

No way two characters could really be this stupid . By the time I got to the middle of this book I wanted to screech with agitation , frustration and impatience . NO ONE could be as stupid and misbegotten as these two people . The silly assumptions and mis - communications ruined what could have been a really good story line . I know Ms. Moning has to be a better writer than this . I assume she is trying to stay true to the romance formula but really this took it too far . How can people who read these books be satisfied with the same plot over and over again . I ran out of other fantasy paranormal books so I turned to this one . Unfortunately , it fell too close to my read of Echo in the Bone by Diana Gabaldon and that 's like comparing Stephen Hawking to a first grade primer . I 'm going to try and remember that frustration the next time I 'm tempted to read a romance again . I gave it two stars because it had a good idea for the story . I 'm just sorry she could n't flesh it out better .

Marked . This free book was a lovely surprise . I enjoyed it from the very first chapter . All the characters were interesting and they are all obviously going to have their own stories . Mildly interesting , mostly off - topic . As someone who has done a considerable amount of taxidermy and preparation curation of museum specimens , I looked forward to this book as a treatment of the subject from a psychological perspective . While some historical background is useful , the return to Ackley again and again was annoying , since the author was obviously copying material published elsewhere . The fact that he did n't even try to make a mount seems hypocritical and his demeaning rationale does n't ring true . I most enjoyed the discussions of novelty taxidermy and the preservation of pets . These areas would seem the best material to use in considering the psychology of people who desire such bizarre creations . I found it also bizarre that the author would try to write an entire book with much off - topic filler and repetition about a subject he claims to be obsessed with , yet does n't deviate from his position as a somewhat disgusted observer .

So Far Away - not bad . ASIN0316097691 So Far Away A Novelis about the cyber - bullying of a young girl in Newburyport , Massachusetts . Natalie is a young 13 year old whose parents are divorcing and neither parent has time for her . She befriends an archivist , Katherine , in the local library to help her with a school project . Natalie and Katherine 's lives become intertwined because of a diary that Natalie has found in her basement . Natalie turns to Katherine when she becomes the victim of mean girls at school and is c yb er bullied . Katherine finds solace in helping Natalie since she long ago lost her own daughter who ran away from home and never returned . This book deals with the issues of cyber - bullying and it 's affect on today 's teens . The story of the diary found in the basement is intertwined with the story of Natalie and Katherine . The ending left things rather unfinished for me . An ok read but not that real for me .

Some readers might think it was too simple , but Burdock the cat is a character that some kids will sympathize with and understand . I really liked him , but I liked them all . As I mentioned earlier they are individuals , and some readers will possibly empathize with different animals . The drawings illustrate the story and characters well . Great advice but Beware small print . Note that the one star is for the print edition only . And it is not for content , but for a problem with printing . Summary Honey Bunny endures abuse from her brother , and since she 's grown to believe that his abuse is love , she 's sad when he temporarily stops , and is relieved when his abuse starts again . This is n't a cute sibling rivalry book and he 's not a just a harmless prankster . Full of errors and inconsistencies . I had high hopes for this book , and I love the spirit behind it . It is cheerful , exuberant and the Latin spin on old classics is refreshing and new . BUT the book is full of errors . There is nothing more annoying than finding inconsistencies , errors and oversights in recipe after recipe . In one recipe , coconut and quinol is added to the dough , but then the instructions tell you to sprinkle those same ingredients on top instead . One recipe tells you to add toasted seeds to the dough , but the photograph shows a thick layer of seeds coating the bread - the recipe makes no mention of this . One recipe instruct you to bake the bread in a loaf pan , but the photograph shows a rustic , oval artisan loaf . It would n't be impossible to improvise , or to figure out what was really meant , but that defeats the purpose of learning from the authors expertise . Repeatedly , the photographs do not reflect the actual recipes . Its confusing and unhelpful . I really wanted to love this book , but the sloppy production and lazy editing make it very difficult to use .

Probly A More Advanced " Take " Than I Was Looking For . First of all , I was anticipating this book would be more of an " picture " book , full of reproductions of women'surrealist artworks . " This " is not what the book turned out to be . Rather , it is more of a narrative discussion of the evolution of the woman 's movement , with a heavy emphasis on its relationship to the male surrealists . Artwork is included , but not to the extent I would have liked , and many of the pictures are not full - page retros . More importantly , though , is that the narrative content , despite having vague chapter headings , does n't really have a " logical " flow , nor does it always adhere to the purported topic of discussion . Also , unless you are already intimately familiar with the artists'styles and lives , it is often hard to appreciate the context of a particular reference as the author " dips in and out of " particular topics , and their illuminating examples . In fairness , I have to admit , I have only skimmed the book , and seriously doubt I will ever really read it . There do appear to be some good summaries of the development and specialties of individual artists that are interspersed throughout , tho , that I do hope to go back and read .

A great first entry . This review is based on an Advanced Reader 's Edition provided as part of the Amazon Vine program . This is Cherie Priest 's first foray into the world of Modern Dark Fantasy . On the surface , it 's pretty typical . Female vampire protagonist . Did I mention she 's a thief private investigator , and hot ? It has a few twists . The first is that the client is a vampire , a blind vampire . The other odd thing is that its written from the first person . To be honest , I found this to be pretty refreshing . You get to really experience the story from Raylene 's point of view . There are a couple of other real twists to the story , which I really did n't predict . I really enjoyed this book , and will be looking for future Raylene Pendle novels .

Not just for dogs . We are bunny owners , and I bought this book because our local shelter told us that clicker training can be a very effective tool for all pets . " Reaching the Animal Mind " is much more in - depth than I had thought it would be , and I found it to be a slightly challenging read . I personally wanted more of " this is how you train your animal " and less animal psychology , although the information is very worthwhile and extremely helpful and effective . The back of the book has an extensive glossary and appendix - the research is quite impressive . The use of positive reinforcement over negative punishment is such a breath of fresh air . This book would be helpful for any pet owner .

Sounded like the author was way too into young teens himself and left me gagging . No real new information about her murder and too much Freedom with the fictionalized personalities . Was disturbing to say the least .

Vintage Beauty ! This book is a must have for any baby boomer , or for that matter anyone who wants to relive the fabulous golden era of slot racing . Philippe de Lespinay is the premiere authority on vintage slot cars and proves it with this beautiful collection of well photographed and rare items . What is even more interesting is the collection of cars pictured here with the original art work packaging ! This is usually the first thing to be thrown away and as such , rarer than most of the cars . I went nuts just looking at the beautiful photos of Cox , Russkit , Classic , BZ , AMT , Revell , Model Products Corp. and many other lesser known companies like Internatonal and Industro - Motive . There is even a section on brands and types of motors . While the book is 96 pages of great slot car memories , it still was n't enough for me . I ca n't wait until his next book comes out !

Thank goodness for the abridged ! I loved the beginning of this book . Dumas sets the whole thing up perfectly . It was entertaining , en trawling and a great story . I loved the end of the book , how Dumas but the whole plot together and what happened to the main characters , Edmond , Mercedes , Versalies , Ferdenand , Danglers et . it was very fitting . The middle however was very hard to get through . I do n't know if it 's just the abridgement or what but I kept getting lost trying to figure out who everyone was . I find it annoying that a lot of the main characters have two or three different names titles et . this makes it very confusing trying to figure out if it 's a new character or a new title . So I had that issue of trying to keep everyone straight and the other issue I had is boredom . The middle of the books is rather boring , excruciatingly at points . Very slow methodical plot buildup that is mostly uninteresting . I wonder if the book should have been abridged a little more . Anyway , I am greatful for the abridged version . I never would have made it all the way through the full 1 , 200 page version .

Maybe on the whole more valuable to a running historian than to the up and coming distant coach .

Very Readable Formula Read . I opted to read the Hunting Party after reading The Guest List , which I really enjoyed . The Guest List was my first Lucy Foley novel and I was intrigued . Sadly , The Hunting Party was a repeat of the The Guest List though perhaps it 's better to say the The Guest List was a repeat of the Hunting Party since it 's the and book . An assorted group of old friends gather for New Years Eve in a remote Scottish estate . They are marooned by a massive snowstorm and one is murdered . Just as in The Guest List , the victim is the " Golden Person " who appears perfect but is actually a very unpleasant human being . The Hunting Party has to many characters - it was quite apparent that both the victim and the murderer were coming from the inner circle of 6 of so characters . Sophophobia is the fear of learning ! I love trivia , and that is what Learn Something Everyday basically is . Something you probably did n't know ! Very colorful and simply illustrated , you can turn the page and learn something new everyday . Based on their colorful cartooned website , learns om eth inge very day . co. up , the " We Are Young " design studio creators Peter Jarvis and Gethin Vaughn together form Young - and their book is here to help you stay just that in heart , spirit , and especially mind . There is a lot of interesting information packed into this small book . It would be perfect for gift giving or for yourself . It 's not only entertaining , it is also educating ! Did you know that strawberries contain more vitamin C then oranges ? Or did you know oysters can change gender ? Did you know Charlie Chaplin once came in third in a lookalike contest ? You 'll find all of these and so much more in this vibrant and colorful book . Sophophobia is the fear of learning ! You wo n't have that if you get this book ! I 've put mine on my desk at the office .

An OK read , but only OK . David Weber is normally one of the best military of writers going . Unfortunately , this is n't one of his better books . This novel was inspired by David Drake 's excellent RANKS OF BRONZE . R. O. B. tells of a group of Roman legionnaires captured in a war against Persia , and sold as slaves to aliens who want to use them as mercenaries . I recommend it . E. A. concerns a group of English soldiers the aliens acquire centuries later . Weber appears to feel constrained by the necessity of conforming to Drake 's background . And the book does n't really end - it just stops , with more to come in the next book . I 'll read anything by Weber , but this is one of his lesser works .

Glad to find another person as obsessed with Bach as I am ! Dan Moller 's love of Bach 's music shines through on almost every page of this stimulating story of the author 's struggle to master some of the beauties and difficulties of this timeless music . That love mirrors my own , a love that has lasted for almost 80 years . I am now 89 years old ! . If you are new to Bach 's music this book may start you on a path to the joy that this glorious music can bring .

LOVED IT ! I read this book years ago and was disappointed to see that it is out of print . I 've been reading Snowden 's magazine articles for years and love her writing style . I 've always fantasized about being a cocktail waitress in Vegas , but would n't have the guts , or the feet , to actually do it . It 's fun to read about how Snowden held up and dealt with the challenges of her different jobs . I loved this book and would recommend it to anyone . Snowden is a very talented writer , and if you 're reading this Lynn , WRITE SOMETHING ELSE ALREADY ! I 'll be waiting .

Small . When I received this product , I thought to myself , this is very small , it contains 8 tattoos of sharks for , what , 1 . 50 . Ok , it was cheap , so , no worries . I think that this package is really neat , marketed for shark - lovers specifically . It might be a neat product as a completing project for a section on sharks , home schooners , shark loving children . It 's easy to wash off . They claim that it 's safe but I ca n't comment either way on that . I give everything a grade , and this product I give a solid " B " . If it were made with finely designed sharks or larger sharks or more sharks or it contained a couple of pages of information about various types of sharks , then I would have given it a solid " A " .

not Garwood 's best effort , but still worth the read . I 've been a fan of Garwood 's work for years , and rate several of her novels as among the best ever written in the genre . I love The Secret and was eager to read this sequel and to learn more about Ramsey and Brodick 's quest for true love . Unfortunately , for me at least , this book fell pretty flat . The plot was needlessly complicated I feel like a lot of explanatory details were left on the cutting room floor and I think would have worked best as two separate stories . The entire Ramsey - Bridgid plot had a lot of potential , but to me was never satisfactorily fleshed out . A separate book would have allowed for some explanation of Gideon 's motives , of Ramsey 's rise to power , and of Bridgid 's early life I think they and we deserved that story . Ransom deserves 3 . 5 stars oh Amazon , give us half stars and even a lukewarm Garwood is better than many of the other romance novels out there . Her trademark humor and steamy scenes make this novel well - worth the read , but I recommend following it up with some of her earlier , 5 star works The Bride is my personal favorite .

dang Noir rocks ! This book has an amazing voice . Thirteen - year - old Dani is funny and charming and always makes you feel like you 're right there with her . I devoured this book in one day and look forward to rereading it whenever I need a pick - me - up .

Another great story in the Taken series ! I started reading these when I came across Taken 1 - 6 as a free purchase . I zipped right through them and bought the next set . Zipped through them and just bought all the rest of the series . I liked the books so much , I bought the rest of Donald Wells'books . After reading Taken 50 , I thought the Taken series was over . The man with no name was dead . How could the series continue when he was such a big part of the series ? No fear , The man , now known as Mr. White , which is truly not a name , is alive . Donald Wells , write faster please !

Pretty crappy for a potty book . Call me a book snob , but this board book really missed the mark . The story is dumb . It 's not engaging and it does n't make good use of the characters from Sesame Street . Swing and a miss on that part . Then , there 's the illustrations . My main peeve . Over 30 flaps to lift ! -the cover promises . OK . So when you lift the flap , you 're supposed to see a picture underneath that furthers the story . that gives a little surprise . that at the very least , catches a young child 's eye . This is the other big failure with this book . The flaps are a flop ! Take for example the flap over a lamp in Elmo 's room - you lift the flap and see the same lamp , same position , with a tiiiiiny bit of yellow indicating that it 's now on . Wow . Another flap shows Elmo 's hand on the toilet handle . Lift the flap and his hand has moved like 20 degrees , indicating he 's now flushing the toilet . My toddler does n't get it . I barely get it , and I 'm an educated grown woman . Look elsewhere if your kid likes lift - a - flap books .

So I was eager to take in this new story , also in audiobook form . I was very disappointed . Also , he reads the part of Serena most of the time with a voice that seems on the line between teasing and sarcastic , but mostly comes out irritating . Not related to the comics at all and stories are kind of boring . I am sure for people who grew up in this time period the 1940s , these stories must be really cool . However , for contemporary readers , these stories are a bore . Most of the villains and crimes are gang related or some sort of robbery or con job . I do n't have a problem with that in of itself , however , it is the lack of connection between the dailies and comic books that I see is the major issue . If you bought this thinking that these stories are in canon or or even related to the comic books , you will be highly disappointed . Other than the characters , Batman , Robin , Alfred , and Commissioner Gordon , these stories have not relationship to the comics . Villains wise , only the Joke made an appearance and it was for only one story . Although the dust jacket shows Two - Face , Catwoman and the Penguin , none of them appeared in any of the stories . Read it for historical reasons . Other than that it was very disappointing .

Do n't bother . This novel would have deserved the Pulitzer prize except for the following factors It 's overlong at 771 pages and grossly overwritten , its main character goes from sympathetic to repugnant and never quite becomes sympathetic again despite the author 's best efforts , the main character is too recklessly self - centered and just plain stupid to easily resolve his dilemma regarding the painting early on and avoid all the later complications otherwise this would have been a very short novel , the elitist overtones are annoying and off putting , and there are long sections of the novel think Las Vegas and Amsterdam that nearly bring what little pace there is to the story to a grinding halt . I managed to finish the book only because I 'm a sucker for coming of age novels , and because I was curious to see if the author could redeem herself by the end . She did not . This is yet another disappointing winner of a major award for fiction .

Awesome potential turns into strange meandering novel with little or no central plot . I 'm a fan of Jack McDevitt , having read nearly all of his novels . His recent work though leaves me baffled . There 's so much potential with the Ancient Shores universe that this should have been one heck of a story . However , what was delivered was a random meandering story with no central plot . The character just kinda show up at the roundhouse , explore something , nothing exciting happens , and they come back home . Rinse and repeat . The administration of the roundhouse seems somewhat implausible for an artifact of such interest to humanity , to be sending out missions haphazardly with what appear to be unqualified characters and unclear goals . Security is terrible . A significant portion of the book is characters whining about how the roundhouse presents a threat rather than an opportunity . It 's like McDevitt is giving the middle finger to the work that he created . I 'm genuinely puzzled why this thing turned out the way it did . Nevertheless , I did enjoy reading it , and I enjoy the author 's work , so I feel it 's worthy of three stars , and McDevitt completion is ts will want to pick it up .

Sad and Inspiring . A poignant and heart - wrenching account of a woman 's life of abuse , alcoholism and neglect from her family starting at a very young age of 3 . The author copes in unhealthy ways , but finds healing , health , love , and forgiveness when she accepts Jesus Christ . The one stable and loving force is the family 's maid , Rose , who is the author 's grounding and loving adult . I highly recommend this book for anyone . It will move you to tears from the tragic family life , and then uplift you with tears of joy .

Difficult to understand , but essential to read . The authors are distinguished scientists holding advanced degrees in chemistry , materials science , and geochemistry . This book clearly reflects that , and if you 've not studied any of these sciences , a primer is in order . They thoroughly rebut Miller 's infamous experiment which supposedly proved life can come from nonliving matter . This book explores the hypothesis of chemical evolution and what conditions would be required , as well as what conditions probably were like on the Earth prior to sentient life developing . Darwin 's point about wanting a " warm little pond " in which evolution would take place is delved into in the chapter " The Myth of the Prebiotic Soup . " Whether you believe in evolution , creation , or creationism , this book is a must - read for anyone with an interest in science .

I liked the aspect of how Sylvia reads her ancestor 's journal to find out what happened in her family . The way the journal is intercut with Sylvia 's daily life is interesting .

Home . A sad novel depicting family dynamics . Each person in the family presents a facade to the members of the household which only serves to isolate them within the family unit . HOME should be a refuge to those returning after many years . But years can not erase the attitudes , prejudices and stigmas that prevail . Unfortunately , the characters'lack of openness to the members of their family causes each member to remain troubled and alone . The facades stay in place , and HOME becomes only a boarding house where several strangers live under the same roof . A bit predictable but enjoyable book .

One Star Because Zero is Not an Option . I have been reading this series since the beginning . It was well written and humorous when it first began but the past few books just seem " off " . No longer are there funny moments between Eve and Somerset , no longer is Eve growing out of her awkwardness . She seems to have stopped aging and thus I still do not have the pleasure of reading about her building a family with her Roarke . Now we have more foul language , a stalled plot with the main story repeated throughout . It is as if the writer thinks we can not follow along . Perhaps they are simply trying to add more pages to the book ? I have never been this bored while reading an " in death " novel . Key supporting characters have been forgotten . Sadly , it seems it is time for this series to die .

Simplistic . Although easy to read , this book offers up large doses of simplistic problems with painfully obvious answers . Granted , mastery of the soft skills encompassed by EQ are important but this book is too superficial in its coverage . Studies are referenced and there is a generous notes section . The references are dated , Seinfeld , really ? And frankly , using Princess Diana as the model of social responsibility was laughable . While she may have been a pleasant enough person she was essentially a media created celebrity . Posing for pictures with sick people or advocating for obviously unobjectionable causes land mines pales in face of the humility and impact of Mother Theresa or the courage of activists such as Lech Walesa . Most of the information is valid but it lacks the depth of a text and the practicality of the best self help books . I do n't know that most students would have either the time or patience to invest in this book . Pass .

Trash . The worst kind of trash , and unfortunately part of a growing genre . If you have read anything by Ann Coulter or Michael Moore you know what to expect . This is literature in a post - literary world , where television is the ultimate form of expression . You 'll find not a fact predigested . The author has nothing interesting to contribute other than noise . The issues he discusses are not nearly as important as his own self promotion . The deliberate , reckless destruction of other people 's reputations in pursuit of notoriety is particularly loathsome . This book , like the works of Moore and Coulter , belongs in the trash . It 's utterly em bares sing that this style of writing has received even 15 minutes of fame in the 21st century .

operated . The most frustrating thing about this book is that it 's just interesting enough to keep you reading . Much of it is thumping ly boring . It 's pretentious and convoluted . That probably explains some of the rapturous reviews . There is a type of reviewer who simply loves this kind of thing . The narration shifts from section to section . Then you find out that the story you 've been told is n't true . That 's a real tiresome fictional gimmick . Of course it is n't true , it 's fiction . Meta fiction is rather tedious . To add insult to injury , the book gets rather preachy at a certain point . The narrator faces a crisis . He wrote a book in which he did n't portray a kid who got killed as a man in full but as well , a subject . He 's a writer . That 's what you do . then it ends and what has it been , not much !

Huge disappointment for this American . I purchased this collection to accompany me on a long automobile road trip . It was a waste of money , and I am giving it away . Here 's why . ALL of these short stories are narrated by Brits . What 's wrong with that ? I , as well as many other Americans , do not understand Brits very well when they are speaking . The words run together , the accents are different , and some words sound like they are mumbled . This , then , is exacerbated by background noise in a moving vehicle . I was not able to understand and enjoy even one story . If you have a hard time understanding Masterpiece Theater or Elementary on TV , then you will not enjoy this collection of short stories on CD .

A parable with a fairytale interior , that went on too long and was ultimately disappointing . What - the - Dickens intrigued me because it 's a Gregory Maguire book ostensibly for children . Well , not really for children , but it 's a storytelling book . And it was . okay . But not the awesome I was hoping for . It 's a story within a story , of three scared kids caught in a big storm without their parents , and their cousin who tells a fairytale to calm them . It 's got some dry wit and an adult layer over the story , but it started to drag on a bit long for my tastes . Maybe I 'm just the wrong age group for it ? The entire point of the external narrative framework was to come to one conclusion , at the very end we all need hope and belief in something . But the story never concludes , and that got under my skin a bit . I do n't have much to say about this one . If you like whimsical stories that parody a sort of WWI - esque social mentality , you 'll probably get a kick out of it .

Good Example Code But Poor Poor Object Oriented Programming . This book is very good in one thing , that is it does give many examples , by which you can get the feel of complex Java topics like Multithreading , RMI , Java Beans , Servlets , and Networking rather easily . But this book is atrocious in using and in emphasizing the concept of Object Oriented Programming OOP . In fact basically it is a C programming book with Java syntax and methods . This is because authors have used Java classes pretty much the way one can use struck in C make fields private and methods public . Otherwise where else will you see such murder of venerable OOP principle of encapsulation and information hiding , where the constructor does the work of 10 methods like a GOD constructor and the class that is supposed to be hidden has its own driver program . I give authors lot of credit for being excellent C programmers , but my doubts about their OOP knowledge will not disappear , unless I see a better product OOP product . I have not seen their C book , but I am sure that it is excellent .

Exquisite character drama about a unique boy . This is a book of deep and complex characters painted with exquisite language . Ordinarily I 'm more of a plot and adventure fan , but the characters here , particularly Edgar , are so richly portrayed that you really want to keep reading their saga . And it really is a saga . I 'm not going to recount the whole plot here , but the characters are challenged , feeling pain , and struggling though life . Edgar is unique , you have to read him carefully to understand what he 's experiencing because he experiences things a bit differently . You keep reading because you want to know how his life turns out . It 's not an adventure story with a big climactic ending , it 's a human struggle story where real characters survive real and surreal challenges . I 'm giving it only three stars because it was so . challenging . Read the first few pages using the Amazon " Look Inside " feature . If you like what you see , you 'll enjoy the book .

Clear but Very Basic . Table Saw , The Tool Information You Need At Your Fingertips Missing Ship Manual is a very clearly written and well illustrated book . Every drawing is well thought out and presented . The text is also clear and concise , what there is of it . The problem , and it is a big one , is the manual is so basic . It does show how to build a cross cut sled , for example , but the vast majority of the book is give to telling one how to rip a board or how to use the cross cut miter gage . Even the maintenance instructions are basic - with one exception . If you are buying your first table saw this might be an educational book for you however , if you have used a table saw for even one month this book will start to look very basic . Another good thing about the book is its stress on safety . Even the cross cut sled has a number of good safety features , even though I have seen more in a cross cut sled plan by Woodsmith . To earn even three stars the book would have to include more easy to make jigs . AD2

not Garwood 's best effort , but still worth the read . I 've been a fan of Garwood 's work for years , and rate several of her novels as among the best ever written in the genre . The plot was needlessly complicated I feel like a lot of explanatory details were left on the cutting room floor and I think would have worked best as two separate stories . The entire Ramsey - Bridgid plot had a lot of potential , but to me was never satisfactorily fleshed out . A separate book would have allowed for some explanation of Gideon 's motives , of Ramsey 's rise to power , and of Bridgid 's early life I think they and we deserved that story . Ransom deserves 3 . 5 stars oh Amazon , give us half stars and even a lukewarm Garwood is better than many of the other romance novels out there . Over 30 flaps to lift ! -the cover promises . OK . So when you lift the flap , you 're supposed to see a picture underneath that furthers the story . that gives a little surprise . that at the very least , catches a young child 's eye . This is the other big failure with this book . The flaps are a flop ! Take for example the flap over a lamp in Elmo 's room - you lift the flap and see the same lamp , same position , with a tiiiiiny bit of yellow indicating that it 's now on . Wow . Another flap shows Elmo 's hand on the toilet handle . Lift the flap and his hand has moved like 20 degrees , indicating he 's now flushing the toilet . My toddler does n't get it . I barely get it , and I 'm an educated grown woman . Look elsewhere if your kid likes lift - a - flap books .

Beware the date of this book , written before serious fraud in evidence collection and analysis was proven to be fabricated . Disregard the stars - I have n't read this book and I 'm not rating the book , I 'm writing to alert readers of it to pay attention to its being written in 2005 . I just finished watching the updated , complete 13 chapters of new documentary , and when I see a book about the case written in 2005 , it seems important that any readers of this book know the evidence presented in court in 2003 and on which the trial 's verdict was based was proven in 2011 to be completely tainted by a prosecution " expert " named Deaver who fabricated and lied both about himself as expert and the blood and other evidence in this case . He based his claims and his theory of Michael 's guilt on supposed " lab experiments " that were completely invalid and unreliable , preposterous violations of even the concept of " experiment . " So whatever this book persuades a reader to believe , it by definition has to be based at least in very large part on'evidence'as of 2005 that is no longer valid evidence .

A bit long for the story it told . I do n't even know where to begin with this . I guess I will say that it was interesting to see a different perspective on King Richard III , and the book was researched and written well enough to make me want to believe that THIS , not the other , terrible things written about him , is his true story . Although while part of me is glad that Ms. Smith was true to history , I have just enough of a romantic soul to wish that Richard had continued his true love affair with Kate even once he was married to Anne , or at least picked back up with it in the short time between Anne 's death and his own death . Overall , this book was good , but I also felt it was a little long and drawn out . I liked it but wo n't go naming it as one of my favorites .

I was not captivated ! This book is about the bravery of the American Presidents from 1789 to 1989 , and how they changed and shaped American policy . I did n't much enjoy reading this book . I liked the chapters on George Washington and Lincoln probably because I have read their biographies , but was n't captivated enough by the stories of the other presidents . I did n't find bravery in many of the stories . Some presidents did shape US policy , but that in itself is not bravery ! It was more like self - preservation . I also did n't like the author 's style of writing . Furthermore , the chapters are not broken down by the name of presidents , so it is difficult to use this book as a cross - reference . I would have liked to see chapters on Clinton and Bush junior . Why did the author choose presidents up to 1989 only ? Why not up to the present day ? This book was after all published in 2007 , so Clinton and Bush could have been included .

Its not a bad book , I was just disappointed by the choice of scientists to highlight . Ill start by saying this is one of my sons favorite books , his favorite has always been This Little President and I was hoping this would be a nice addition , so it does do the job , however I have a problem with the scientists chosen . In fact , every scientist on the last page getting a mini blurb I think could have deserved an actual page over some that were chosen . Not all were bad , but I think at least 3 or 4 of the pages could have gone to a much more interesting scientist . I do n't think its a bad idea to shed light on some lesser known scientists , but for a children book highlighting only a few , I d love it to focus on someone more well known . Similarly , I think this book did a great job of showing that women can be just as important as male scientists , since their are more women than men in the book , however Rachel Carson and Annie Easley are household names that I think should have been included .

Pretty Sassy Cool Approved . Sort of . i not really the biggest fan of Charlaine Harris , but I m glad she did not write this to mirror the Sookie Stackhouse novels . Welcome to Midnight , Texas . There is one stop light and few people in this town . We are introduced to Manfred Bernardo , half psychic half conman who has just relocated to Midnight to have a more peaceful place to work , giving his readings over the phone and internet . Little does he realize he s moved into the center of something much more . Charlaine Harris gives great descriptions of all her characters and the roles they play in Midnight . However much this makes for a lot of ground workthats it . Hardly any good action actually takes place in this book . I liked the magical factor of this book , but it just want enough . I want to read the second book Day Shift only because I want to know what happens to Lemuel and Olivia . Lacking in action and plot , Midnight Crossroad is a great idea but leaves a lot to be desired .

Not just for dogs . We are bunny owners , and I bought this book because our local shelter told us that clicker training can be a very effective tool for all pets . " Reaching the Animal Mind " is much more in - depth than I had thought it would be , and I found it to be a slightly challenging read . I personally wanted more of " this is how you train your animal " and less animal psychology , although the information is very worthwhile and extremely helpful and effective . The back of the book has an extensive glossary and appendix - the research is quite impressive . The use of positive reinforcement over negative punishment is such a breath of fresh air . This book would be helpful for any pet owner .

Run away ! Buy something else ! One whining millennial after the other foolishly believed their insipid personal narratives constituted enough entertainment to be transformed into fiction . Ho hum . Other than the delightful story by Maria Reva , which relates the stereotypes of Russian bureaucracy , the book is n't worth the paper its printed on . The stories were so horrible , that , even by skipping several paragraphs , you can still get a feel for the plot i. e. nothing warrants going back for the not - so - missing details . I was shocked to see that so many of the authors had such outstanding credentials . I continue to wonder what has happened to great storytelling and who is judging them .

Enjoyable . I liked this book although I found it to be a rather odd amalgam of personal reveal and historic reporting . The historic reporting of the LA Central Library fire was intense and riveting , if in reality unsolvable . The personal reflections , were to me , somewhat insipid and pale . It is a positive thing that Orleans explains why libraries mean so much to her , I just did n't find that it did much to enhance the story . At worst it interfered with the rhythm . I also found that the short chapter format created a choppy narrative that bounced from theme to theme and was to me , less than optimal . Perhaps the format is more suitable to the unfolding of a mystery , this was not it . The title is a bit of a misnomer . It is really about Libraries , the sum of all books , rather than just one .

HarperCollins did n't do its job . This novel was " Eat , Pray , Love " meets " The Da Vinci Code . " If you enjoyed either of those books , this story might be up your alley . My complaint has nothing to do with the author or her story . My complaint is that of a consumer this book was very poorly copyedited . Perhaps half of the pages contained an error where a preposition or a definite or indefinite article were missing , and occasionally there were sentences that were missing subject - verb agreement . Some sentences were missing clauses that interfered with them even making sense . This want a self - published or small press book where you know that budget constraints might have factored into its production . This book was published by William Morrow , an imprint of HarperCollins . The cover price was 27 . 99 . Cmon , HarperCollins , is it too much to ask that you have an editor give a manuscript a final pass before it heads to the printer ? Surely your readers and authors deserve some professionalism .

The book was of no value to me . I really was n't expecting it to be that helpful , but it was even less thorough than I anticipated . I have a modest Ed . Wusthof collection going back to a few 1814 - 1895 knives , several 1895 - 1920 's , and then pre - WWII to present , roughly 100 knives total . The books coverage however , is abysmal . There are three pages on Anton Wingen , for example , that was in business 1888 - 1993 . For Ed . Wusthof , a company that is family owned for over 200 years , from 1814 to present day , there 's 34 of a page . That meager listing leaves out the 2 earliest company marks . With even my limited knowledge , I could list several pages of maker 's marks for the company , with approximate year ranges , designs , and materials . I wo n't try to return it because the seller did his job with speedy delivery , and there are no promises in the description as to what it will do for me . I 'm commenting just to warn other users to check it out a little more carefully , it 's far from a'bible'of German cutlery .

The Kim Kardashian of Indian Fiction . I gave this book 2 stars only because the Hindu mythology and the vague references to it in an attempt to explain some historical findings traditions is interesting . The main plot however starts off at a peak , hot fast and ends in a cold flat dull pit . The story telling is so horribly amateurish I was quite shocked it even got published at such a grand level . I guess being a loaded industrialist helps in that regards . The story seems like it was written by someone in high school who just read Da Vinci Code and was so excited by it he had to find a quick Hindu parallel bang a novella out . That 's why I call this book the Kim K of modern Indian fiction , superficial promise of something spectacular , famous for no good reason , just good marketing put to good use .

Good description suspense . Colonel Patterson was quite a sportsman and wrote in an informal style about his experience in ridding the Tsavo area of Kenya of at least two man - eating lions that had taken and consumed hundreds of workers on the Uganda railroad project where he was an engineer during the construction . Patterson created a good descriptive narrative that deals with the subject lions in the first half of the book and devotes the rest to tales of his hunting trips for other big game in Africa . His approach is matter of fact , devoid of hyperbole and compelling reading .

Hold on Tight . Holy YES PLEASE ! I got this book early as part of the Kindle first program . It is set in Nashville , Tennessee one of my favorite places . Right from the beginning you can sense the mystery , suspense , and secrets . This book had me hooked from page one and never let go . The character of Finley is a very complex character that I appreciate tremendously . There are so many facets to her your not sure what is what or who she really is until you dive deeper into the story . This story has many layers of suspense not just on the case Finley and Jack are working , but with Finley , her past , and her husband . The intrigue as you turn each page grows and you find yourself on the edge of your seat unable to stop turning pages . The last chapter of this book was so amazing with more twists and turns than you ever saw coming . I can not wait to see what happens or what is discovered regarding Finley and Derrick . This was my first book by Debra Webb and now I must go buy more !

Follows The Same Formula As The Rest Of The Series . The Final Spark is the conclusion of the Michael Vey series about a group of teenagers dealing with the gifts that were thrust upon them during their mothers'pregnancies . Honestly , the series went on too long and I struggled to read through this book . The Final Spark sputtered out and did not have the impact of the first few books . Although the situation had changed for Michael and his friends , this book followed the same formula as the others . I did not find it all that exciting and was not thrilled with either the writing style or the plot . The dialogue seemed forced in places and the situations in which the Electroclan find themselves are not all that realistic . It seems ridiculous that the teenagers , their parents , and others in authority would not have found a way , by now , to get the upper hand over Hatch . The Final Spark is not a book I would recommend to other readers , as it was a disappointing end to the series .

5 stars if you do n't expect much combat narrative . Glad I read it , it changed my entire outlook about the Pacific war . The Southwest became a black hole for Japanese airpower and once it was one the outcome of the war in the Pacific was decided . This book covers every detail of living conditions , training , leadership , organization , the airplanes , et . What you do n't get is a lot of combat narrative . When I was 300 pages in I was thinking , so detailed accounts of the missions should start now . it never did ! BUT , by reading this you are rewarded with a deep understanding of how the Pacific war in the air was won . I highly recommend .

Post - Katrina New Orleans . Carmela , owner of a New Orleans scrapbook ing store , is trying to get her business back together as well as her relationship with her ex - husband , Shamus . Things change quickly when Shamus is kidnapped and his Uncle Henry is murdered . Of course the New Orleans police can not be trusted to solve the mystery , so Carmela launches her own investigation . She and her friend Ava talk to several possible suspects in an attempt to find out who had a reason to resort to kidnapping and murder . The best thing about this book is the setting , and there are quite a few interesting references to different aspects of New Orleans . On the down side , there are several spelling mistakes in the book which is always a distraction . Also the plot is not very compelling and the characters are quite one - dimensional . I found myself not very interested in whether Carmela and Shamus continue their on - again - off - again relationship or not .

Very disappointed in Chilton 's , once a good name in automotive care . My windshield washer motor is not working , and there does n't look like an easy way to replace it or the plastic reservoir . So I look in this manual and it says disconnect the battery remove the washer reservoir drain reservoir fluid remove pump from reservoir inspect pump and replace if necessary install pump until seated on the seal install reservoir refill reservoir reconnect battery Well , duh . Anyone with a lick of common sense could give you those instructions . Unlike Chilton 's manuals of the past , that used to be massive , NOWHERE in this cheap , thin , paperback manual does it say HOW to remove the reservoir . It appears that it has to be removed from underneath , or possibly from the wheel - well . Basic simple instructions like these are useless , and this manual is full of vague explanations . Unfortunately , there are no other manuals to choose from .

A waste of money . I am very new to SQL Server 2000 or any SQL Server for that matter , so I wanted a book that was robust , but was easy to follow . " Step by Step " seemed to be the way to go , but this book leaves MUCH to be desired . It is WAY too basic . I mean , the language SQL Server uses is called TRANSACT - SQL , but not ONCE in the book does she go over TRANSACTIONS ! She reiterated the same points over and over , and used WAY too many screen shots . I would say at least 70 of the book is comprised of useless screen shots . You get hardly any actual content at all . and best of all , the examples are VERY weak . I am a big fan of WROX books , since WROX books are very complete and can be used as a desk reference . This book , however , is unless the second you finish it . I recommend it ONLY to people who have never programmed ANYTHING before , and to those who do n't care about learning fundamentals like transactions . The entire contents of this book can be learned from a 30 minute reading of some of the MSDN documentation .

5 stars for the photographs not including the double exposures and 1 star for the text which is best described as odd and word . I have split this review in half to accurately rate it 5 stars for the photographs not including the double exposures and 1 star for the text which is best described as odd and borderline silly . This book could n't seem to decide if it wanted to be an architecture book , a photography book , or a rambling stream of consciousness from the overly fanciful brain of Laughlin . Frankly , I could n't stand the authors anthropomorphizing of every tree , pillar , and clump of Spanish moss . The flowery , artsy descriptions were so unnecessary . The photographs themselves expressed everything that needed to be said from the beauty of long ago architectural achievement to the sad depression of neglect and loss . Words really were n't needed other than the histories of the houses and the people whose vision and talent built them . I also did n't think photos that were intentionally produced as double exposures were needed . They added nothing to the book and made me question what genre this book was trying to fit into .

Not for Younger Children . Ms. Masterson visited my five - year - old son 's class recently , ostensibly to help children get in touch with their emotions however , the real reason appears to have been to sell her book . The book , which is meant to help children get in touch with their feelings , may be appropriate for older children . But when a five - year - old tells me that he does n't like himself , something has gone horribly wrong . My son has been unable to sleep , has not been his usual carefree self , has difficulty sleeping , has expressed feelings of loneliness , and has generally become a different child since listening to Ms. Masterson 's " feelings " spiel . Does anyone out there really believe that it 's appropriate for a preschooler to try to " heal his insides " ? Come on . What is this ? A new age approach to child rearing ? If so , it seems to be more damaging than helpful . I strongly urge parents of younger children to keep their kids way from this book and Ms. Masterson .

Flawed but interesting . Nightfall is a flawed but enjoyable dark tale that offers up an interesting and unique premise while creating a fair amount of suspense and thrills . A hefty suspension of disbelief is required for this one , and a bit of patience as it takes quite a while for things to ramp up . Still , I felt the suspense from the first , and it was my rampant curiosity that kept me going through the entire first part of the novel . Nightfall exhibits little or no character development , so it 's kind of hard to care about these characters . The idea was just so attractive to me that I hung with it , and was somewhat rewarded by some unique monsters and a mythology that developed nicely throughout the novel . The action packed second half of the book is where the chills and horror filled moments come in , and this novel delivered pretty well . Once again , you ca n't examine things too closely , but if you are able to just go along for the ride , it turns into a fun trip . Nightfall is a cautious recommend for horror fans in middle school and up .

Better than the Slithering Corpse . This is a companion to the book The Slithering Corpse and other Sinister Stories . This one is MUCH more of a visceral read - plenty of people dying and getting hacked up or devoured . Though the other one did terrify me , I read this first , and it has always had the power to send a chill down my spine . The first story especially , still affects me , and I read this book 11 years ago ! It was terrifying as a child because the circumstances are quite easy to relate to and brings back to mind all those things in the dark you never wanted to see . Although it has the same scare - factor as Alvin Schwart 's books , those stories really relied on Stephen Gammell 's drawings to amp up the fright . These stories could stand on their own . The font , the drawings , the abrupt , rather simple way it 's written - perfection for any child who REALLY wants to feel the icy chill of fear clutching their heart !
