Disappointing . This is about a boy who , after a near - fatal childhood accident , became an introspective poet . But I did not find it to be something that would pull me into the narrative or learn very much about the character . The book is small , the typeface as well . No photos other than that on the front . The narratives were detached , seemed to ramble on . This book seemed to be a series of vignettes which sometimes appeared to be illusions or dreams . I could not really relate to the child , nor could I relate to the writer who was more of a disembodied voice than a narrator , or a fly - on - the - wall . If at least there had been a photo of the child with his favorite dog as mentioned on one of the opening pages , perhaps it would have added some " body " to this book , but nothing here was really compelling . Nothing really brought us closer to the boy as a child and then a man . Cloudy writing at best .

Disappointed . I have read every one of Jennifer Weiners'books . So I bought this one in an airport , hard copy . Miserable mistake . It 's an easy , fast read - that 's what I 've always loved about Weiner - her books and her people are relatable and real which makes the reading a delight . But this was slowly paced , very little happened , and worst of all - the main character was unlikable . She came across as pretentious and seemed to sincerely believe even after her rock - bottom scenario in the bathroom of her daughters birthday party that she was better than everyone else . I saw shades of this mean - spirited persona flickering throughout'The Next Best Thing ' , but there were so many lovely moments in that book that I dismissed it . It makes me wonder if her profound success has removed her from everyday reality , and she herself now views the world with somewhat disdainful eyes . Original Jennifer Weiner we loved you . Come back to us .

The Best Book I 've Read In The Last Five Years . I almost never recommend books to anyone . Ever . Seriously . It never works out well when you recommend anything to friends , but especially books . Even if you have always loved the same books , it never works out . However . . . for this book , I am willing to risk it because it is simply that good . The narrator of the story is the maid . No big spoiler there . That she is weird is also not a spoiler . By weird I am talking about a person who is somewhere on the Auspberger 's scale sorry about the spelling . She is extremely smart about facts , but clueless about people 's emotions and motivations . She is the unseeing eye of the hurricane of life that swirls around her . She can describe everything , but understands nothing . This makes her descriptions of this murder mystery both fascinating and hilarious . I am actually recommending it to my harshest critic , my mother . That 's how good it is !

Suspenseful , especially since it 's a first of . There were times I wondered if this would turn into a religious " end of days " novel . It did not . Thankfully , because that 's something I can not abide . Instead , it proved to be a pretty gripping apocalyptic novel , one I can say is realistic because my specialty in university was mass extinction , with emphasis on the two " biggies " , the end - Permian , a volcanic event , and the end Cretaceous , a mostly meteoric event . This story , being focused on religious zealotry turned " crime against humanity " , is believable precisely because there are religious fanatics and politician allies who would be willing to create just such an endgame in order to " save our souls " . Throughout , however , Freedman weaves a captivating and not - so - predictable story . What more can I ask ? Perhaps I enjoyed it more understanding the events because I too am a scientist with Ryanne 's background , but I think not . As long as you are n't a science - denying fool , you will understand everything clearly . I would only assure you this story is VERY plausible given the circumstances presented let us just hope we live in a slightly more rational world . On to the next . I 'm glad I did not have to wait . I do n't have that many years left .

sanford Ca n't Write a Bad Book . Usually authors who are as prolific as Sandford eventually seem to burn out and their later books are often stinkers . This malady does not seem to afflict Sandford who churns out book after book and never fails to deliver a riveting story to the reader . Shock Wave is no exception . Sandford spins a nice yarn involving Minnesota investigator Virgil Flowers , who is a mellower version of his boss , the fabled Lucas Davenport . In this book , Flowers is called into a small Minnesota city to investigate the bombing of a planned " big box " store site . He pursues the bomber , just as the bomber begins to pursue him . Sandford keeps the action going and also does a good job of keeping the characters realistic . He does n't rely on a bunch of serendipitous plot turns and , in this day of hyper - violent novels and movies , Sandford manages to tone things down a notch . All in all , a very good thriller .

A good book in many ways , but- . Falls short , in my opinion , though it 's a good book in many ways well written , good characterizations , and well conceived - personal dramas played out against the background of larger historical events . But it 's told in the first person , and the narrator 's voice is monotonal - and ultimately monotonous . As to what that tone is , I 'll quote Lila , from Marilynn Robinson 's much better book of that name " He looked at every single thing in the world as if it had a price tag on it and he knew it was n't worth half that much because he could see what the paint hid , where the rot was . " p 243 . And so it is here . There 's a lot of pithy criticism and acute social observation , but it wears thin and is n't enough to carry a 384 - page book . It 's a shame , really , for a work that has so much going for it I feel like the author tripped over his own feet . A good editor could have helped him out .

Pleasant Diversion for an Afternoon . I enjoyed reading " Do n't Lose Her " by Jonathon King , but after I finished , I was left with a sense of dissatisfaction . Private Investigator Max Freeman is called in to investigate the kidnapping of the wife of his best friend , a federal judge who is 8 months pregnant . King head hops from the judge 's POV , to Freeman 's to the kidnapper 's to give the reader a good understanding of what is happening and to allow us to develop sympathy for all who are involved . King moves the plot along , and it was hard for me to put the book down . I especially enjoyed the setting in the Florida Everglades . Yet , I found the rationale for the kidnapping to be kind of silly , and Freeman largely was a reduced to the role of gofer while his friend Billy , husband of the kidnapped victim , is the one who does the heavy lifting in terms of solving the identify and motive of the people behind the kidnapping - and he pretty much does it off scene , presenting his conclusions to Freeman as wait accompli . I do n't know that I would read another book in this series , but it was a pleasant enough diversion for an afternoon .

Great conclusion and first book of a series , but . elder 's Game is a great sci - fi in many ways . It is a much easier to read than many futuristic pieces and the settings are vivid although somewhat left to the imagination am I just saying I have a good imagination The novel follows Ender as he completes military training to defeat'The Buggers ' . In order to succeed Ender must survive his murderous brother , fellow students , the games that his superiors play , and eventually the enemy themselves . My problem with the book is that its main drawcard is the ending twist . The rest of the book lacks real tension . The main character is a child prodigy who never looses a battle , so one reads the book without any fear of the protagonist failing or the need for a resolution of tension . The character development is relatively basic , although there are a few satisfying revelations . There are also the occasional interesting philosophies on warfare throughout Ender 's lessons . Ultimately Ender 's Game is an excellent beginning to a series and a relatively easy read . Recommended to sci - fi fans and those who enjoy straightforward books .

Repetitive and TRITE . I 'd never read anything by this author , but a trusted reader - friend of mine gave me a copy and hailed it as nothing short of amazing . Well , it 's the kind of novel that one retreats to in hopes that something will actually happen this time I pick it up , only to find a scattered nugget or tiniest bit of insight - just enough to bait the reader for the next attempt at the novel . Even with the assistance of the Irish Dublin vernacular , French 's characters remain mostly flat and almost entirely featureless - which is a shame since the reader really WANTS to imagine these people and care about their lives . The story is told - rather than developed - and is anchored by shameless repetition . and not the good kind , either . Perhaps the author 's use of this device meant to reflect oral traditions in the tightly - compacted neighborhoods of Dublin , but the repetition never makes the story more compelling nor does it flesh - out the characters it merely annoys the reader . faithful Place _ became one of those novels that I forced myself to finish - but not out of anticipation .

Definitely an " adult " fairy tale . This was my first ever Neil Gaiman novel , and the fact that it had been billed as an " adult fairy tale " got my interest . The premise is an interesting one to win the heart of the beautiful Victoria Forester that he loves , young Tristan Thorn embarks on a quest to return with a star they saw fall from the sky . But when he enters the land of Fairie , he finds himself in a strange and dangerous world . While there were moments where Gaiman 's talent shone , there were also episodes filled with overly - long sentences and extensive parts in brackets which bogged things down . What 's more , the story proved " adult " in more ways than none , with at least one obscenity and several sexually explicit references that make this tale definitely unsuitable for children and teens . Perhaps this is a rare case where the movie is better than the book after all . -GODLY GADFLY April 2019

More suited for web analysts'managers . This is a fast reading book about how to be an effective web analyst at a large company that can afford such . The author writes that the web analyst needs to analyze web stats with respect to company 's goals , and then to present to management and other company staff , goal - oriented action steps . With color illustrations , so very pleasant fast reading . Not really sure this book 's worth the money though . Though it talks about a web analyst job , its simplistic message is that a job any job - e. g. web analyst needs to be seen in relationship to the company 's goals and its other employees . So , the book is basically a Business 101 Career Guide - to understand what one 's job in a company really is . My opinion is that this book is more appropriate for the web analyst 's manager - so that the manager understands what the web analyst is suppose to be doing . It 's too basic for a web analyst careerist .

. continued Parker 's series have successfully maintained what I have loved about them . The other writers who have continued Parker 's series have successfully maintained what I have loved about them . Coleman does n't . In his hands , Jesse Stone is not just a flawed human being but a tortured mess - a whole different character in ways that count . The hope that he can learn to control his drinking is gone . Instead of figuring out a relatively clean way to sort out the evil around him , this Jesse Stone buys into it , leaving him compromised and even more tortured . The ending , instead of providing the reader with a small island of satisfying closure , simply ups the horror . Coleman may be a good writer of his kind of stuff , but cramming a Parker novel into his recipe was not a good idea .

Lighthouse . This is a great book , extremely well written by W. Isaacson . I am a non - American citizen with a lot of respect and interest for the history of the USA . Now I am reading several books about the Colonial era and the Founding Fathers , and I 've found this to be the best book I 've read so far , and Benjamin Franklin , in my modest opinion , the best American ever . I learned a lot and I feel very close to B. Franklin . He is a great model of citizenship to follow . A lighthouse to all of us ! I 'd recommend this book to anybody who would like to know more about the life of Benjamin Franklin scholar or just curious , somebody interested in the history of the US of the XVIII century , and anybody who likes to read History or Biography in general . If you feel a lack of true leadership in the overall US politicians today , this book will give you tons of it !

Not Another Not So Good Picture Book . If your primary interest is in a picture book on calligraphy you would do better to search the topic on Pinterest at least there you might have a better chance of actually having a caption associated with the images . Ms. Lach disappoints in her limited approach to compiling images for this book . There seem to be as many images of'things'script is fashioned after than there are images of actual script . What is most disturbing is that she neglected to add captions that could offer a description of the script portrayed . There is so little for the student of calligraphy to glean from the pages of this book money would be better spent looking specifically for an historical summary of the craft . Do n't get me wrong I love the images it 's just that I would have really loved to read captions describing them .

I did not find it to be a good book for master 's students taking a course on introduction to online teaching , though . There is nothing in this book I do not cover in my course through mini - lectures or articles . Additionally , some of the information in the text is common sense . I would not use this in the course I teach as I find it too basic . Perhaps it would be a good text for undergraduate students since there is little to no theory in the text . It 's basically a " how to " text for novices .

However , the profanity is so pervasive and so gratuitous that it ruined " We Are Never Meeting In Real Life " for me . Just about every other sentence is full of the F word , G. D. , Bitch , et . et . And it adds NOTHING to what Ms. Irby is saying . I 'm sure not a prude and have been known to use profanity rather often when it means something . It is pointless and grating to the reader to have profanity thrown in ad nausea . Samantha Irby has a lot better vocabulary than to just bomb us over and over with words that do n't add anything to the story . Maybe this is the way people actually talk somewhere , but nowhere I know about . The book would have been at least 110 shorter without the bomb words . Ms. Irby is a good writer and she can be very entertaining . Again , she could have done so much better .

Strange Maladies for Sure . Early on in the book I was reminded of Eric Berne 's work of forty years ago . which he titled Games People Play in an attempt to describe both functional and dysfunctional social interactions . Berne described the types of social interactions . Now comes Jhumpa Lahiri with her extraordinary talent which allows her to describe how these people communicate with each other and more amazingly , what they say when they communicate with themselves . She is truly an Interpreter of Maladies and as Frederick Busch noted in his oft quoted praise of her Pulitizer . " Lahiri honors the vastness and various ness of the world . " I suspect there are few people who suffer from such maladies but they need an interpreter just like everyone else , I suppose . And Ms. Lahiri is a good one .

Misleading - No padded covers and not a board book . I bought this book thinking it would have cloth - padded covers as per the description , but really , only the crescent moon is padded and wrapped in a shiny fabric . Also , from the stitched drawings , I had thought they will be somewhat textured . Turns out that was just the illustrator 's style . Pages are rather flimsy - not a true board book , but the worst part was the flaps . They are a thin paper folded along one edge and glued sticky - taped to the pages , which will so easily be ripped by a toddler handling the book and lifting the flaps as they love to . Our copy already has a flap completely detached itself after just two readings . I have put it away , as it serves no purpose if my 18 - month old ca n't lift the flaps by herself without tearing them .

Life , food , and personal culture . Yeah , I just said the words " personal culture . " Maybe I should have said something more prose , like personal experience with culture . We taste . We put things in our mouths as infants as a way of learning about them . We taste and we taste life , and in tasting " find out about things . " And when you start to think about what you are tasting and what you are finding , thoughts really start exploding . For the author , and for many of us if we will acknowledge it , taste is a primary way of information gathering . And the events and sights and sounds all those other information passageways that are our senses that accompany it mean that food is culture and culture is food . And here , in this book , is the life that meets us at the plate . One person 's experience with cultures as experienced through food . Altogether a somewhat interesting read , which may or may not leave you hungry . And will probably also bring you some laughs and possibly some occasional gags . Forgettable , but entertaining .

All I Needed . I think I may need a dentist visit after this book , because it was so sweet it rotted my teeth . Young love in the summer always seems to be a good fit for this time of the year . I like that Colasanti brings realism to her idealistic characters there is struggle , real world pressures and work in this relationship . While Seth and Skye do seem made for each other , it does n't come easily . The subplots of college life and high school friendships hit the nail on the head as well . The 80s music throughout is also a plus in my book too . And finally in the plus column , it 's a short book , one you can easily finish in a single sitting or a single hour if you 're me . All in all , All I Need continues Colasanti 's tradition of delivering solid , sweet contemporaries to readers . Overall A-

Deeply moving and thoughtful . When Mary - Margaret , a well - meaning but slow young woman , sees a vision of Jesus'blood in a Roman Catholic Church , she stimulates a miracle - craze which compels many people to question the meaning of faith . This is a very difficult book for me to review because I 'm rather ambivalent about it . It is deep with meaning - but would mean something different to the " faithful " than it would to the " faithless . " This is a quality that few books attain , and I believe this is why it deserved to be nominated for the Orange Prize . However , this story is also very sad . it took me in a direction I did n't expect . There were a lot of negative messages mixed in with the positive messages , which , I suppose , represents life perfectly . But still . some of it was hard for me to read . I would recommend this book to anybody who wants to explore faith and the meaning of mother - child relationships more deeply , and with an open mind .

eyeopening . Not going to lie , there was a point in reading Alex Moazed and Nicholas L. Johnson 's " Modern Monopolies " that I had to put it down and stop reading because 1 there is so much information and 2 it was depressing me just how much the platform business model has taken over . I mean , I shop amazon , which is a platform , because it is convenient , it has much of what I need and ca n't find locally . Even to research products , I often use amazon so I can see how I use it in my life . But to actually read how this still fairly young business model is now the monopolies with no signs of slowing requires hitting the pause button because it can get exhausting . That said , the authors do present their information clearly and in a way that most readers will be able to follow and understand . As overwhelmed as I got , it was still understandable and maybe not required reading , but certainly eyeopening reading .

Maybe reaching this heavy , thick gloominess the comparison with honey is inevitable was the author 's intent , and if so , the book is a masterpiece . But after I finished reading it , I felt like reaching for air .

So Brian 's not Frank . Read this one , too . I came into this series with a lot of preconceptions that these would not be worthy successors to the originals . And they are n't . But after a second reading , I realized they 're not supposed to . " House Harkonnen " is a prequel , not a sequel . It 's supposed to " fill in the blanks " of what happened before the greatest book in science fiction history . NO book can ever hope to live up to that kind of hype . But I believe Brian and Kevin do a masterful job of setting up things that we know are going to happen in later books without killing the suspense . Now they 've started to explore the new storyline they created , and they do a good job . I , for one , ca n't wait to see " House Corrino " . So Brian 's not Frank . But he 's working from Frank 's notes , with the aid of an author who is used to working in other people 's universes . If you like " Dune " give this series a chance . I believe if you come into it with an open mind , you 'll find it almost as entertaining as the original .

Handy catalogue , poorly written . This is a formulaic set of essays , poorly written though if you 're a fan of dangling modifiers and repetitive clinches , you might get a kick out of reading . The author misunderstands some fundamental musical concepts e. g. , describing EVERY female voice as " soprano " . I find very little information here that is n't readily available on Wikipedia . I could go on at length about what a good editor might have done to improve the usefulness of this volume . That said , it 's a handy catalogue of significant folk - music figures and groups , and each chapter ends with a discography . so if you do n't have handy access to an internet search engine , this could actually be a useful book .

Great Story and Characters . Lady Delilah Montebank has her marital sights set on the Duke of Branville . There s just one problem he barely knows she exists . But no matter , she s got a plan to win him over with her charm , her witand perhaps the love potion she has in her possession would n't hurt her cause . Lord Thomas Hobbs , Duke of Huntley , thinks his best friend Delilahs quest to become a duchess is ridiculous . He s always said he rather give up all the brandy in London than commit to one person for life . Besides , he knows that Delilahs love potion ca nt possibly win over Branville . since she accidentally gave it to him instead . But perhaps this is the excuse he needs to show her he s always loved her . This was an inventive story on how a man can move from the friend zone in an era when the term did n't exist . In these types of stories , usually its the female with the unrequited love . It was a nice change of pace to have it the other way around . I really enjoyed this story and the characters , Delilahs quirky nature in particular . I recommend . I voluntarily read and reviewed this book

Pleasant Diversion for an Afternoon . I enjoyed reading " Do n't Lose Her " by Jonathon King , but after I finished , I was left with a sense of dissatisfaction . Private Investigator Max Freeman is called in to investigate the kidnapping of the wife of his best friend , a federal judge who is 8 months pregnant . King head hops from the judge 's POV , to Freeman 's to the kidnapper 's to give the reader a good understanding of what is happening and to allow us to develop sympathy for all who are involved . King moves the plot along , and it was hard for me to put the book down . I especially enjoyed the setting in the Florida Everglades . Yet , I found the rationale for the kidnapping to be kind of silly , and Freeman largely was a reduced to the role of gofer while his friend Billy , husband of the kidnapped victim , is the one who does the heavy lifting in terms of solving the identify and motive of the people behind the kidnapping - and he pretty much does it off scene , presenting his conclusions to Freeman as wait accompli . I do n't know that I would read another book in this series , but it was a pleasant enough diversion for an afternoon .

A Worthwhile Read . An easy reading , well - written , highly interesting , and enjoyable introduction to this turbulent period of Iberian history . Although at times the author veers dangerously close to historical fiction adding tidbits of detail which he has only inferred , speculating on the inner thoughts of his characters , making his own assessments of events , this account adheres closely to the known facts and most readers can easily determine when these inferences are being made . A popular history , not strictly a scholarly work , no footnotes . A general bibliography is provided . For a general audience i. e. , me this is an excellent book . I am glad that I found my ancient hardback copy in a library discard pile !

Gripping story overrides format errors . When I bought the first three books for my Kindle , I did n't realize there was a fourth until I finished book 3 last week . And lo , there it was in my recommendations . I loved the story Men and women kicking butt and taking names , the dead get a chance to have the final word before going to their just reward , and all the major players get pretty much what they deserve . Martin makes it clear that Happily Ever After is n't always going to be all kittens and rainbows , but she does end the story at a satisfactory point . The biggest problem I had with this eth book was the rough file proof only one paragraph in 3 was free from missing spaces , and all the em - dashes were hyphens . There was a bit of extra space between paragraphs , and the italics coding looked like it was botched in a few places . I do n't claim to be the most perfect writer , but I 'm the sort of person who gets knocked out of a story when I see a grammatical error . Despite all the bumps in the road , I still maintained my excitement over the journey I took with these characters .

Flawed but interesting . Nightfall is a flawed but enjoyable dark tale that offers up an interesting and unique premise while creating a fair amount of suspense and thrills . A hefty suspension of disbelief is required for this one , and a bit of patience as it takes quite a while for things to ramp up . Still , I felt the suspense from the first , and it was my rampant curiosity that kept me going through the entire first part of the novel . Nightfall exhibits little or no character development , so it 's kind of hard to care about these characters . The idea was just so attractive to me that I hung with it , and was somewhat rewarded by some unique monsters and a mythology that developed nicely throughout the novel . The action packed second half of the book is where the chills and horror filled moments come in , and this novel delivered pretty well . Once again , you ca n't examine things too closely , but if you are able to just go along for the ride , it turns into a fun trip . Nightfall is a cautious recommend for horror fans in middle school and up .

A brief interlude . I only really dug two of the four stories in here , which are standalone single issues that are n't forwarding a larger storyline . And those two are the ones in the middle , about cats and Shakespeare . Gaiman is a wise man in the fields of authority and creativity , and these middle two each really offered a pretty full worldview on their own . The other two strive for emotions they really do n't connect to by the end . Also included is Gaimans script for the first story as a curios . Overall , a stepping stone and pause before hopefully getting into some meatier stuff .

I was fortunate to know this handsome boy when he was a. I was fortunate to know this handsome boy when he was a baby . When I heard about the book , I ordered it immediately . When Shane was little , he loved to imitate the " Fonz " from Happy Day 's . My husband and I were so overjoyed on one afternoon at my mother 's home . We sat on the floor and encourage Shane to take his first steps . We let him go to each of us and the room was full of so much love . Yes we got his first steps and they are in my memory forever . What a gift from God he is . Happy and so sweet . I missed seeing his face for many years but knew he was given the best of the best and I heard what a great athlete he had become . Thank you for writing this book . I will probably cry , laugh and not be able to put it down . With all my love to Shane , A. D.

Borderline unreadable . I enjoyed the first book in the Hatching Series a lot and each subsequent book a little less . I appreciated the tight , punchy chapters and changes in point of view which reminded me of World War Z in a highly positive way . I wish I had found out the fate of every character but in the end the broader story was worth it . I say this because The Mansion is the exact opposite . It focuses on a very limited cast of characters in one primary setting . The first chapter was a long , painful , repetitive slog with verbose but uninspiring descriptions of roughing it in a cabin where software was being developed . Sometimes they did n't have electricity but somehow they invented something better than Alexa and better than Google . Ok . Sure . I feel guilty for reviewing something I am having a hard time finishing , but if I can save someone else from this , it 's worth it .

Boxes too small on two puzzles per undersized page . I have n't had such an eye strain problem since someone once sent me a trash bag full of mixed up pieces from three 1000 - piece jigsaw puzzles . After two card tables and two days I made it to the eye doctor , luckily without running into a tree or heavy traffic . This books puzzles , two to a page , have tiny boxes to hold the possible as well as final numbers and my crosscut lines . I do n't see light pencil lines well and use ink for all puzzles also avoids getting eraser dust on the breakfast toast . I tried two Sudoku puzzles , and each time everything went fuzzy from eyestrain after just a few minutes . The multi - grid Samurai puzzles , fun idea , have even tinier boxes and fuzzier out with a headache in five minutes flat . I bought this for the spiral binding to use at breakfast no need to hold down pages plus pen and toast . I can not recommend it for anyone with a tendency to eyestrain and am very disappointed about wasted time and money .

The funny side of being tormented in the Retail Profession ! I just reviewed another book about retail with negative results . that book only had 2 stars because it was boring and depressing . In contrast , Pretending You Care by Norman Feuti is a tongue in cheek take on working retail . He shows you the ins outs of working retail , letting you know that no matter what you do , you 're trapped . But he does it in a humorous way , sharing stories along that way that make you laugh . If you 're going to buy any book about retail , I would suggest this one . Norm also writes a comic called , of course , Retail . If you have ever been a retail employee , are currently a retail employee , or are thinking about becoming a retail employee are you insane ? ! then I suggest reading both the comic and this book . At least if you 're trapped in a job you hate , you can find ways to laugh about it !

Wait Until Then Is A Masterpiece For Children About Heaven . Definitely my favorite Tyndale read this year , Randy Alcorn 's " Wait Until Then " supersedes all other books for children on the subject of Heaven . Perfectly written , in easy to understand fashion and it has beautiful illustrations . This sweet book explores the promises of Heaven , finding positive meaning in our trials and what happens when we die . These in depth subjects are presented in such a tender way through the story of a Grandfather " Gramps " who has cancer and his beloved grandson " Nathan " who struggles with spinal bifid . In true Randy Alcorn style , the best selling author offers a ray of hope and joy to his readers . Always backed by scripture , this book of only 32 pages offers numerous uplifting spiritual lessons . I highly recommend this book to anyone facing a giant in their life to gain perspective and courage . Excellent Read !

Good story but really needs editing help ! This was actually a good light paranormal murder mystery and I liked the characters and story line which kept me reading despite the writing problems . The reason for the 3 stars is that this author has written quite a few books but has done nothing about the bad editing . The constant use of misused words balling vs bawling , shuttered vs shuddered , passed vs past and many more was a problem through the whole story . The writing was also a mixture of third person and present tense which was very confusing at times . It seems the ARC reviewers did n't notice or did n't want to bring to the authors'attention . If there is another in this series I will try but I sure hope something is done about this and the author gets help with using proper words the writing style mixture . There is a lot of potential of these being really good stories .

A waste of money . I am very new to SQL Server 2000 or any SQL Server for that matter , so I wanted a book that was robust , but was easy to follow . " Step by Step " seemed to be the way to go , but this book leaves MUCH to be desired . It is WAY too basic . I mean , the language SQL Server uses is called TRANSACT - SQL , but not ONCE in the book does she go over TRANSACTIONS ! She reiterated the same points over and over , and used WAY too many screen shots . I would say at least 70 of the book is comprised of useless screen shots . You get hardly any actual content at all . and best of all , the examples are VERY weak . I am a big fan of WROX books , since WROX books are very complete and can be used as a desk reference . This book , however , is unless the second you finish it . I recommend it ONLY to people who have never programmed ANYTHING before , and to those who do n't care about learning fundamentals like transactions . The entire contents of this book can be learned from a 30 minute reading of some of the MSDN documentation .

Sorry - this is not it . I got the book a year ago and read it then . I thought that this book is certainly not it - there is nothing to learn from it . Sorry . Cut and dried . Good story and lots of action to keep you occupied . Held back by some very soggy dialogue that often felt stilted , along with a step - by - step narrative style that becomes a little irritating . This reader prefers to work a few things out for herself , and much of the narrative , mostly in the first person , is of the " I did this , and then I did that " type with little emotion , and extraneous information on insignificant and uninteresting details of daily life . I prefer to discover characters by seeing how they react to the circumstances thrown at then . I guess it can be a fine line , but this story suffered because of it . Good plot and lots of twists and turns , and a satisfying resolution .

Waste of paper . I was assigned this book for my into to sociology class and I find it to be a lot of blustering with inaccurate information given the price . The book discusses the dualities of conflict and order in society , though you only need to read a few chapters in to realize the book is nearly completely biased to the conflict paradigm . They also like to reference themselves throughout the book but on certain " historical facts " and " observations " there are no citations as to where they obtained this erroneous information . Some of the claims the book makes are rather blatant and sometimes incorrect . My personal favorite was the political system in the United States is fair to everyone . Seriously ? If you have any knowledge of American history candor politics , I think you will be disgusted you wasted 122 . 00 to buy this .

If you 're the type of person that likes to read every single thought a character has , then this book is for you .

Not a Lad . Rowan Hood , OUTLAW GIRL OF SHERWOOD FOREST by Nancy SpringerWhen her mothers spell of protection ends suddenly , Rosemary finds their home burned and her mother killed . Rosemary runs to the forest to escape , disguised as a boy , taking the name Rowan . Sharing her food with large youth , an enchanter with music , she earns a boon from the aelfe and the lesson to use the gifts her mother gave her . She does so , finding water , herbs , friends and allies , and much adventure , in her search for Robin Hood . This is a delightful book , designated for Juvenile , but satisfying to this reluctant adult , so much so that I m ready for the next in the series LIONCLAW .

Mature or teenybopper ? Painful . That 's the first word that comes to mind when I think of this book . But mixing that with the " bull poop ie " and poorly written dialog made for young teens makes it seem like the authors are confused by their own work .

An excellent continuation of book two - the reader now sees . Magically Betrayed is the third book in the Hunted Witch Agency series . An excellent continuation of book two - the reader now sees Devon 's growth and development as she slowly comprehends what she is able to achieve with her magic . Gerard is always around to protect her and they are now a little more than friends . With a good supporting cast of secondary characters the story is fast paced and action packed - dramatic , intriguing , full of adventure , suspense and mystery there is never a dull moment . The reader is taken on a truly emotional roller coaster ride . At times sad but at times also humorous and entertaining it is a well written , arresting and compelling tale that always holds the reader 's attention . Gifted with a copy for an honest review . Highly recommended !

Specialized and weak on application . I find little to say about this book . It addresses the macro trends of its title , at a fairly broad and repetitive level . It has much less to offer in terms of the second part strategies for gaining competitive advantage . Just a few weeks after reading it , I genuinely ca n't recall a single instance of an insight that goes much beyond the obvious of the macro trends . That obvious includes impacts of economic growth , strains of future logistics and widespread inadequacies in existing infrastructures . Yes , agreed . The data the book offers is useful in framing the problem , but rarely gets concrete about such issues as cold storage facilities , transportation industry scale and coordination , costs , telecommunications . It 's all like discussing airline policy without mentioning airplanes .

Orphanage turned mental asylum . Maggie is constantly torn between her English father and French mother and in Quebec , the divide is huge . Maggie falls in love with a poor French boy and becomes pregnant at 15 . Her parents force her to give up Elodie for adoption . The book alternates between Elodie 's life in the orphanage , later turned into an asylum , and Maggie 's life . This was an interesting story , particularly how the orphanage was turned into a mental asylum and the orphans were labeled mentally incompetent - purely for money . My biggest problem with this book was the time transitions . Some of the chapters had dates , most did not . Most of the time I was left guessing how much time had passed , which was pretty frustrating .

Not your usual for dummies book . All of the for dummies books that I have read previously started by listing the huge variety of people that the book could help - I have found that to be an uplifting start to their books , and something I look forward to and enjoy . This one starts listing all the people it can not help and aiming itself at a very tight niche . Aside from anything else , it sold itself short . I do not fit that niche but found enough good content to make the book a worthwhile read . That said , the introduction is not the books only distancing from the brand 's history . All of the books I have read previously had humor , to a greater or lesser extent . Humor has always helped me to learn . So that was a style I truly appreciated . This book is not endowed with humor . It appears that the author was quite angry when he wrote this , and that shines through in the writing . So , whilst the good information in the book does make it worth reading , the writing style , and the noise in some chapters make it a real pain to read . I shall keep my notes , but will not be keeping this one as a reference resource .

Do n't start with this one . This book is another entry in the series featuring Dr. Bill Brocton , his assistant , Miranda , the coroner , Dr. Garcia and some other less important recurring characters . If you 're a fan of the series , you 'll enjoy this work . However , the first chapter contains some spoilers that give away the plot and ending of previous entries . In fact , a major thread in this story is a continuation of a previous one that 's common in series but too much history is given so it will make sense to newcomers . An editor with a sharper red pencil would have helped . Like previous books , this one pays homage to the history of Oak Ridge , the scientists who worked there and the secrets they kept . The action lags a bit from time to time , but then moves along elsewhere . There 's a second plot having to do with some legal and ethical gaps in the transplant industry that runs in parallel for so long is becomes a distraction . In this reviewer 's opinion , that plotline could and should have been the main story . If you 've read this review so far , it will seem disjointed to you , with several ideas running along at once . That 's intentional the book reads the same way .

Fantastic product for struggling readers . Hooked on Phonics Learn to Read is a truly excellent product . I have used Hooked on Phonics with my grandson at the kindergarten and first grade levels . Formerly a struggling reader , he has now completed the kinder and first grade programs and will be starting the and grade program shortly he is a first grader . The programs are carefully crafted in a step - by - step fashion that allows for consistent progress and success . I have provided extra motivation by allowing him to earn computer game time at the end of a lesson . He has also been allowed to earn small prizes from an inexpensive prize box as a performance reward . The story books that accompanied each grade level are very well written , often describing humorous events . My grandson and his younger sister both enjoy having the books read aloud as they laugh at the funny situations described in the plots . I recommend Hooked on Phonics Learn to Read for any parent who wants to help their child advance his or her reading skills candor who has a struggling reader who will benefit from this expertly formulated program .

Dated Fictionalized Account of Leopold Loeb 's " Thrill Killing " . Meyer Levin 's COMPULSION , written in 1956 , is a nonfiction novel based on the famous 1924 " thrill killing " committed by Nathan Leopold and Robert Loeb . So much has been written about this particular crime , it 's hard for a " true crime " aficionado like myself to accept Levin 's portrayal of Leopold and Loeb as fictional characters as Judd and Artie , respectively with complicated thoughts as imagined by Levin that describe their motivations and feelings during and after the crime . The book reissued in modern format is very well written , but Levin 's 1950s style is wordy , resulting in a book that is 456 pages long . It tries the patience of a modern reader accustomed to " sound bites " and fast - reading thrillers . Because it is so speculative , and devotes so many pages to Judd 's and Artie 's not - very - convincing inner thoughts , COMPULSION does n't work for me . If I 'm going to read about Leopold and Loeb 's crime , I 'd much rather read a nonfiction account . I rate COMPULSION at 3 stars " It 's okay " on the official Amazon scale .

Really great start , loses it at the end . I really loved Generation A at the beginning - the story , narrated from five different points of view , about five young people stung by bees at a time in the future when all bees have disappeared from the earth , is quite funny and engaging . The characters are snakily funny and the course of events that lead to the disappearance of the bees and the then - current state of the planet are certainly believable enough . My main problem with this novel is that towards the end Coupland gets his characters together and has them engage in a Decameron - style storytelling extravaganza that was , for me at least , too much of a departure from the rest of the novel as to seem almost a lazy way to end the novel . The stories ultimately resolve the novel , but I think it would have been better had the narrative remained consistent - without the Decameron shortcut .

EUROPEAN TRAVEL JOURNAL PROVIDES GOOD INFORMATION HOWEVER IT IS 16 YEARS OLD AND HAS NOT BEEN UPDATED . The Journal is impressive with the information provided to a European Traveler . The currency exchange information is no longer accurate since most of Europe now uses the EURO except for a few countries . The imbedded 9 . 95 price on the back of this paperback book was confusing since I paid six times this price plus tax and shipping . When I questioned the Vendor about this price discrepancy I was told that there are few in circulation which commands a higher price and that the 9 . 95 was the price 16 years ago . There was no full disclosure in the description of the Journal as to why the 9 . 95 price was not in effect

After doing so much writing , maybe Brin wanted to depart from the linear narrative that one always expects , but this novel is so scattershot that you have no inkling where it is headed . Which would be fine if there were a satisfying revelation waiting to pull everything together . Alas the closest thing to that is the underwhelming conclusion that makes the reader question if the journey was worth it . On the plus side , there are many thoughts provoked along the way , mostly having to do with what'existence'really does consist of , but the narrative is poorly served by elements that the author reveals in the afterword were recycled from earlier writings , along with his'uplift'scenario . If its classic Brin you 're looking for I think you can afford to give this one a miss .

Probly A More Advanced " Take " Than I Was Looking For . First of all , I was anticipating this book would be more of an " picture " book , full of reproductions of women'surrealist artworks . " This " is not what the book turned out to be . Rather , it is more of a narrative discussion of the evolution of the woman 's movement , with a heavy emphasis on its relationship to the male surrealists . Artwork is included , but not to the extent I would have liked , and many of the pictures are not full - page retros . More importantly , though , is that the narrative content , despite having vague chapter headings , does n't really have a " logical " flow , nor does it always adhere to the purported topic of discussion . Also , unless you are already intimately familiar with the artists'styles and lives , it is often hard to appreciate the context of a particular reference as the author " dips in and out of " particular topics , and their illuminating examples . In fairness , I have to admit , I have only skimmed the book , and seriously doubt I will ever really read it . There do appear to be some good summaries of the development and specialties of individual artists that are interspersed throughout , tho , that I do hope to go back and read .

This book could only be enjoyed by a lonely , elderly person with lots of time to enter the personal life of someone else .

Started with a Bang , Ended with a Fizzel . I was very cautious when I began reading this book . There are sweeping claims made by Bell , and the reader is expected to take Bell 's word for them . There is some scriptural references , but not enough to substantiate Bell 's claims . I liked the tone , cadence and style of the writing . The claims of empire building in the church are not new to me , and I agree . What I did not like was the misplaced guilt trip and the secular humanistic qualities of the book . Loving and caring for the poor in this world , is NOT the focus of Jesus ministry or the Gospel , as Bell claims . It is certainly important to show Jesus love and care for humanity in practical ways , as almost every one who names the name of Christ does . This message of the arrival of the spiritual kingdom of God is the Gospel . NOT attempting to end the poverty of spirit by a radical demonstration of who Jesus is , yet seeking to implement some form of socialism is a misguided humanist line of thinking .

The Wonderful Story of Vivien Thomas , a black man during jim crow days who invented the surgery to save blue babies . A beginner 's basic guide . If you are just starting in macro , close up , IR or UV , this is your class 101 . It answers your questions , even those you do n't know to ask yet . It covers cameras , even some older cameras that you can buy cheap Nikon D40 and Nikon D70 that will work well in IR without being converted , you just need a filter . It 's coverage of filters is comprehensive . It defines filter terminology , such as band pass , cut on , cut off , hot mirror , et . It covers the gear you will need . It covers both the scientific and artistic aspects of this type of photography . The images illustrate the text and are not meant to be artistic or represent his best work . It is not a coffee - table book . His other book " Digital Ultraviolet and Infrared Photography " is for mature photographers , that is professionals working in the scientific , forensics , medical , et . field . This book,'Photographing the Unseen World " is your first book . You many never need another . I highly recommend this book . I could have saved a lot of money on buying how - to books had I had this book first .

An exquisite teacher but a disappointing book . As a 35 - year yoga practitioner I have , of course , been aware of Seane since she was a silent class member in the original Bryan Kest videos . I have deep respect for her exquisite physical awareness and attention to detail as a teacher . I personally find her energy a bit strident in yoga classes but know she has passion and sincerity , along with ample experience so I was very curious and had high hopes for enjoying this book . That being said , I ended up returning the book , which is something I have done maybe once or twice in my life . I found it an odd combination of vulgar , repetitive , self - conscious and just not very interesting . I wanted to enjoy it and pressed on but decided not to finish the book . There are too many gems out there and life is too precious to slog through a book you find clumsy and adolescent . This reads like transcripts of a blog , not a polished and confident memoir , and that is solely the responsibility of the editor and publisher . I still have infinite respect for Seane as a teacher but just do not recommend this book .

Once again , we see love is not all you need , especially when you are a parent . Rosie and Rex are somewhat star - crossed lovers , and their differences bring them together even while they keep them apart . While living in the blush of love , they bring two children into their marriage , and they do n't know how to keep it all together , despite desperately wanting to . I got very angry at these parents for keeping their mouths shut when they should be talking , being rigid when they should be bending , and not setting their feet down when that was absolutely required . This was a tearjerker , but it ends on a positive note . Even when we are n't quite sure how to love someone , if we are willing to be vulnerable , uncomfortable , and try though we 're sure it will cause us torture , we are all better for having walked openly through the pain .

Excellent , poignant book - you will learn much . SHall Suffer Death by A. J. Bannister is a book I highly recommend . Bannister 's case is examined in detail , his life in prison , and the realities of a death sentence upon the mental and emotional makeup of the condemned , their family and friends is explored . It is a touching book - a book which if read with an open heart and mind - can bring a reader to the realization of the humanity of all . AJ Bannister was executed in October , 1997 . It was , in my opinion , the vengeful killing of a dear brother in our human family . Had AJ been permitted to live , I believe his life would have continued to bless many . He was a good man . I urge persons who oppose the death penalty , as well as those who support it or are ambivalent about it to read this powerful personal account of a man sentenced to death .

Most of the questions revolve around the persons life , what brought them to Eucharistic Adoration , and how it has affected their life since , This is where I was disappointed I was looking for a book that Centered on Eucharistic Adoration , but this book centers more on the lives of the Interviewees . I think this book is best suited for those looking for light reading , and some conversion stories , maybe apologetics . Like I said , this is n't a bad book by any means , just not what I had in mind .

Dull and ponderous . The prose is lovely , but this book is maddeningly repetitive . The grandfather and grandson meander in circles through time , chasing women , drinking , and having fistfights . They are also very speedy travelers the only fast thing about this book , leaving Nebraska and arriving in Minnesota or New Mexico after a brief reminisce about a sexual encounter . Upon arrival , nothing much happens , and whichever character is doing the traveling conjure up some more sex memories and then is miraculously back where he started . The zillion layers of flashbacks are confusing . There is no plot , and the reader is merely kept hanging by the suspense of the grandson discovering his biological history . I blame the editor for not reducing the 446 pages to half that or fewer . Forcing the author to tighten up the stories would have greatly improved the flow of the book .

These recipes take their inspiration from cuisines around the globe including Mexico , Hawaii , China , Italy and the Mediterranean . And when it comes to stuffing , called dressing by some people , Los Angeles - based Mrs. Cubbison 's is the hands - down expert , being the first to merchandise convenient stuffing mix in the grocery aisle .

Well Written Fictional Portrayal of Early 20th Century Kidnapping . Andrew Hilleman 's " World , Chase Me Down " is an extremely well - written novel , based on the real - life kidnapping of the 16 - year old son of a wealthy Omaha meatpacking magnate in 1900 by Pat Crowe and his criminal partner Billy Cavenaugh . It 's told from Crowe 's perspective and largely in the form of flashbacks to the period surrounding the crime and the trial five years later , as well as a few glimpses into Crowe 's later days circa 70 years old . Hilleman is an evocative writer and does an excellent job portraying early 20th century Omaha , Nebraska and Crowe 's life on the lam . Pat Crowe - aside from one or two incidents - is a fairly likable criminal and it 's the flashbacks to 1900 that are the highlights of this novel . The trial bogs down a bit and is less entertaining than the rest of the book , but overall , this is an enjoyable and entertaining read , and an interesting fictionalized portrait of an early 20th Century crime and Omaha .

A parable with a fairytale interior , that went on too long and was ultimately disappointing . What - the - Dickens intrigued me because it 's a Gregory Maguire book ostensibly for children . Well , not really for children , but it 's a storytelling book . And it was . okay . But not the awesome I was hoping for . It 's a story within a story , of three scared kids caught in a big storm without their parents , and their cousin who tells a fairytale to calm them . It 's got some dry wit and an adult layer over the story , but it started to drag on a bit long for my tastes . Maybe I 'm just the wrong age group for it ? The entire point of the external narrative framework was to come to one conclusion , at the very end we all need hope and belief in something . But the story never concludes , and that got under my skin a bit . I do n't have much to say about this one . If you like whimsical stories that parody a sort of WWI - esque social mentality , you 'll probably get a kick out of it .

The title of this book should be Enjoy Continued Suffering on Your Spiritual Path . Few of the contained personal histories sound like they were written by self - realized people . There are few insights into the nature of life , or anything else important . Several of the histories focus on sexual pleasure , which , while of interest to some readers , is in my opinion utterly without spiritual value . Most of the histories celebrate personal flaws , claiming that the emergence of personal problems such as depression or anguish has a spiritual value . I would suggest that the rapid gaining of the full realization that we are pure awareness first , so that suffering ends , is what is of real spiritual interest . This book can help the reader evaluate the Waking Down in Mutuality process and organization . For me , it did not resonate . For you , it might .

Chaotic , inaccurate psych info poorly - stereotyped " autism " . Usually Armstrong 's novels have storyline that follow a fairly logical sequence of events , with at least some hints as to the " whodunit " if there is one and a clear conclusion . Watcher In The Woods , however , had so many tangential plot lines crammed that the story arc was almost buried in the chaos when the mystery was abruptly solved , it seemed to come out of left field . I 've read the previous three books , so I knew the backstory for each character , but without that knowledge I would 've been more than a little lost . I was also dismayed at the book 's wildly inaccurate claim that sociopaths have borderline personality disorder . Even worse was the painfully outdated stereotype - based depiction of autistic people as being robot - like science te ch geeks with absolutely no sense of humor , awareness of standard non - literal conversational phrases or social niceties , or ability to display more than faint flashes of emotion , and that the one thing they really need is for ne ur o typical s to constantly point out things they 're doing " wrong " rather than accepting that they 're different .

A Must - Read for Those Who Treasure Democracy . Barbara F. Walter has written a deeply - research book on the history of civil wars , focusing on the 20th century to the present . It 's a disturbing read but also enlightening as she shows how data can almost forecast civil wars the types of things that foment societal disturbances that lead to bloody uprisings . She also shows the various measures government can do to prevent or defuse civil wars , primarily through responsive actions to grievances and by being inclusive to all citizens . Walter warns of the dangers of social media and suggests that governments regulate teach companies . She delves into nationalism , factionalism , and political figures who try to divide a nation rather than unite all members for the common good of its citizens . This is a must - read for those who want to understand the polarization that has engulfed much of the world in the past 20 years . Walter offers hope but it 's something citizens and government officials are willing to work for .

What 's Reality Got To Do With It ? I 've found Maguire 's books to be somewhat uneven . I loved Confessions of an Ugly Stepsister and and Wicked . I liked Mirror Mirror . I 'm mostly confused by After Alice . I had a hard time getting into the book , as I was expecting Alice to be central to the story and had no idea who Ada might be . Once I got into the book , I found it to be a strange mixture of Wonderland and Oxford as Maguire moves back and forth among households and worlds . Eventually , all these seemingly disparate threads do come together as the delineations between reality and fantasy become increasingly blurred . The characters are interesting - especially Ada and Lydia - and it 's interesting to see how Wonderland and Oxford influence each other . You may remain a bit befuddled to the very end , but it 's a worthwhile experience .

Bored of the Rings . Look , there is one LOR and that should be enough . I do n't know about other SciFi readers but I 'm getting pretty tired of these long , long , long , trilogies that do little or nothing but set up the final chapter of the last book . What is going on here ? Something or someone or somewhat has managed to'turn off'parts of the laws of physics on Earth so that electricity , gunpowder , internal combustion , and so forth no longer work . Who ? How ? Why ? No matter , what counts is now people on Earth revert , for no apparent reason , to some sort of feudal society so that Stirling can write a long , long , long trilogy about swords , damsels , in distress , evil Overlords , et . , et . , et . I did not read the first in the trilogy , I picked up the second because I was traveling in Panama and it was all that was available , and I will not read the last segment because ENOUGH IS ENOUGH ! I actually think Stirling is a good writer and seems to know his way around a good plot . So why do yet another LOR ? Why not write something original and , hopefully , in less than 1500 pages ?

Flawed , although probably the best . My primary gripe is that the prompts in English are inconsistent and unnecessarily backwards , grammatically . For example , the announcer gives the following prompt in English " The coffee of that coffee shop is delicious " . Not only is that sentence grammatically awkward , it does n't match the grammar of the correct translation in Japanese . The correct response in Japanese is simply , " That coffee shop 's coffee is delicious " . There is no reason why the prompt can not match this . I really wish Pimsleur cleaned up these inconsistencies for a more productive and less frustrating learning experience .

It was a very good read - but the next one needs more Veronica , less Nancy Drew . If I had just been reading a mystery , I would have given this one 5 stars . It was well written , paced well , had the types of twists and turns I always like to see in a good mystery - all in all a well told story . But Veronica Mars in " real life " is not a wimp , and she came off pretty wimpy in this book . If I were to make a suggestion to the author , I would have suggested more time watching Veronica Mars - which is pretty ironic , I know . I will make one comment that is a minor spoiler , so if you you hate spoilers stop reading now - this just illustrates my point . The Veronica Mars from the movie who punched her former classmate in the mouth and said " Original enough for you ? " was not the book Veronica Mars who was afraid to go to the gun range . The Veronica Mars we all know and love would likely have had her concealed carry permit the day after her 18th birthday . So next book , more of the tough , cynical , sparky Veronica , and less of this wimpy Veronica .

Like a lot of phrase books , this one is not very good . The book has many phrases that I will never use , like this one under " social " I do n't mind watching , but I would rather not join in " . Or " where 's the local internet came ? " If you just ask " Internet ? " , someone will point you the right way . If you ask the entire sentence you will likely get a detailed response that you will not understand . Also , the word " claro " is not in the book , or at least I could n't find it . " Claro " is a very commonly used word in Mexico . Its literal meaning is " clear " but it is used as a catchall word that can mean " OK , sure , of course " . This problem is common in phrasebooks generally , not just this one . I 've also used LP 's Eastern Europe and Turkey phrasebooks and had similar problems . Note I 've used many LP country guidebooks and think they are very good .

A Disappointing Read Overall . An accident involving a car leaves a woman terribly injured , so it is up to her young daughter Hannah to give details . As it becomes increasingly apparent , there is something very abnormal about the entire situation . Can the authorities and medical personnel find out enough to get a true picture ? Dear Child had the elements of a good mystery thriller , but the resulting story was just words on pages for me . It felt like an outline that was thrown together with some connecting sentences and very little emotion . The author tried to direct the plot with certain twists , but did not unspool the truth in a way that built suspense . As a huge reader of mystery thrillers and suspense , I was disappointed in the overall novel , but especially the conclusion . For these reasons , I would not recommend Dear Child to other readers . Disclaimer I was given an Advanced Reader 's Copy of Dear Child by NetGalley and the publisher , Flatiron Books . The choice to review this book was entirely my own .

The Winter Soldier takes you on a Beautiful , Horrifying , Heartwarming and Heartbreaking Journey . Young Lucius is a medical student in Austria when World War I begins . This is the beginning of The Winter Soldier . Like most of my reviews , I will remind the reader that you will know quickly if you want to go on the journey with Lucius . Huge disappointment for this American . I purchased this collection to accompany me on a long automobile road trip . It was a waste of money , and I am giving it away . Here 's why . ALL of these short stories are narrated by Brits . What 's wrong with that ? I , as well as many other Americans , do not understand Brits very well when they are speaking . The words run together , the accents are different , and some words sound like they are mumbled . This , then , is exacerbated by background noise in a moving vehicle . I was not able to understand and enjoy even one story . If you have a hard time understanding Masterpiece Theater or Elementary on TV , then you will not enjoy this collection of short stories on CD .

Hugely disappointing - thin plot and tepid writing . I utterly love Harris 's Lecter books . The first three are the epitome of psychological suspense , and while HANNIBAL RISING suffers in comparison , it 's still a solid novel well worth reading . I ca n't say the same for CARI MORA , which might have worked better at novella length . The idea of getting a forbidden cache of gold under trying circumstances is as old as Harris 's beard , and he brings nothing new to it . The sadistic villain is a pale , charm - free copy of Lecter , and the climax comes as no surprise whatsoever . It 's a plodding book with plenty of padding , including snippets of research that apparently had to be featured , even when they were n't that important to the plot . I even winced at certain sentences that could have used a stronger editorial hand . Harris 's heart does n't seem at all to be in this one , but if you must , it 's an extremely fast read with its 308 pages of large type . A sad way to end an otherwise astonishing literary career .

A decent overall look at his life . This biography does a decent job of looking at the overall life of Grant . Other biographers have focused solely on his military career . And while this biography does a decent job , it is not detailed enough to do real justice to any part of his life , when compared to other biographies . Smiths description of Grants military career , does n't hold up at all compared to Catton 's work . The author stops every once in a while to make some snap analysis of what events mean , but fails to back it up as solidly as a good historian should . Overall this is n't a bad job as an into into Grants life , it 's just been done before by better historians and better writers . Read Grant 's autobiography , or Catton 's books on Grant .

Sweet Little Fantasy . The Castle in the Mist by Amy Ephron , read by Laraine Newman is a sweet magical story about two siblings living with their aunt during their school holidays . Tess and Max find an enchanted castle and befriend the boy that lives there named Will . However , all is not as it seems . The three children have a whimsical , fantastic adventure on the night of a full moon , a blood moon and a lunar eclipse that leave Tess and Max wondering what parts were real and what were imagined ! Throughout the story ran a theme of loss and longing , all three children missing a parent . This story had so many lovely elements but also left me with a lot of questions and wanting more . Perhaps the answers will come in the sequel , which I have yet to read . It was a fun , fast read .

A Whitman 's sampler of Beat writing . Oh dear , oh dear . Despite editor Seymour Krim 's spirited defense of the Beat movement in his introduction to this wide - ranging sampler stories , poems , essays , and excerpts of novels and dramatic works , what " The Beats " actually demonstrates is that most of these folks just could n't write very well . Granted , this stuff must have felt cathartic and even revolutionary at the time , and there 's validity to any kind of art - no matter how flawed - that shakes people out of their apathy , but as writing it simply does n't hold up . There are two pretty good stories'Double Feature'by Hubert Selby Jr. and'The Choice'by Anatole Broyard the rest of the fiction is a mess . It 's a testament to Krim 's perceptiveness that he included a piece called'The Know - Nothing Bohemians'by neoconservative essayist Norman Podhoretz . While Podhoretz strikes an almost ludicrously antagonistic tone think Joe Friday lecturing a bunch of hapless hippie kids on " Dragnet " , he does have a point about Jack Kerouac 's disdain for clear expression , and Krim realized that .

A parable with a fairytale interior , that went on too long and was ultimately disappointing . What - the - Dickens intrigued me because it 's a Gregory Maguire book ostensibly for children . Well , not really for children , but it 's a storytelling book . And it was . okay . But not the awesome I was hoping for . It 's a story within a story , of three scared kids caught in a big storm without their parents , and their cousin who tells a fairytale to calm them . It 's got some dry wit and an adult layer over the story , but it started to drag on a bit long for my tastes . Maybe I 'm just the wrong age group for it ? The entire point of the external narrative framework was to come to one conclusion , at the very end we all need hope and belief in something . But the story never concludes , and that got under my skin a bit . I do n't have much to say about this one . If you like whimsical stories that parody a sort of WWI - esque social mentality , you 'll probably get a kick out of it .

Familiar themes with unlikeable characters . I really thought I would enjoy this book , but I just could not get in to the characters . In fairness to this author , I am a fan of Downton Abbey and had read " The American Heiress " a couple of months ago . At least the first third of the book felt like a second _ rate recap of those two tales . I did not like any of the characters the family was a bunch of sullen nitwits with no compassion for others , the staff were no more likable either . There were long descriptive passages between short snippets of dialogue , but the author still did n't manage to create any striking images in my mind . It felt like a good editor might have removed at least one - third of the book to improve it 's incredibly slow pace . The second two thirds of the book became more interesting than the first and introduced several new characters . The entire thing was very predictable and dull . I wo n't be looking for the next two books in the series . I would suggest reading " The American Heiress " and renting the first two seasons of Downton Abbey and just calling it a day .

One Totally " Un - Bear - able " Section . Surprised that no reviewer picked up the on the thread of minor low class characters making short appearances in the first two sections being fleshed out in the remaining sections . A street performance bear trainer , a domestic servant and the bear trainer 's brother are all given back stories . Problem is there 's no relationship between their behavior in the earlier stories and what comes later . And in the case of the interminable bear trainer story there 's no payoff at all , except seeing a bad situation go increasingly worse as the story proceeds . I get it that all these minor " u n see able s " have lives just as fraught with drama as their " betters , " but just making that point is not enough to make a good book . Have enjoyed Mukherjee 's previous work and am attracted to Indian novels in general , but this was a miss for me .

A bit dated . The book is probably fine if you 're just looking for ideas , but you 'll mostly see familiar styles what were architecturally edgy a few years back . The book had one unexpected effect - I found it truly sad to see a vintage neighborhood library converted into a single - family home . The room that was filled with reading tables now had one single dining table . I guess we 're supposed to be thrilled by all the space and light . In actuality , that room is too vast for a single table . A black and white photo of early library goers sitting on the steps brought another spasm acute nostalgia . The converted post office had a similar effect . Equally sad the outdoor balcony of a home converted from a religious edifice . There was no particular design concept . The idea was the new owner could dine al fresco surrounded by medieval - style religious artifacts .

A struggle . This is the type of book that your Literature professor would assign as reading material because the author has made every effort to provide a smoothy blended from a multitude of imagery . I struggled with the initial chapters , slogging my way through the excessive use of stereotype , putting it down in disgust for days at a time . I found that the later chapters were easier to read and even evoked some sympathy for the characters , but ultimately I find I was just relieved to be done with the book . I have to agree with another reviewer that this was the author 's attempt to create'Literature'with a capital'L ' . Once past the initial chapters that author takes a few steps away from the standard archetypes for soldiers and actually develops the main characters , though it occasionally feels a little forced as the story is retold through each character 's eyes . Ultimately , I can not recommend this book . War is hell , but there are better stories , in my opinion , to get that point across ASIN0684803356 For Whom the Bell Tolls or ASINB0080R5B2 M All Quiet on the Western Front .

Grammar anyone ? I used this textbook for a late - start community college course . What bothers me the most about this textbook are the numerous grammatical mistakes and incomprehensible sentences that occur throughout the text . One in front of me right now pg 395 discusses " payments to Philippine customers officials " . I 'm guessing this should have been " custom officials " ? While I do n't pretend to have perfect grammar myself , I often find my concentration broken by syntax errors in the text . As other reviewers have also mentioned , the chapters seem overly - long and dry and the text is entirely black and white with no colors or pictures . What also stands out are certain organizational issues , which include certain topics popping up every chapter rather than just having one chapter address the subject . Another issue is the authors citing academic research without providing enough context such as not even providing the scholar 's first name . I also take issue with their over - reliance on the ethical models of Rest and Kohlberg while only giving token acknowledgement to criticisms of these models .

The book was of no value to me . I really was n't expecting it to be that helpful , but it was even less thorough than I anticipated . I have a modest Ed . Wusthof collection going back to a few 1814 - 1895 knives , several 1895 - 1920 's , and then pre - WWII to present , roughly 100 knives total . The books coverage however , is abysmal . There are three pages on Anton Wingen , for example , that was in business 1888 - 1993 . For Ed . Wusthof , a company that is family owned for over 200 years , from 1814 to present day , there 's 34 of a page . That meager listing leaves out the 2 earliest company marks . With even my limited knowledge , I could list several pages of maker 's marks for the company , with approximate year ranges , designs , and materials . I wo n't try to return it because the seller did his job with speedy delivery , and there are no promises in the description as to what it will do for me . I 'm commenting just to warn other users to check it out a little more carefully , it 's far from a'bible'of German cutlery .

Disappointing and repetitive novel . I did not finish this book . It was very repetitive and uninteresting . While I was looking forward to reading about Catherine of Aragon - books about Henry VIII typically focus on Anne Boleyn and ignore Catherine 's motivations - the execution was poor . First , there were significant implausibilities in the portrayal of King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella of Spain . Gregory portrays them as rather open minded and solicitous of Islamic practices . Catherine is portrayed as very appreciative of the Muslim legacy of Spain . This is absolutely ridiculous , considering the fact that Ferdinand and Isabella were brutal religious fanatics who sparked the infamous Spanish inquisition . Second , Gregory portrays the relationship between Catherine and Henry VIII 's older brother , Prince Arthur as a love affair . I suppose it is possible , but very unlikely in that time period . Gregory 's purpose , of course , is the key premise of this book - that Catherine of Aragon lied when she said that her marriage to Arthur was not consummated , which means that her marriage to Henry was unlawful under church law . However , the efforts to make this point are rather forced - the romance between Arthur and Catherine reads like a nauseating dime store romance
