Excellent Overview . If you 're a relative beginner who wants to know the whole sweep of the Big Bang story in one big bite , this book is for you . Well written , easy to follow , lots of illuminating examples , hits all the highlights . Singh is a very good teacher . I 'm no novice , and I learned quite a bit myself . There are , however , a few minor errors . For example , on p. 171 , Singh notes that in 1789 William Herschel constructed a 1 . 2 meter telescope , the world 's largest in aperture at the time , but that it was so unwieldy he abandoned it in 1815 " and thereafter used a more moderate telescope for most of his observing , with a 0 . 475 - metere aperture . " Actually , the smaller scope was built in 1783 , and it was always the one that Herschel used for most of his observing , even after the larger one was built . On the next page is an illustration of Herschel 's favorite scope , the 0 . 475 - meter , but Singh labels it the 1 . 2 meter . Again , a minor mixup , which detracts little from the book 's overall worth . Well worth the read .

Not so secret info in here . I got this thinking it would be stuff that people learn after much trial and error . you know , " trade secrets " , like the title . chef a likeable guy . The fat chef is a likeable fellow , and you want his romance to pan out because he has the best intentions . However , although a sweet story , it is not truly believable . If you 're looking for an enjoyable read about likeable folks during a difficult time Germans in France during WWII , you will enjoy this book . If you 're looking for a gritty WWII drama about the brave underground getting back at the Germans , you 'll be disappointed . Yes , it deals with the underground , the Germans are arrogant and cruel , and nice people are imprisoned and tortured . But not'on screen'so - to - speak . Yes , the chef does something horrible to the nasty German , but it 's only implied , never spelled out . I 've found Nath 's books to be enjoyable reads about nice people in bad times , but white washed so that you do n't have to suffer , see the blood and guts so vividly detailed in many modern books and movies .

Better than the movie but . Crazy , Rich , Asians is a fun , easy , read . The problem is Rachel is n't a very likeable character . She 's less a victim here than the movie but it 's hard to sympathize with her . Sure she gets treated badly , but she does n't fight back , she let 's everyone around her do it for her instead . The same can be said for Astrid . She 's this impeccable woman , rich beyond compare , but prefers to whine and suffer for a man who clearly is n't interested . Astrid also gets saved by a Knight in shining armour . I did like how the author mixed , mandarin , Cantonese , et . words into the dialogue and let the readers know what they meant . The book is a fun escape in to a world so far removed from most everyone , so if you do need an escape from being cooped up and cold , as long as you do n't expect much depth , you 'll enjoy Crazy , Rich , Asians .

Not the quality I hoped for . I 've purchased several adult coloring books recently from different places . I was sad to discover though that the paper is very cheap quality and the marker crayola washable fine - tips bleeds easily through the page and that the marker actually runs a bit on the paper . Then as I flipped through the pages I discovered that ever other page was a rather plain , generic looking pattern that really was n't what I had hoped for for the 8 - 9 I spent for the book ! I 'm considering requesting a return and finding a book for my friend elsewhere . This was n't the treat I was expecting .

Bitter Blather . While the work is verbose and literary , it is annoyingly simple and repetitive . The juiciest parts of the book are the near - sci - fi bursts of Idiocracy , where social media has warped everyone into imbecilic attention - whore children . Eventually , this same set of jokes and satire grow stale by books end . The heart of the plot concerns a pair of unlikely lovers navigating their turbulent relationship with each other . The lack of imagination and odd circumstances to this meandering affair can be attributed to this story being largely modeled after the writers own love life in this semi autobiographical tale . The observations and humor simply grow tired by story end , offering nothing new by the end that had n't been ruthlessly flogged earlier in the book . Much like a nouveau Philip Roth , this book is filled with suppressed rage , pseudo - academia and sexual frustration which dominates the narrators black and bitter perspective .

Too detailed for casual use . Although this is actually a very good guide , with great detail , it will be useless to us as casual visitors to Madeira . It is actually so detailed that it is hard to figure out where and how to do casual king . It seems very hard to even get oriented . It may make more sense once we are there , but I would have liked maps that provided a better sense of orientation . If we lived there , or had several weeks , this would be much more useful .

Better to make a graceful exit . Better to make a graceful exit off into the sunset of your literary career . Than to persist doggedly in the absence of all inspiration , and the apparently absolute desertion of your muse . The reviews crying mediocrity , lack of originality , continuity , consistency , and most devastating of all , inspiration , are tragically , true . I am saddened beyond words . I waited through two Lost Lord novels to do a review , hoping there would be a miraculous improvement . after all , everyone has a bad day once in awhile . Alas . This does n't look good for MJP 's literary future , or for her devoted fans . My disappointment is deep and my chagrin is vast . I ask , as so many others have - who wrote this ? What have you done with our Mary Jo ? I am absolutely perplexed . mystified . Is the MJP of old gone . forever ? There 's just nothing in this series so far , and I , for one , will go no further to redeem this previously gifted writer . How sad .

Exciting but . The great thing about this book is the way it keeps you moving and interested from page to page . Unneeded sequel to capitalize on movie success . An unfortunate dull sequel to such a great first novel . So much of the focus is on the philosophical differences between the family members that it overshadows all horror or thriller elements . It read almost like a domestic slice of life with a post - apocalyptic backdrop . All of the action happens in the last 15 of the book and multiple lines are wrapped up quickly with near immediate major characteristic changes and actions that are not followed through with natural consequences By the time the action starts I had mostly checked out . Also there are major plot holes that made the main conflict make no sense .

How Much is Grace ? This book does n't quite feel authentic . Grace is either a struggling writer with a ringer doing the real writing or she did n't really do much in the way of piecing this book together beyond babbling stories into a tape recorder and turning it over to " THE REAL WRITER " . Either way the book is partially entertaining . But the second half of GS 's career when she took a back seat to the miserable helium mouth Mickey Thomas was awful . I still detest songs like " Sara " and " We Built this City " both reflected the worst aspects of pap radio in the 80s . But during Grace 's early career - The " White Rabbit " phase she was without peer as a female singer stylist . I loved her . So I quit reading the book when she sequel into the awful Jefferson Starship part of her career . I hope she made a lot of money because the music reeked . So if you pick this book up , even if like me you do n't really think Grace wrote much of it , the stories are reflective and funny .

Surprisingly disappointing . This is a sequential followup to The Last Emperor , and given the excellence of its predecessor , a really poor sequel . Extraordinairement dcevant ! I have loved most of Ms Penny 's Gamache series , but this was just horrid . I agree with many of the other negative reviews boring , one dimensional characters , contrived . I only completed it because I wanted to know if Peter was found or not . Although I must say , I 've never been really fond of either Clara or Peter 's characters . The use of asbestos as a murder weapon was almost laughable . The ending was abhorrent . Ms Penny 's other books are so artful , the prose , brilliant . Wasted my time and my money - the only redeeming factor of this novel was getting to listen to Ralph Cosham one last time . His voice will be dearly missed . Rest in peace , good man . Let 's hope the same fate has come to Gamache should he appear in another novel as bad as this one .

Chilling Story , Book Too Wordy . Came across this one due to interviews the author gave . The story is impactful - I find the sickest part of it not Cullen 's behavior , but the hospitals'responses . If you 're a true - crime buff and have not read the Cullen story yet , you 'll find it a meaty one . However . Many times , the book devolves into overly - flowery descriptions of environments or irrelevant backstory . I do n't need two paragraphs talking about trees , or three paragraphs musing about unrelated character motivations . I wound up skipping chunks of pages over over as a result . Otherwise I could have just stopped reading due to boredom . It felt like the author shoved excess text in to meet some wordage count . Serious weakness to the story .

Incredibly silly amazingly bad . butterwort is the same guy who writes under the pseudonym of WEB Griffin , and has several series of military adventure books out under that name . I ve generally found those books to be enjoyable , though somewhat light , fare . On the strength of that association , when I saw this book in the store and read the flyleaf , I thought I d give it a read . I wish I d saved my money . I m now on page 163 of the hardcovers 417 pages and just ca nt force myself to continue . I have no idea what Butterworth was trying to do here . Was he going for another MASH of which he was supposedly one of the coauthors or Catch-22 ? " Being There ? " A satire ? A comedy ? What ? This is just a nonsensical story , utterly absurd , told in a breathless and juvenile fashion , chockfull of inanities and anachronisms . If this had been written by an unknown author I think it would have collected a drawer - full of rejection notices from publishing houses and disappeared out of existence completely unread by anyone other than the author and whatever family members he imposed it on . Buy something else .

Gives pretty basic advice and is outdated . For anyone in a current LDR and is the tiniest bit teach savvy or has a smart phone , this book is outdated . Clearly this book was published before Skype and testing was common , which makes the suggestions on using technology almost humorous . My long distance boyfriend and I were already doing all of the things suggested to keep intimacy alive , to keep each other involved in each others lives while we are living on opposite coasts . There also seems to be a more conservative theme to this book , which is fine since it is n't overwhelming . It is nice as the authors did interview long distance couples that made it work , and those that did n't . A quick and easy read that may help bring hope back into a LDR that is experiencing some trouble . But really , the best advice they give in the entire book is communication is key .

Wanted this to work so bad . I had a horrible time getting this book to work . The first two pages refused to work no matter what I did . So I got a new one . That one did the same thing . I finally got a third one and that one worked if I went under a very bright light . It took me 2 weeks to figure out the book needed a brightly lit room to work well . However , when I recorded the fourth page it registered that as the third page and erased the previous page I had just done . This book was so frustrating that I almost sent it back and just gave up . However , after 3 weeks of working with it , I finally got it recorded " good enough . " The book however is not worth the time and frustration . Too bad . Such a great idea if it worked correctly !

Read Mountain Climbing for Dummies first . If you know your mountain climbing terminology , things like couloir , seracs , cornices , bini , fluting , abseiling and saddles , then this may be the book for you , since they are strewn throughout without definition otherwise , " Mountain Climbing for Dummies " is required reading before even attempting this . I was lost in a blizzard of foreign jargon . Then , every step of the journey is described in monotonous , dull detail . 13 of the book leads up to the accident . I found " Into Thin Air " to be a much superior offering in mountain disaster stories for a layman .

I need to reread this one . Authority by Jeff Vandermeer is the second book in The Southern Reach Trilogy . In this book , we get a look at the system that sends people into Area X. I really enjoyed that we followed a fresh face at the government agency who was learning more about Area X and the team , which allowed the reader to learn more as well . It was really interesting to see things through Controls eyes . He started out curious , but things slowly started to spiral out of control . There was one scene that really creeper me out ! That scene alone added another star to my overall review ! However , just like the first book , this one was still a bit confusing . There were many instances where I had to stop , turn back a page , a reread . This one also seemed to ramble a bit to me . I think if things had been tightened up a bit , I would have enjoyed it more . While I did n't really love this one , I m still really glad I read it . I definitely want to continue on to the third book , and I still want to reread to see if this is one of those cases where I enjoy it more the second time around .

Awkward language . I have a masters degree in engineering so I do understand geometry . I found the language used in describing the spine tilt to be awkward . However , I read the book again to clarify the ideas presented . I found that I hit the ball further and more consistently using this swing method . The traditional pro swing , wherein the weight shifts from one foot to the other , requires precise timing of body movements . Even though the pro player constantly practices , even they play inconsistently from week to week . For the amateur , this stack and tilt method is less demanding of timing precision and allows for more consistent contact with the ball . The method has certainly improved my ball striking . Buy the book it 's worth the price . But read it over again as the language is torturous in my opinion .

A little disappointing . Do n't get me wrong , it 's a good book . My purpose in buying it was that I grew up in Pocatello and moved away as a young adult . In case Hammett 's original was not enough . Joe Gores was a good choice to write this prequel to ASIN0679722645 The Maltese Falcon His own ASIN0752851829 Hammett Crime Masterworksshowed he has a good grasp of the style and setting and he 's ale to ape Hammett 's prose pretty well . The real problem for me is that the book is basically three novellas that really only serve the purpose of setting up The Maltese Falcon , by themselves they really do n't have much purpose . Creating scenarios to put the main players in place , Effie , Miles , and Polhaus all make their obligatory appearances in a meandering group of mysteries with a central foe that seems a better fit for a contemporary action movie - a psychopath killer who also can plan complicated capers . It all seems a bit too much for what turns out to be novel with little suspense . Nothing can happen to the main characters and without that possibility , the story needs to exciting and involving . This does n't quite hit the mark . It 's not a total misfire , Gores is a good writer and he keeps things moving , but the end result remains just what you expect .

Painfully clumsy . This book seemed promising at the start . The plot is fairly fast - moving and obvious research has gone into the drug smuggling storyline . However . the Karen Vail character is fatally flawed , and not in a good way . This is a vehicle with a poorly - developed female character who is supposed to be a bad - ass FBI agent . I found the unfortunate conflicts in the development of her character to be very distracting to the story . It 's a problem sometimes found in female characters conceived by male authors . Sorry Alan Jacobson , you do n't " get " what makes strong women tick . Some examples of issues I had with the character . Karen has a child , but considers her own safety and the potential impact of danger on her child 's life in only a very superficial , passing way throughout the book . She is so concerned about her boyfriend 's well - being he 's been captured tortured that she has no appetite , but slurps down a chocolate milkshake for the sugar rush how stereotypical is that ? . I could go on and on , but why should I ? The book speaks for itself . I thought it would never end .

Must - Read 's are sometimes a hit miss . I read this book because I was never compelled to as required reading in school and because every list of modern classics had it as a " must - read " . I may be alone in this but I did not enjoy this book . in fact I forced myself to finish it . I believe had I read this book in my formative years I may have had another conclusion as the plot does not follow the formulaic nature of so many works of fiction . However , this was not my first venture into nontraditional plot lines so it did not have the same impact . I did enjoy the period nature of the story and the fact that one must appreciate that some of the defiant acts of Holden Caulfield were quite defiant for the day . Still , it was the overall brooding , pessimistic attitude of the plot that served as a turnoff for me . I suppose life is filled with enough to be pessimistic about that I did n't enjoy it as the premise of a book . In any case , I am glad that I read it , if only to say I read it however , I would n't anticipate placing it on my reread list of books any time soon .

Lacks major publishers terrible organization . This just is n't useful . If you want to sell , say , a mystery novel , you 'd like a list of publishers who accept mystery novels . Older editions of the WM had publishers listed by category , so you could go down the list of people who accept mystery novels . Now , that info is way in the back of the book , and you have to keep flipping back and forth thru the book , searching for the names in the index in the back . Easily takes 10 times as long . Also , most of the biggest publishers just are n't listed Random House , MacMillan , et . Nor are their imprints . Probably they did n't reply to the WM 's query because they do n't want submissions . But the WM should go down the list of the 30 top markets and find out whether they do , or not , and at least have an entry saying " Did not respond " so you do n't have to keep searching thru the book under all the different imprints , subsidiaries , previous names , and conglomerate owner for a publisher .

Not suitable for those who are n't practiced within this area of expertise . why I returned it . At 74 I have been studying origami especially modular designs by Michael La Fosse and thought this would be a perfect addition to my library . Unfortunately I returned this book because too much of the author expertise is assumed to be the level of the students trying to learn . Very complicated without clear illustrations that are understandable . I was so disappointed and desperately wanted to be able to learn her work , but this book is written or those who know this field and not for someone who lacks the skills she has . I worked with Nick Robinsons books and progressed and even understand Robert Langs work in part but this book does teach but assume with complicated and near impossible results . Books are to teach , and for me this clearly missed the target even though I wanted to be able to do this beautifully and magnificently executed models .

Eva died too soon . But this book has preserved . Eva died too soon . But this book has preserved everything we ever wanted to know about her from early childhood on . Her music is so mesmerizing that I wondered who she was , why she was n't more famous , why people had n't heard of her . The photography , the text , her family , friends . all these come together to provide a rich , penetrating look at the life of young woman who , had she lived longer , would have achieved the fame she richly deserves . The purity of her voice isunlike any other artist I 've ever known . Thankfully , through technology , is has been preserved for us just as this book has .

A compelling love story . This is an excellent book , which I 'd give " 4 . 5 stars " if that rating were available . It 's a fast - moving , very readable book which emphasizes Gettleman 's love of Africa and its people . It 's also a somewhat harrowing account of the dangers of journalism in far away places . Contrary to what one reader claims , " Love Africa " is not " dick lit " , a testosterone fueled account of the author 's love life . It is also not a racist rant , as a couple of other readers implied . Yes , Mr Gettleman was not always faithful to his fiance - but he 's honest about his mistakes , and he makes it plain that they were mistakes , very serious ones , for which he 's profoundly sorry . Yes , he uses a couple of racist - sounding phrases - but he uses them to point out that they are racist , and inappropriate . " Love Africa " is a story of love for another human , and a story of love for a continent , its nations , and its people . story are correct . Reading it made me want to return to Africa myself .

Not just for dogs . We are bunny owners , and I bought this book because our local shelter told us that clicker training can be a very effective tool for all pets . " Reaching the Animal Mind " is much more in - depth than I had thought it would be , and I found it to be a slightly challenging read . I personally wanted more of " this is how you train your animal " and less animal psychology , although the information is very worthwhile and extremely helpful and effective . The back of the book has an extensive glossary and appendix - the research is quite impressive . The use of positive reinforcement over negative punishment is such a breath of fresh air . This book would be helpful for any pet owner .

Earnest , but one - note . Sad to say , but this book turned out to be one of diminishing returns . Manguel is a clear lover of books and libraries , and he researched intriguing stories about various libraries , their development , their architecture , their necessity , their maps of the human mind . But just like another book I read a few years back that tried to address the joys and magic of reading and books , I found Manguel 's ideas interesting but not world - shifting . This book certainly deserves its praise , for his efforts are clearly heartfelt and thorough , but I must admit that I find the overall tone a little one - note . Thus , the trend of categories through which he studies the concept of the library as memory , as shadow , as shape , as oblivion less and less surprising and thus less and less engaging . Perhaps some left - turns and even more self - doubt or - criticism might have taken this into more compelling directions .

catalog of amazing capabilities . This is a good catalog of the surprisingly powerful features available in CSS3 , e. g. , a ad flying logo like TV stations had back in the 1980s . The book is organized by type of feature rather than by project or goal , so it is useful as a survey of what CSS3 can do and then useful as a reference . For a tutorial you 'd want something organized by project and example . I give the book four stars rather than five because there is n't much explanation for when or why you 'd want to use particular features . Also , the examples seem contrived rather than lifted from real style sheets .

Still on the fence about whether I 'm happy I read this or not . I 'm conflicted about this book . Have you ever finished a book and thought , " I 'm not sure I 'm glad I read that . " ? That 's how I was after reading this and I eventually decided to throw it in the donation bin . The thing about this book is that there a quite a few topics approached that I was really uncomfortable with . Oddly enough , SPOILER ALERT , murder was n't one of them . But , you know , incest was . Here 's what I wrote to my friend after I had finished and he asked me my thoughts " It was a sad story with no hope of a happy ending . Did n't know that till about half way through though and at that point there was no going back , I was sucked in . But some beautiful ideas , some stunning paragraphs and sentences that were thrown so casually in and without warning that you just kept reading , hoping you 'd be blindsided by another one . " This book had all the makings of a book I would really love . Bit of a thriller , Greek mythology and history , beautiful language , academia . Dragon of the Lost Sea . The dragon character in this book was one of the most unlikable characters I 've ever had the misfortune of reading . She is rude , thinks she knows more than anyone else , and is extremely childish . Yet , sometimes she likes humans and is surprised to find a nice one . Her mood swings from thankful to agitated in one paragraph . The boy is not much better . He is good to a fault , and is not bothered by anyone or anything . He takes his beatings in stride and does n't seem to mind getting rocks thrown at him . Characters aside , the book has little in the way of a plot . It is a straightforward adventure story which lacks a large amount of substance . There are certainly better children 's books out there .

Gone Girl . In the beginning I would have rated this a one star . I truly did and still , after completing the novel , do not like the characters who are neurotic and egocentric , to say the very least . The only likeable character , in my opinion , is Go . Perhaps that is what the author was wanting . Amy is evil . I suppose I do n't like how she can manipulate and control others as she does I want to see more courage and strength from those she considers adversaries . However , admittedly , she is dominant , bright and skilled at the evil she inflicts on others . I am disappointed that Nick , her husband , just when I thought he would be her equal , was outwitted and lost in the combat between him and his wife Amy . I may read another Flynn novel simply to compare the two , but if the characters depicted are similar to these , it will be the last .

One Star in the Universe . Billions and billions of stars in the universe but only one for this book . Why ? Because Carl Sagan was totally ignorant of the subatomic world and the possibility of mu lt i verses . He saw only one star in the sky , and its name was Sagan . He was a sophist who appealed mainly to a pop culture that looked for easy - to - digest science in support of its secular morality .

The parade that never ends ! I am hesitant to give this book 3 stars , but to be fair , the beginning was exciting and frightening . A world renown sculptor is kidnapping families and feeding them wholesome meals , forcing them to exercise until their bodies are taut and fit , then encases their bodies in amalgamate to make molds of their bodies that depict their suffering . He then casts the molds with bronze . He cleverly sculpts different heads onto the statues so they wo n't be identified . He is truly a monster . That was the premise of the story and the author did a great job conveying the horror these families went through . He did a excellent job depicting the madness necessary to perform such heinous acts against another human being . What he did n't do very well was end the book . The ending was rushed , stupid , and lacked imagination . The book is not a total waste of time , but there are too many great suspense novels out there to devote precious time to this one that just becomes phony and tiring in the end .

Tough book to enjoy . This is definitely not one of Slaughter 's usual great reads . At one point I felt like I was reading a tutorial on the court system . There were a few highlights but mostly this book was painfully slow , dull and at times pointless . As I was reading it I could not help but think that Slaughter wanted to write " outside the box " but struggled to do so with every chapter . Big disappointment !

Touring with Meg . Another " Oh , wow ! " book from the outstanding Amy Waeschle . What a delight to be drug around LA wondering if I 'm going to end up dead for hanging to close with LA Times writer Meg Dawson . We made it though and now Meg is about to set off to the great PNW to solve murders and mysteries in Seattle . By the time I finished reading this book I wondered if there was anyone who could be trusted . Is it possible the whole world is dirty ? It 's not quite that bad folks but you do need to be on your toes . It 's really sad that so many people can be so futzed up . It 's enough to make one wonder if Meg will ever trust anyone again . One thing that is to be appreciated is Meg 's surroundings . The scenery , especially the beaches , in Los Angeles is outstanding . The power of the natural world to allow her to recover from trying times ca n't be denied . The strength she demonstrates to persevere is incredible . She does n't give up , run away , or wimp out , ever . All of this is achieved without a lover . I voluntarily reviewed an Advance Reader Copy of this book

To much of an origin shift . Wonder Woman has been given an insane number of comics this year , and I wanted to check out this one . Unfortunately , it did n't live up to the hype . Jill Thompson 's take on Wonderwoman features some amazing artwork , and I do like the core idea of this series . In this book , the Amazon 's are regretful that they ca n't have any more children . Because Diana ends up being the only child on the island , the rest of the Amazon 's spoil her rotten . It 's not a particularly unlikely direction to take . But unfortunately , Thompson kept Diana as a brat well into adult , and filled the entire book with it . As a result , Wonder Woman becomes who she is not out of a sense of adventure or wanting to protect the world , but out of redemption . It 's incredibly frustrating to read WW 's origin story twisted in such a way .

A fun read . I 'm a fan of Lindsey Davis , Saylor , and Maddox Roberts . I 've picked up a lot of Roman history from reading their mysteries . And , a recent visit to Rome to view archeological sites gave me a good feel for the streets and houses , forums and temples , that these authors describe . I did enjoy this mystery although it 's not as well written as the Falco stories . Flavia seems too modern in attitude to be believable as a daughter of a Roman citizen . The plot is okay , but not exciting and puts no demands on the reader . The history on which the story is based is interesting however , and the festival scenes are amusing . I look forward to reading the future adventures of Flavia .

Depressing Book . Perhaps depression is the point of this book . In that case , it probably deserves 5 stars instead of the 2 I 'm giving . It does that very well . The stories are about people getting divorced , committing infidelities , sleeping with married people , drinking excessively , dying , and otherwise going through down times . One happy woman knows her husband cheats on her , but just does n't care . She 's about the happiest of the characters . She turns down the sexual advance of another woman . This reminds me a lot of literature I read while working toward my degree in English . At times , it got to me . This book did , too .

Good book , Bad Story . This is a " true crime " book full of people so naive , manipulated , and convoluted that no one could possibly make up this story . The morning after Christmas 1997 in Bremerton , WA , a young pastor 's wife was found burned to death in her home . Her death was ruled accidental however , years later it was discovered she was dead before the fire started . Meantime , her " grieving " husband manipulated the women of his congregation into " loving " him in his grief because , after all , he had a direct line to God , and God knew what was best for everyone . I still find it hard to imagine people who blindly follow someone who tells them what they should think and believe yet it happens all the time . Olsen 's account is well - written , but the story itself is absolutely disgusting , especially since it is true !

Leaves you hungry not for more but as though you never ate . This book is on a short list of books that I not only did not finish but threw away as to not pass onto someone else . When one of the characters who was away from his family compared his attachment to his wife and new child as three people sharing an umbilical cord , I felt reader doom early on and should have stopped reading . Simply put , the cover is better than the story . It seems made up rather than real , historically accurate and interesting . I know it 's not historically accurate but it should at least pretend as such . You do n't get to really know and care about most of the characters . Too much " tell " rather than " show . " Rollins likes to use branded products in his writing instead of showing what is going on or the objects used and why they matter . While I wanted to finish reading this story because I 've invested half of a book in it , I ca n't finish it . Maybe his other stuff is better . I probably wo n't read him again .

Obnoxious . Max is the typical woman with a man 's name . An accomplished journalist committed to solving cold cases , she is a tough talking beauty who excuses her rudeness , obstinacy and other flaws under the guise of an unflagging commitment to truth . She returns to the posh town of her wealthy family to attend the funeral of her " best friend " , a man who may have committed suicide . Over a decade earlier , he stood trial for the murder of a young woman who coincidentally was also Max 's bessie , but was never convicted . At the same time she becomes involved in the investigation of the seemingly unrelated murder of a young man whose grandparents approached her at the airport . These investigations of course put her at odds with her already estranged family , Nick , the hot detective and David , her fierce but caring bodyguard . The story was predictable and not hard to figure out quite early on . There are too many inconsequential characters . While Nick and David have charm , Max is just obnoxious . Her arrogance and stubbornness put Nancy Grace to shame . Although not a complicated read , it is long and the unlikeable heroine made it seem even longer . Pass .

Lacking . I own a BGE and am a fan of Ray Lampe . In fact he even lives in my town so I was excited about reading this book . However I found much of the information lacking and or inaccurate . Perhaps I missed it but there are several pizza recipes but no instructions on how to heat the egg to very high temperature required to cook them . He uses the fire starters to light the charcoal but these have chemicals . I , and many other " eggheads " have found the stovepipe lighter works best . He says when you are done cooking to close all vents and let the egg cool down . This is indeed the company 's recommendations . However living in semitropical and ultra - humid Florida , I found doing so produced mold and mildew on the grate , inside cover and firebox . So I do the opposite open the vents wide and burn every thing done . Finally he talks about the con v EGGtor without showing what it is . Thus there are inattention to details and misinformation . I am very disappointed .

Started out liking it well enough . . . I started out liking it well enough but . Perhaps it is the fact that China is at least nominally atheist , and likely has been for the author 's entire life , but it seems that she gets some things wrong about Buddhism . On the other hand , I 'm Theravada , not Chan , so she could be right about rural beliefs and practices in China . I do know dogs , though , and quickly became impatient with her attempts to write from the dogs'points of view . Again , the difference between suburban middle class America and rural anywhere , but the characters'neglect of the dogs incensed me , made it hard to stay in the story . An award - winning writer , she never puts a foot wrong there , with flawless rendering of her Chinese characters not so much the white guys and lyrical scene - setting . Just not my cup of tea . Maybe it will be yours ?

Great history of the Baptists in America . This is a really good book and it is a book that was needed . While the author does cherry pick the history he chooses to write about , he chooses well all historians do this to one degree or another . This book presents another view from the popular view regarding American history . Popular history revolves around secular history candor perhaps around the Covenant theologists . This is a must read for any independent , fundamental Baptist . Southern Baptists would likely enjoy it as well . Perhaps even the spinoff brethren - the Church of Christers would get something out of it . Would n't it be great if people would spend more time studying true history and carefully filtering every thought and deed through the Bible . Perhaps some folk would see the errors of their wayward theology and would repent and make the necessary changes within their denominations or leave their assembly for a pure local church . This book tells of the suffering and death that was brought to so many of our forefathers so that we might have a pure theology .

Lacks major publishers terrible organization . This just is n't useful . If you want to sell , say , a mystery novel , you 'd like a list of publishers who accept mystery novels . Older editions of the WM had publishers listed by category , so you could go down the list of people who accept mystery novels . Now , that info is way in the back of the book , and you have to keep flipping back and forth thru the book , searching for the names in the index in the back . Easily takes 10 times as long . Also , most of the biggest publishers just are n't listed Random House , MacMillan , et . Nor are their imprints . Probably they did n't reply to the WM 's query because they do n't want submissions . But the WM should go down the list of the 30 top markets and find out whether they do , or not , and at least have an entry saying " Did not respond " so you do n't have to keep searching thru the book under all the different imprints , subsidiaries , previous names , and conglomerate owner for a publisher .

Strangest book I 've ever read ! While the author sounds like just the nicest person in the world , this book was certainly not my favorite . If it had stuck to one story and brought real depth to the characters , it could have been interesting . But every character seemed so unbelievable to me . I 've not met anyone who would respond to life events in the manner these characters did . Not believable at all ! And the whole female impersonator thing was so confusing . By calling a man , she , you never knew for sure who they were talking about and who was speaking . I did not think those characters were very well developed . But the biggest thing that was jarring to me , was Holly , whom adored the kids next door , but with almost a blink of an eye , seemed to put them out of her life and she rarely seemed to interact with them after that . That defies normal behavior . I just found it a rather strange book . Having said that , it did hold my interest enough to want to know how it ended . So I 'll give her that . But I ca n't honestly say I would spend my money on another book written by this author .

McDonald book 's , would just be another adventure for the same character . Wrong . The time span between the 2 book 's , is roughly 18 month 's and it 's almost as if the author did n't like the protagonist , he created in book 1 , so he decided to create a whole new personality for Alec , in book 2 . Do n't get me wrong , the and is just as good as the st but be ready to accept a totally redone detective . It 's worth reading , so I hope you enjoy . Susan Nussbaum 's " Good Kings Bad Kings A Novel " is one of those books . Susan Nussbaum 's " Good Kings Bad Kings A Novel " is one of those books that if you do n't pay attention to you 'll get lost in a plot that 's simple yet also overtly complicated for no real reason . The story alternates perspectives between Yessenia , Teddy , Mia Joanne across all aspects of life from rape to foster care to just about everything in between . It is these shifting perspectives stories that while at times help the book also hurt it since it 's very easy to get lost in the plot . The characters I want to care about could be anyone of us , but at times are so thinly written that I as a reader stopped caring about partway through . Granted there are some shock value moments from Teddy 's death to Mia 's rape but it all seems so forced at times that it does n't work . A very disappointing book that I had far higher hopes for .

The myth and idea of the Count have staying power , but the novel is as dull as dirt . I know all the critical reasons for its popularity , but all of these strike me as very strained .

I wanted to like it more . I wanted to like this more than I did . It 's a good idea but the coming - of - age part of Alan a Dale was a bit tedious at times . When it was found , said enemy ran away , thereby making everyone think he was the thief . However , Alan was known as a thief and known to have seen where the jewel was hidden and known to hate his enemy . Surely someone would have put two and two together , especially since the enemy was the son of the woman who lost the jewel ! Too pat . Robin Hood was nicely nuanced as someone who had to control a group of people and not just a goody two - shoes . But some of his doings went a bit far , though I liked that he rejected religion . Incredibly bad English text makes enjoying this good book very difficult . It seemed to me that this book was not written in English , but translated from some other language . Or else , the services of an editor were dispensed with . Not only are there misspellings everywhere and typographical errors galore , but there are phrases that do not occur in English on almost every page . " He was stood up , " means " He stood up . " It is very hard to read something where words do not fit , and phrases are plainly wrong . That said , it is an interesting mystery , well described , and the characters actually have personalities . A good tale . Did I mention that commas appear where they should n't and do n't appear where they should ? Some sentences have to be read twice in order to make sense of them . It is a good mystery .

Very pretty patterns and some very useful techniques . That said , Folk Bags is still a keeper for me , and I 'm very glad I purchased it . Aside from the stranded color knitting which I do like , some of the projects are so interesting that I may actually take down my guard and try my hand at seaming up a few . The author 's inclusion of two particular techniques used in the bags - working entrelac flat , while joining the ends in a tube as you knit , and embellishing with a crochet needle instead of traditional embroidery - set this book apart from others of its kind for me .

Beware the date of this book , written before serious fraud in evidence collection and analysis was proven to be fabricated . Disregard the stars - I have n't read this book and I 'm not rating the book , I 'm writing to alert readers of it to pay attention to its being written in 2005 . I just finished watching the updated , complete 13 chapters of new documentary , and when I see a book about the case written in 2005 , it seems important that any readers of this book know the evidence presented in court in 2003 and on which the trial 's verdict was based was proven in 2011 to be completely tainted by a prosecution " expert " named Deaver who fabricated and lied both about himself as expert and the blood and other evidence in this case . He based his claims and his theory of Michael 's guilt on supposed " lab experiments " that were completely invalid and unreliable , preposterous violations of even the concept of " experiment . " So whatever this book persuades a reader to believe , it by definition has to be based at least in very large part on'evidence'as of 2005 that is no longer valid evidence .

Not recommended for the novice glass collector . Unless you are familiar with the Fostoria line , this is not the book for you . As a collector who is just acquainting herself with glass , the arrival of this book is met with great disappointment . Most pieces are unmarked , so a good reference to the patterns and color shades is valuable . Of the 240 pages , only 48 contain color pictures . The majority of the patterns are represented by black and white catalog clippings and silhouette line drawings . Some patterns have no visual representation at all . There is also a small section dedicated to reproductions with the warning that no value can be given to reproduced items . However , there are no tips on how to spot a reproduction . Perhaps those already familiar with the patterns would find this a valuable tool , as the listings of pieces in each pattern appear to be complete and the patterns are sensibly listed in alphabetical order .
Wonderful book . Excellent seller and great product

Level Zero my Ass . This was a pretty damn good book and was well worth the wait as I had pre - ordered it about 8 months ago . The book is well written and for those like me who ca n't stand editing errors , this book had none , at least that I caught . The author focuses more on the brave acts of others , regardless of service and every account of bravado is countered by at least one account of utter terror , exactly as I would think armed combat would be like . It follows along with a MARSOC JTAC SSGT and his fellow Marines and a cast of characters that defy belief to all but those that have lived the nightmare that is apparently Afghanistan . My only complaint is that it was too short , unless he 's planning on another book please , I beseech you in the name of all things Chesty Puller I think it should have covered the entire deployment , not the just the first half or so . SSGT Golembesky served 2 tours in Iraq and 1 in Afghanistan , so I 'm sure he has plenty of material to match his terrific writing style . Semper Fi , Marine you did good here .

Good , But Does Not Stand Out Among Other Novels In The Genre . St. Martin 's Press and NetGalley provided me with an electronic copy of Anything For You . I was under no obligation to review this book and my opinion is freely given . A call to the police about a would - be intruder ends in the discovery of a murder . The victim is Adam Grant , a respected San Francisco prosecutor and a man with a personal connection to homicide detective Valerie Hart . Vowing to keep her personal feelings to herself and solve the mystery , Valerie lets the investigation take her down a dark path to the eventual discovery of the responsible party . I liked Anything For You , but I was not really fond of the character development or the predictable plot . Too many liberties were taken with regards to the police investigative process and I really did not like the ending . Valerie 's past with Adam was a necessary part of the story , but the rest of her personal life just felt like filler . Overall , I was not shocked or stunned by the events as they unfolded and , in retrospect , I did not particularly like Valerie Hart herself . In a genre full of great police procedural thrillers , Anything For You just did not stand out .

Very pretty patterns and some very useful techniques . The only reason I did n't give this product 5 - stars is a personal one - I'm the type of knitter who always seeks to avoid sewing , and a lot of the projects in this book contain seams . That said , Folk Bags is still a keeper for me , and I 'm very glad I purchased it . Aside from the stranded color knitting which I do like , some of the projects are so interesting that I may actually take down my guard and try my hand at seaming up a few . The author 's inclusion of two particular techniques used in the bags - working entrelac flat , while joining the ends in a tube as you knit , and embellishing with a crochet needle instead of traditional embroidery - set this book apart from others of its kind for me .

A major issue I had was with the sparse index - basic terms such as " template " were missing , even thought there 's a fairly good introduction to it in chapter 2 . I did learn some theory and techniques from this book , but as a complete reference it 's not quite complete .

Excellent , poignant book - you will learn much . SHall Suffer Death by A. J. Bannister is a book I highly recommend . Bannister 's case is examined in detail , his life in prison , and the realities of a death sentence upon the mental and emotional makeup of the condemned , their family and friends is explored . It is a touching book - a book which if read with an open heart and mind - can bring a reader to the realization of the humanity of all . AJ Bannister was executed in October , 1997 . It was , in my opinion , the vengeful killing of a dear brother in our human family . Had AJ been permitted to live , I believe his life would have continued to bless many . He was a good man . I urge persons who oppose the death penalty , as well as those who support it or are ambivalent about it to read this powerful personal account of a man sentenced to death .

An emotional lesson . While doing a research paper about Chinese femininity , I stumbled upon this book and thought at first glance that I could use it . To my surprise , it ended up changing my paper and my life . There is no other book that captures the pain , misery , or humanity of the Chinese woman 's experience . Yet , it is still hopeful and encouraging . Each chapter deals with a different woman 's story . The topics range from love , sexual abuse , suicide , and acceptance . Some passages were so difficult to read that I cried , or flew into an angry rage . While other passages made me hopeful . This is a book where you are best to discover its contents for yourself , so I will leave this summary vague . I highly recommend this book . If your interests are in Chinese history , woman 's issues , or just great life stories that provoke strong reactions , this book will truly satisfy you .

To be sure , there are enough potentially interesting events to hold the reader 's attention through much of this work in the anticipation that something will develop , but these sparks are rapidly extinguished by banal conversation and dull narrative . The novel continues in this plodding pace , culminating in a contrived and , no doubt , hastily conceived conclusion .

Interesting , Feel - good , Unrealistic . One of the few Grisham novels in which the lead character seems far too unrealistic , that too for a lawyer . Unless Grisham intended to make such a wild swing of character to emphasize the " dramatic " effect his trauma and experience has had on the character , it just seems implausible . The plot , however , is interesting , fairly fast - paced , and original . The subplots involving the main character 's marriage seems to be present only because a need for a subplot was felt . The plight of the homeless is perhaps the aspect in the novel that deserves the most attention . It will most certainly make any reader ponder what hesse may be able to do to improve the plight of the homeless . The usual narrative , easy - reading style of Grisham is evident in this novel as well , and readers familiar with his style wo nt be disappointed . This is certainly one of his better books in terms of theme , not the best in terms of executing the plot . A must read for all Grisham fans you could care less for reviews , any way ! and a fairly good introduction to Grisham , if you have n't been introduced to this author .

A Few Small Issues that Add Up . As a mystery , this book was very good . I really liked reading about life in that era . The politics and law were fascinating . But there were several issues that , alone would not be a problem , but together caused me to rate this book down . 1 Way too many characters . I read this book in about 2 days and I 'm glad I did . If I had had to put this book down for a few days , I fear I would have lost track of who everyone was . As it is , I kept having to remind myself and in a few cases , the book had to remind me . 2 The narrator checks out every woman as if she was a side of beef . It got really old after a while . Though he did get a comeuppance at the end . 3 Everything seemed to drag out . It is n't that the book is wordy it is n't . It just felt like it took forever for things to get going and then to progress . Too much time eating and drinking in taverns , that could have been cut .

Promising intentions with unsatisfactory results a disjointed , dreamlike , cold book . Not recommended . An absent mother and dying father leave Catherine and her brother Rob in pseudo - isolation , encouraging the relationship between them to grow intense and intimate . But when that relationship begins to break down , Catherine alone must reconstruct the fragments of her life . A Spell of Winter is a dream of a book , disjointed , atmospheric , and cold . However effective that atmosphere , it deadens the intensity of relationships and character 's sufferings . The right elements are there a complex and distinct protagonist , a gothic dark , often intense view of relationships and experiences with a poetic if unrefined voice to match , and a well - intended character arc . But the book only floats along - surprisingly explicit in some aspects , it still leaves too many secrets to linger in implication its tone is always cold , dreamy , disconnected , and its impact follows suit . I 'm predisposed to love half a dozen tropes in A Spell of Winter , but to my surprise the book did nothing for me . The intent is there , and the book is n't a waste , but in its heart it stays frozen . I do n't recommend it .

More than I needed . This rather large book gives anyone who 's interested a course in the workings of the oil market . While it certainly educates those who wish to understand the workings of this huge market , it really did n't help me as an investor as I hoped it would . I read the first quarter and scanned the rest . I was searching for an itemized list of what events in this market would give me an understanding as to what might happen next . both in upward and downward moves . A list of notable events and the corresponding expectations is what I wanted . I never found it . If I had diligently read the entire book and mapped them out myself , it might have been possible . I 'll never know since I did n't want to put that much effort in . One more thing As an aside , this is a typical scientist technologist work . If a central theme or thesis is developed , the author can not resist coming at it from at least 3 different angles , all saying the same thing . This is not needed . We can infer other related instances . This practice only makes the book much too long and wearies the reader .

Good Story Told Well . Another good story from Michael Connelly , the best crime legal author currently writing . In this one , Michael Haller , the Lincoln Lawyer , crosses the aisle to the prosecution side and teams with detective Harry Bosch and his ex - wife to try to assure that a convicted child murderer remains in the slammer . As always , the story is well told with all the usual plot twists and surprises one expects from a Connelly book . The defendant and the crime are appropriately creepy . I never wanted to put this down . My only complaint was that with two main characters , in a few places I got confused with whether Haller or Bosch was doing the talking . This was not a major complaint though . Some reviewers felt this book was not up to Connelly 's standards . I disagree . While it is not his very best that would still be The Lincoln Lawyer , it is a very good story told very well .

Ran out of steam . I thought the book started out interesting enough . Being in roughly the author 's age demographic , I know the excitement of trying to cook on your own while being brought up in an eating - out culture . Some things she points out - people whose parents did n't cook usually do n't cook at home , the price of grocery store shopping vs. eating out , urban foraging were interesting to read . The memoir style writing of it is fine as well , but she quickly loses steam and stretches the most inane stories for way too long . Supper clubs and private food parties in NYC sound fun , but when it becomes about what people are wearing and how awkward she felt and her numerous flings and how exalted she became in the foodie - NYC - sphere it becomes just so tedious and boring ! She is so mean about her failed dates too , like being disgusted with one guy just because he 's two years younger than her . Whatever . If her publisher did n't ask for 300 pages I 'm sure she could have kept her writing much more concise and interesting , but they did n't , and she did n't . Meh .

These are novice writing mistakes . Thankfully the MS seems to be well edited with few if any spelling , homophonic , or blatant grammar errors . I 'll update this review when I finish the book . I AM curious about the cause . Just not sure what needs to be resolved . Can you imagine the crowds going into Boston on the Red Line too see deceased loved ones ? Major tourist draw !

full of painful memories , she wants to have a normal life . 3 . 5 stars - this book was giving for an honest review by Bookstasters and Brady Stefani - Thank you ! Courtney , a fifteen - year - old girl , wants to be normal . With a scary past , full of painful memories , she wants to have a normal life - normal friends , boyfriends , party . but when she starts to dream about aliens visiting her in her bedroom , things get a little weird . or are they dreams ? All of the information is given little by little , so you get hooked on the pages up until the end ! This is an excellent teenage sci - fi book . Brady Stefani was able to get all the turmoil of emotions and particularities of a teenage girl which only a few authors can really do ! . It was a very pleasant surprise ! The only thing I did n't like very much was the relationship Courtney has with her mom . actually , anything related to her mom . It was very odd to see a parent behave like that . But he gets amazing points for making this book about sorority , girl power and specially , not letting turn into a teen romance ! It was refreshing ! Sad end to a series that had so much early promise . No actual spoilers included here , many other reviews already reveal them . I can simply say that reading this book was an unsatisfying waste of my time . There was token reference to almost everyone who showed up in prior books but almost no real attention to the vamps who were among the most interesting characters in the entire series . The book felt superficial and contrived . Also , much space was devoted to discussing Sookie cooking , cleaning , applying makeup , washing her hair , shaving her legs , et . Blech . Fans will inevitably want to read Dead Ever After for " closure " but I recommend doing as I did - check it out from the library and do n't waste your money .

talent writer - would like to see more character development . This is my first Colleen Thompson novel . I think that she has a lot of talent . The story follows Rachel , a photographer who is trying to restart her life after being acquitted for the murder of a former art student who stalked her . That 's quite a mouthful , so I 'll wait for you to read it again . Rachel heads home to Texas , where her grandmother , father , and stepmother live . She 's understandably brittle , as some people still think she might have committed the murder as well as other heinous acts . However , she meets Zeke , a man running away from his own past . Can these two people , so beaten down by life , find love ? I think you can probably guess the answer to that one . There were some surprises , which always makes a mystery , well , a mystery . I think that if this had a bit more character development , I would have enjoyed it more . I just could n't care about the characters as much I wanted to . Overall , not a bad read and I will probably check out some of her other books .

It was a very good read - but the next one needs more Veronica , less Nancy Drew . If I had just been reading a mystery , I would have given this one 5 stars . It was well written , paced well , had the types of twists and turns I always like to see in a good mystery - all in all a well told story . But Veronica Mars in " real life " is not a wimp , and she came off pretty wimpy in this book . If I were to make a suggestion to the author , I would have suggested more time watching Veronica Mars - which is pretty ironic , I know . I will make one comment that is a minor spoiler , so if you you hate spoilers stop reading now - this just illustrates my point . The Veronica Mars from the movie who punched her former classmate in the mouth and said " Original enough for you ? " was not the book Veronica Mars who was afraid to go to the gun range . The Veronica Mars we all know and love would likely have had her concealed carry permit the day after her 18th birthday . So next book , more of the tough , cynical , sparky Veronica , and less of this wimpy Veronica .

Another Cutesy Romance . I 've read several of Jill Mansell 's books and , while this was n't a favorite , it did have all the elements that make it enjoyable anyway . Mille and Orla are two women who need one another badly - Millie needs some excitement in her love life , and Orla needs another hit book after being in a writing slump . Orla hires'Millie to relay her adventures to her for a hefty sum in return , Orla writes about Millie , her love life , her friends , and her job . Along the way Millie meets some guys mostly through Orla , but some on her own . One man that Millie finds , Hugh Emerson , comes with a gorgeous face but a lot of baggage . Whether or not he and Millie can work through his issues is central to the story . My only complaint with this book - and all her others too - is that the hero heroine take a very long time to come together . In a book that closes in on 500 or so pages , that 's a long time to wait for the romantic reward .

Magpies . One staple of summer reading is a suspense novel , and Ruth Wares latest book titled , The Death of Mrs. Westaway , will satisfy those readers who like an engaging thriller . A protagonist named Hal living hand to mouth receives a letter about an inheritance . Ware leads Hal to and fro as she considers how to play her hand , which is a skill she has developed as a Tarot card reader . When the magpies arrive on the scene , Agatha Christie fans will feel on familiar ground , albeit without a Miss Marple to straighten everything and everyone out . Instead we have hapless Hal gradually stumbling into jeopardy and reward . I was thoroughly entertained by this novel . Rating Four - star I like it

After reading your review of the book it was obvious to me that you never taught at the high school this teacher is talking about . You refer to him as a crotchety old man , but in fact he was a very gentle caring man who cared a great deal about his students . I know because I attended this particular high school and saw first hand how arrogant and manipulative some of the students could be . I had no problems with any of my classmates , but I saw first hand what many tried and did get away with . This teacher is just telling what he and some of his fellow teachers experienced at the school . The teacher who wrote this book was telling the truth and many parents should read it and see what it is like for the teachers who try to instruct their children .

Complications . The prolific author Alexander McCall Smith titled the third installment of his Corduroy Mansions series , A Conspiracy of Friends . Readers of the earlier novels will be delighted by the return of a familiar cast of London characters , including the terrier , Freddie de la Hay , whose presence and character is as fully developed as his human companions . Smith presents the growing complications in the lives of these characters , and by the end of the novel , readers will have enjoyed spending time with these interesting people , and will await the next installment . Those readers who are new to the series might start here and wonder why would anyone care about these characters . It 's best to start at the beginning and join those readers who love the ways in which Smith develops characters whose lives become interesting to readers and whose struggles and foibles can be similar to our own . Rating Three - star Recommended

This book did n't work for me . THE END OF THE OCEAN had a promising premise - dual timeline , two POVs and a mystery behind that linked all these elements . The writing was good and descriptive plus the topics approached were important family , survival , climate change . That being said , I felt disconnected with the characters and the storyline felt mostly flat . I ended up skipping few pages in order to find a reason to make me invested in the story . At last , the execution left a lot to be desired . Unfortunately , this book did n't work for me . I received an ARC from BookishFirst in exchange for an honest review

Mildly interesting , mostly off - topic . As someone who has done a considerable amount of taxidermy and preparation curation of museum specimens , I looked forward to this book as a treatment of the subject from a psychological perspective . While some historical background is useful , the return to Ackley again and again was annoying , since the author was obviously copying material published elsewhere . The fact that he did n't even try to make a mount seems hypocritical and his demeaning rationale does n't ring true . I most enjoyed the discussions of novelty taxidermy and the preservation of pets . These areas would seem the best material to use in considering the psychology of people who desire such bizarre creations . I found it also bizarre that the author would try to write an entire book with much off - topic filler and repetition about a subject he claims to be obsessed with , yet does n't deviate from his position as a somewhat disgusted observer .

Sadly lacking in depth . Volume 1 is the most developed of the three . However the plot is derivative and the characters other than Eva are shallow . For example we are told two things about Tahl he is a leader and he is very handsome . We are never actually , shown his leadership in fact he is bypassed at every turn , even by Eva . Apparently good looks is enough for Eva which makes their relationship more stereotypical than having any depth . The battle scenes , both large scale and individual are chaotic at best , often incomprehensible in detail . Eva is apparently able to develop into a sword wielding wonder in the space of about two years , able to best people her own age who have been training for about ten years . Although she has been working at Soots forge for many years we are n't really shown how her strength is evidenced in any realistic way . The plot , storyline , and character development are lacking . I suggest reading Matt Heppes Orb series or even Miles Camerons books which are written for a more mature reader .

These are not real GRE questions . I have taken the GRE twice , so I have a fair idea of what the test looks like . This book has the same general format , but the questions are terrible . I have run into numerous issues with faulty reasoning in the verbal section and unrealistic ratios of fill - in - the - blanks in the math section . In general , they ask questions far harder and less strategic than the GRE actually asks . I actually threw it away after the third practice exam because I was so frustrated . If you are looking for a more accurate and helpful review book , I highly recommend the Princeton Review version . That book alone helped me improve from a 152 , 150 to a 157 , 156 .

Tough Book To Get Through . I loved Ms. Liviero 's " Pastel Orphans , " and was looking forward to loving " The Road Beyond Ruin . " It was okay , and could have been great . First of all it was confusing because it went back and forth in time within each chapter . The characters for the most part were really despicable . It was a very depressing story , which of course is attributable to the post WW II era . I liked the unexpected twists the story took . Usually I can figure out what 's coming , but this one took me by total surprise . Unfortunately I had to wade through 34 of the story before it got interesting . Before that , it was one depressing incident after another . At any rate I am neutral about recommending the book , which takes place in a small German town near a river and centers on two houses with survivors of the war . It goes into their lives before , during after , but I do n't want to go into details because it would be spoiler .

Some of the lengthy writing spent on the inner thoughts of a couple of the characters could have been put to better use . Regarding the plot , Cleeves creates one significant red herring that is never clearly resolved , the character just stops appearing in the story and , the solution is a typical deus ex machine with the solution appearing almost miraculously at the end when Joe reports the findings of an interview he 'd had , and the killer confesses in a near cloche drawing room scene .

Not terribly useful . All in all , there 's not much to recommend about this book . It has two sections , one dedicated to using the Manga Studio EX software , and the other giving general tips about creating Manga comics . Both sections are terribly light , with basic instructions but lacking the kind of depth or detail that other art books often offer . This is especially true of the section about creating comics , which is generic in its content - it really repeats basic comic advice that can be had in a dozen other books , without offering anything new . The software itself a trial comes with the book seems an awful lot like Photoshop with a lot of preset custom brushes and such , but then lacking the versatility that PS offers to do more than Manga . Perhaps if the book had been dedicated solely to the program , and gone on from the basic - basics into highlighting tips , tricks , and tools more , I would see more value in it . As is , I could n't recommend it .

Wonderful book - the real romance of travel that is fast disappearing . This is a wonderful book that reminds you of when travel was an adventure before globalization made it a packaged commodity . Anyone who loves the romance of travel and can get their hands on a copy should jump on it . The country and people are among the most interesting I have read about , the writer is a real person that takes you with him in a book that seems like what a friend would write back to you . This is a story that includes such things as writing to a Russian cartographer asking where on the map he thinks the true origin of one of the Asia 's longest rivers is , meeting a forest ranger in a remote land who had always wanted to find it for himself and setting out through hundreds of miles untracked wilderness to get there . The Mongolian people are unique and you will find no references to a McDonald 's . Their country is still theirs . This is a gem of a book .

A great read about the power of grief and love . This is an interesting story about a woman who endures the shock of tragedy , and finds an anchor to the world she knows when the dust starts to clear . The story is definitely written for the young adult scene , but as most young adult stories they can be enjoyed across multiple age groups . Simmons does a good job of basically reverse engineering the story and revealing bit by bit , kind of like a mystery but not quite . The writing is solid , I found it flowed quite well which is a good thing since this is a start to a series , and the characters are loveable . I will say that outside of Evan and Laney it was a bit hard to find a connection with the characters , but Simmons does more than enough with her main character and love interest to keep us connected to the story . This story does really touch on loss and how to cope with life after a close , personal tragedy . Its very hard not to feel the pain Laney goes through . Ill definitely keep an eye out for the next piece in this series .

In Mr. Thor 's black and white world either you are for unfettered capitalism or you are for forceably taking from those people who work hard for their wealth and redistributing it to the lazy and shiftless - there is no middle ground , no shades of gray . I would recommend this only to those who believe Fox News is news and not propaganda and comedy .

Has potential . Since I enjoyed Lori 's Men Who Walk the Edge of Honor series so much , was excited when BookTrib offered me the opportunity to review her new Love Undercover series ! Run the Risk introduces us to Detective Logan Riske , who has Pepper Yates under surveillance in the hopes that she will help him find justice for the murder of his best friend . Undercover as a construction worker , Logan has no idea that Pepper has a few tricks up her sleeve as well ! While I understand that Logan was undercover , it bothered me a little that he was going to use Pepper in order to get to her brother . Because of this , I was glad to see Pepper stand up for herself and not let herself be used ! But does a relationship built on lies have any chance at all ? This series has potential , but think the the Men Who Walk series is a hard act to follow . I liked Logan 's partner Reese , maybe because he rescued an abandoned dog ? And what 's up with Reese 's neighbor Alice ? I did enjoy the story , and am curious to see if Reese and Rowdy get their own books , as I really liked these guys !

Not so much a guide as a treatise . I was looking for a book on inflammation , aging , and diet . This book has a chapter called " The anti - inflammatory diet " that I read first . It taught me a few new things but mostly confirmed that the eating and activity plan that I created for my my husband should help relieve his inflammation problems . That chapter being helpful , I returned to the beginning of the book to read the whole thing . I quickly found myself skimming the pages and looking for interesting tidbits . Overall , I found the writing style tedious , explanations too long , and the little " real life stories " uninteresting . I know this book has many good reviews , so others obviously found what they needed in it . Maybe because I had already read so many books on aging , diet , supplements , disease , et . , I did not find the rest of the book very informative and certainly it was n't a guide . It contains very detailed information on aging and its physiology . I admire Dr. Weil very much , but this book just did n't provide me with the information I was looking for .

Balanced , Readable , and Spiritually Nourishing . Dawn Eden 's Remembering God 's Mercy is a fantastic buy for anyone who has ever experienced any degree of trauma or dysfunction in their lives , i. e. , all of us . In a very readable and enjoyable manner , Dawn gives the reader an extremely balanced application of Catholic spirituality to the most difficult parts of our lives . You need not worry about whether she tries to smuggle in any pop - psychology and pass it off as Catholic tradition or teaching . You 'll get none of that here . What you 'll receive is a fantastic reflection upon Ignatian spirituality largely through the mind and words of Pope Francis . This book does n't stop there , however . In Remembering God 's Mercy Dawn Eden walks us through a needed spiritual growth in all of our lives by helping us understand the whole of our lives through the mind and wounds of the Glorified Christ . It is with great joy that I strongly recommend this book to all Catholic and Christian readers .

Interesting Premise . I have mixed feelings about this book . I did like it the premise was unique , that depression and suicide is an almost viral epidemic among teenagers and needs to be treated by reprogramming them . But , somehow , I did n't love the book . Maybe the romance was too predictable ? Not sure . It was definitely one of those formulaic bad boyhood girl romances . However , I did enjoy the world building of the dystopian future and the imagination of the epidemic and the story moved along . The teenagers were definitely the more well rounded characters and it frustrated me that the adults , while trying to prevent suicide in teens , did everything to promote it by not allowing anything but good feelings or off you go to get programmed . Anyone living under that kind of pressure would crack . It just felt like in their protection of kids the adults lost all common sense .

Did the author actually make any of these recipes ? I was super excited for this cookbook , but I 've been extremely disappointed with every recipe I 've tried so far . The biscuits are just one step above hockey pucks , and the bread is not much better . Honestly , I 've had far better luck using regular family recipes and just handling the dough less . This was a big waste of money !

Great Book for Entry Level Financial Analyst . Eh , a couple interesting moments but mostly forgettable . Throttles between a two and three stars , there 's a bunch of interesting stories and concepts here - the idea of addiction to media is compelling , but Patton Oswalt does this thing where he builds up towards the big revelation that it compels you to go " so . ok , yeah , now what " whenever he brings out the nuggets of wisdom like how consuming a media does n't make you good at doing media . There 's a bunch of small moments that stick out , but the best moments have nothing to do with movie addiction anyway ! I guess I 'm just disappointed because I feel like there 's a solid book from Patton , but either he 's too nice or too busy to go hard at creating a thicker work .

Unfortunate . Probably the worst part about this book is that it was n't better . With better editing , a finer eye for plot holes , and a bit more character development , this would have absolutely been worth reading .
