Intriguing ! 3 - 3 . 5 stars . I was offered an arc of this prequel to the popular Limetown podcast series from the publisher via NetGalley for my honest review . I had never heard of this series but the premise sounded quite intriguing so I accepted Three hundred people living near a research laboratory in Limetown , TN , suddenly disappear without a trace . Among them is Lia Haddocks'uncle , Emile . The government is not releasing much information and her parents will not talk about it , so Lia does some investigating on her own . The mystery dips into the paranormal with Emile 's backstory , told in alternating chapters . Good storytelling ! With a cliff - hanger - type ending , I 'm totally hooked , wanting to know more , so will probably HAVE to listen to the podcast now .

. continued Parker 's series have successfully maintained what I have loved about them . The other writers who have continued Parker 's series have successfully maintained what I have loved about them . Coleman does n't . In his hands , Jesse Stone is not just a flawed human being but a tortured mess - a whole different character in ways that count . The hope that he can learn to control his drinking is gone . Instead of figuring out a relatively clean way to sort out the evil around him , this Jesse Stone buys into it , leaving him compromised and even more tortured . The ending , instead of providing the reader with a small island of satisfying closure , simply ups the horror . Coleman may be a good writer of his kind of stuff , but cramming a Parker novel into his recipe was not a good idea .

Bland , Uninspired Ghost Story . Expected a good old - fashioned ghost story in a modern , but gothic setting . Promising premise - young married couple returns to college town to write and savor their life together , while stumbling upon odd and inexplicable experiences . Was set to curl up with this one and get happily drawn into a deliciously slow and increasingly unsettling mystery . None of these things happened . I ve abandoned the book multiple times and finally gave up at page 110 . Clare and Jess are uninteresting , one - dimensional , stereotypical characters with no chemistry . The plot is excruciatingly plodding and predictable . Very little action , and not much effort to push the story forward . I love books with introspection and interior monologues , and do n't require a riveting pace , but there is no depth here to offset the lack of movement . Exceedingly tedious and tepid . Nothing to propel the reader to continue reading . I knew I was done when I realized early on that I did n't care about the characters or what happened to them . The writing is adequate , but uneven and given to a formulaic style . I wanted to like this book , but did n't . Sophmoric and dull . Better books in this genre exist .

Terrible , Unless You 're Looking for an Example of How NOT to Write . I have made my living as a professional writer for 30 years , and I can definitively say this is absolutely the worst manual on writing I have ever written . Pyne has some good ideas in here , but they are pretty much the ideas you would find in most writing manuals . The difference is that Pyne buries them in a heaping mass of prose , so his good ideas are easy to miss . What is ironic is that he writes disdainfully about writing tight . I see why he does not care for that approach he can not do it . The worst thing about this book is not the lardy writing , though it 's that Pyne uses extended similes candor metaphors in virtually every paragraph . The resulting prose is exhausting and confusing . This tome is a perfect example of how NOT to write .

Once again , we see love is not all you need , especially when you are a parent . Rosie and Rex are somewhat star - crossed lovers , and their differences bring them together even while they keep them apart . While living in the blush of love , they bring two children into their marriage , and they do n't know how to keep it all together , despite desperately wanting to . I got very angry at these parents for keeping their mouths shut when they should be talking , being rigid when they should be bending , and not setting their feet down when that was absolutely required . This was a tearjerker , but it ends on a positive note . Even when we are n't quite sure how to love someone , if we are willing to be vulnerable , uncomfortable , and try though we 're sure it will cause us torture , we are all better for having walked openly through the pain .

Title should be " Compact living . on a limitless renovation budget . " . Title should be " Compact living . on a limitless renovation budget . " Everything is designer showroom - perfect on these pages , like an Ikea or Pottery Barn or Crate and Barrel catalog . However the spaces lack human reality , such as quirky collections or individualized space needs or child friendly design . You do n't even meet the inhabitants . Yes , invest in built in cabinets and fold away stair cases if you own and have the money . Again , these options are unattainable for many struggling to pay the mortgage or are renting . A much better book is Bartolucci 's " 1000 soft or less . " That features real people with real budgets . I wanted real advice , not catalog advertisements for perfect unattainable ideal design . I was disappointed . But perhaps idealism and extravagance , not realism and cash poor budgets are what most readers want . Hence the popularity of ARchitectural Digest , and why I am so turned off by such mags .

Ran out of steam . I thought the book started out interesting enough . Being in roughly the author 's age demographic , I know the excitement of trying to cook on your own while being brought up in an eating - out culture . Some things she points out - people whose parents did n't cook usually do n't cook at home , the price of grocery store shopping vs. eating out , urban foraging were interesting to read . The memoir style writing of it is fine as well , but she quickly loses steam and stretches the most inane stories for way too long . Supper clubs and private food parties in NYC sound fun , but when it becomes about what people are wearing and how awkward she felt and her numerous flings and how exalted she became in the foodie - NYC - sphere it becomes just so tedious and boring ! She is so mean about her failed dates too , like being disgusted with one guy just because he 's two years younger than her . Whatever . If her publisher did n't ask for 300 pages I 'm sure she could have kept her writing much more concise and interesting , but they did n't , and she did n't . Meh .

Huh ? That 's It ? I was flabbergasted to read the reviews from people who gave this book 4 - and 5 - stars . Did we read the same book ? Maybe not . Perhaps these people purchased the book edition at full - price , whereas I downloaded my kindle edition for . 99 , and they received a version that is markedly different from mine . This book was one of my worst summer readings . Mr. Cantrell had the makings of a good novel . However , instead of developing an intricate story with likeable and villainous characters , he fills the pages with too much technical babble that robbed the story of any mystery and interest . I agree with some of the reviewers who commented that it was like reading a technical manual . In numerous instances , when the author engages the reader with a twist in the plot , he never develops it much further , only to leave the reader with anticipation . And the anticipation , of course , turns out to be one of the biggest disappointments at the end , leaving the reader to ask , Huh ? That 's it ?

Decline in art quality . The first three books in this series are phenomenally done . Homelands , Exile , and Sojourn are all five star efforts . The art team changed for this second trilogy though , beginning with the Crystal Shard . The quality was still good , but a bit different . This book , the second of the second trilogy , was a decline though . As I read this entry in the series , I kept noticing that the main character in a given panel is n't drawn with very much detail - eyes do n't have pupils sometimes , hair is a single solid color with no lines , a sword will just be a solid black silhouette , the hilt will disappear into the bottom of the fist , and then come out the top at a weird angle . Those are all things that I would not mind if they were on smaller , background characters , but that is how major , speaking characters whose face or body will dominate 70 - 80 of a panel are done . Any fan of the series will still enjoy it , and the first trilogy is amazing , but this particular book does n't really live up to the standard that the first books set . It 's still worth checking out , though .

Managing Conflict . I just completed the unabridged audio book " Market Forces " . No , it is not a book about today 's business . No it is not exactly a Sci - Fi book . Well what is it ? Hard to describe . Set into the future around 2050 the book follows the future investment advisors of " Conflict International " . An investment company that profits from the various little conflicts overthrows wars etc between groups worldwide . CI acts much like a venture capital firm of today , they apply the money of their investors into these " conflicts " hoping to make the results come out profitable for their investors . Well , if that is not odd enough for you , it gets stranger . The corporate culture in 2050 has investment advisors battling on the roads in a kill or be killed conflict with other investment advisors . How do you get a promotion at CI ? Simple you battle as road warriors to the death of the person who 's job you want . It is a very strange society in this vision of the future . Would I recommend it ? A moderate yes . It is a long audio book and a bit hard to follow . The payoff is not as exciting as it could have been considering the setup .

Life , food , and personal culture . Yeah , I just said the words " personal culture . " Maybe I should have said something more prose , like personal experience with culture . We taste . We put things in our mouths as infants as a way of learning about them . We taste and we taste life , and in tasting " find out about things . " And when you start to think about what you are tasting and what you are finding , thoughts really start exploding . For the author , and for many of us if we will acknowledge it , taste is a primary way of information gathering . And the events and sights and sounds all those other information passageways that are our senses that accompany it mean that food is culture and culture is food . And here , in this book , is the life that meets us at the plate . One person 's experience with cultures as experienced through food . Altogether a somewhat interesting read , which may or may not leave you hungry . And will probably also bring you some laughs and possibly some occasional gags . Forgettable , but entertaining .

Should be Titled Why Americans are Stupid and Should Elect Liars . Although this author writes articulately , I found this book galling and many of its underlying suppositions flawed . Friedman makes it quite clear that he considers Americans too ignorant and cowardly to accept our role in the world economy and the country 's position as an unintentional empire . It is his opinion that we require lying , scheming presidents he thinks Obama is doing smashing ly , by the way to recorder the balance of power and manage the world as an unofficial emperor while feeding the American public soothing stories and polite lies to keep the steeple quiet . Despite mentioning that Middle Eastern Muslims want to reinstate an Islamic Caliphate , he contradictorily asserts that they hate and attack America only because it is economically powerful . He points out that other nations , like China , are happily financing American debt while facing their own crises , yet somehow predicts that China will lose power rather than catastrophically for the US collecting on what it is owed , directly or through influence such leverage supplies . Although he makes a few valid points here and there , this book is insulting , founded on poor logic and best skipped altogether .

Bland . Is it the translation ? When a translated book seems bland , it is hard to know whether to fault the author or the translator . Here , the translator certainly did the author no favors by injecting modern idiom and a certain breeziness into the book . The author can be faulted too , for not coloring the story with enough detail about life in 16th century Venice . I do n't mean that the book should have been cluttered with description , but we hear nothing of eating or drinking or music or culture and the story itself a search for a politically important artefact - might have been set in any era . What we are left with is a readable but unexciting mystery set in Venice just before the Protestant Reformation . A valuable and politically explosive book is in the city somewhere and a " devil " is murdering people trying to find it . I liked the characters but overall I found the book unexciting . An average effort , so three stars . I received a review copy of " The Lion and the Rose " by Riccardo Bruni translated by Aaron Maines Amazon Crossing through NetGalley . com .

Great plot idea , terrible execution . In the book We Need to Talk About Kevin , its been 18 months since Eva Katchahdourians son Kevin went on a killing spree in his high school . In a series of letters to her ex - husband , Eva talks about the aftermath of the murders , while examining the past for a reason why it happened . WHAT I LIKED Evas pretentiousness bears both a stark contrast and a cold similarity to Kevin . The authors portrayal of PPD and mastitis are very relatable . WHAT I DIDNT LIKE Every character is so unlikable . Eva is such a narcissist . Her husband is a willfully ignorant buffoon . Kevin is a sociopath . The parts of the book that actually struck an emotional chord and made the characters relatable were few and far between . Most of the book was Eva complaining ungratefully about food and houses and the loss of personal freedom that is parenthood . I know the author is an activist , but the propaganda is very thinly disguised . The plot had so much potential , but was lost in the pompous ramblings if the protagonist .

Fun but Faulty Thesis on Psychopathy . This is honestly a very fun and engaging read , but I have fault it for a lack of scientific rigor and a rather lighthearted conclusion that whitewashes a lot of the realities of the'psychopath . 'I add scare quotes there because the psychopath is a loosely defined psychological category , not a formal diagnosis with a well - defined population . The author leverages this ambiguity to cherry pick the characteristics of certain psychopaths that make his conclusions more agreeable . The book is honestly persuasive and leaves the review confident that we can gain a lot of value from flipping the valence of research on psychopathy and considering the psychopath as a'dark saint . 'The author kind of views psychopaths as mutants i la X - men , and says that some are heroes and others are villains . This is all very engaging only if we ignore our general ignorance about the complexities of the relationship between brain activity and human behavior . -Ryan Mease

Interesting , but a bit melancholy . Although I found this book interesting , I found the melancholy feel a bit irritating at time . I understand and can relate to her feelings of having to exist in duality because of societal conventions , but that 's about it . Perhaps it is because I am of a different generation . I did enjoy her ability to step outside herself and see , retrospectively , what effect this type of existence had and continues to have on her .

Then the errors not caught by proofing , spell check or basic editing distracted me from the important storyline . Some sentences did not make sense at all while quotation marks in strange places , missing from either the beginning or the end and even a blatant error while describing Jane Doe . One minute she is 36 and in the same sentence she becomes 56 ! I would overlook a few errors but this book is about 80 errors . A psychological thriller I finished in one sitting . I really liked the Silent Patient , so I was really excited for this one . I feel a little bit let down though , though I love psychological thrillers . From the first chapter of this book , I knew Edward Fosca could n't be the murderer because that would be way too obvious and anticlimactic . The reveal of the killer was completely random - I felt like there were no clues or hints or anything leading up to the revelation that Zoe was orchestrating this entire thing . I was suspecting Elsie for a bit and then Fred , and I could tell it was Zoe a few pages before it was revealed . Although I was surprised about Sebastian 's involvement - I feel like that was a good revelation . That being said , I did read the entirety of this book in just one sitting , and it was definitely a page turner for me . I also loved the connections with the Silent Patient and seeing Theo mentioned again was awesome . I did expect more from Alex Michaelides , but I would recommend this book to others .

Interesting look at American Suburbs in 1975 . I received an advanced copy of this book in exchange for an honest review . I guess , I do n't really know how I feel about this book . The writing was good and the story was ok .

Magpies . One staple of summer reading is a suspense novel , and Ruth Wares latest book titled , The Death of Mrs. Westaway , will satisfy those readers who like an engaging thriller . A protagonist named Hal living hand to mouth receives a letter about an inheritance . Ware leads Hal to and fro as she considers how to play her hand , which is a skill she has developed as a Tarot card reader . When the magpies arrive on the scene , Agatha Christie fans will feel on familiar ground , albeit without a Miss Marple to straighten everything and everyone out . Instead we have hapless Hal gradually stumbling into jeopardy and reward . I was thoroughly entertained by this novel . Rating Four - star I like it

Poetic writing , depressing book . I was so excited to read another book by Laura Kasischke . I loved " A Perfect World " full disclosure I am an apocalypse - story lover . Give me " the world is ending , here 's what this group of people does with it " line and I 'm hooked . I suppose that " Life Before Her Eyes " was much better - written , word - wise really , her description of scenes and objects is poetic , which obviously comes naturally to her , since she 's a poet , but the story and the narration sucked me down , down , down , down . I only finished it because I hate to put a book down before the last page unless the writing is terrible . So , for a beautiful and lyrical read that gets into your head and makes you think that perhaps you , too , are going crazy , I highly recommend this book . Or not .

Be skeptical . This book is excessively alarmist . Persuading others to act on improving our public schools requires well - reasoned arguments , not Chicken Little scare tactics . Another bogus book of internet joke lists . It seems that a number of people have taken the mass - forwarded joke lists that they got emailed for friends or found posted to newsgroups , and published them in a book . This includes bogus joke lists and stories that have been discredited to different famous people . Some of the most glaring examples found here include the " George Carlinisms " and the " In the World of Steven Wright " lists filled with things that neither comedian wrote , but that some people eventually stupidly attributed to them on the internet . And stupid authors like this go ahead and publish them without researching .

Not a Great Story , But Great Fun For Dug Fans . Our five year old is a big fan of Dug , one of the characters in ASINB001KVZ6FW the recent Pixar movie , Up . She was delighted to get this book . Other young fans of Up or Dug would be too , but most other kids would probably find it a little dull . Using simple , cute artwork that resembles cutout collages , this book basically tells the story of the first two - thirds of the movie as seen through the eyes of Dug . Over the course of the story , Dug , a loveable but underestimated dog , meets the other main characters , befriends them , and helps them to make their first escape from the villain and the other dogs . As I said , my daughter is a Dug fan and loves having a story about Dug to go with her ASINB0029UC6AQ Dug plush animal , but I could n't give the book more than three stars . First , the writing is a little basic . Second , given that they were retelling the movie , I 'm not sure why Disney did n't just add 3 or 4 pages and finish the story . In my opinion , both of those would have added a lot .

Simplistic . Although easy to read , this book offers up large doses of simplistic problems with painfully obvious answers . Granted , mastery of the soft skills encompassed by EQ are important but this book is too superficial in its coverage . Studies are referenced and there is a generous notes section . The references are dated , Seinfeld , really ? And frankly , using Princess Diana as the model of social responsibility was laughable . While she may have been a pleasant enough person she was essentially a media created celebrity . Posing for pictures with sick people or advocating for obviously unobjectionable causes land mines pales in face of the humility and impact of Mother Theresa or the courage of activists such as Lech Walesa . Most of the information is valid but it lacks the depth of a text and the practicality of the best self help books . I do n't know that most students would have either the time or patience to invest in this book . Pass .

3 . 5 stars . The XY has a very interesting concept that immediately grabbed my attention . Society is filled with females only . Males are kept separate and lead completely different lives . Males have only one purpose to provide sperm in order to contribute to the human race . Our narrator and main character , River , starts out very naive . She grows throughout the book and its nice to see how brave she becomes . The characters are well - done and develop well , particularly River . I thought the story was really lacking . The writing and the overall concept was able to draw me in and keep me captivated , but I was very underwhelmed by the story as a whole . Nothing really happens other than right at the beginning until about 70 into the book . While I want bored , I am disappointed with the story . It had so much potential with such an interesting concept .

You have to dig for the good stuff . Dornenburg and Page assembled some really interesting insights and experiences from many US chefs and sprinkled the book with some of their recipes . First the good stuff . When the chefs tell their stories , you get some interesting and entertaining insight into the restaurant world both here and abroad . The discussion of the apprenticeship process in Europe is fascinating , as are the stories about how various chef 's started . Now the not so good stuff . The recipes are not well edited at all . In some cases little information about ingredient quantities is provided , and the procedure descriptions are hit - or - miss at best . Do n't risk a big dinner party on these recipes unless you 've tried them out first . Also , the authors include several pointless tables addressing things like who once worked for whom .

Started with a Bang , Ended with a Fizzel . I was very cautious when I began reading this book . There are sweeping claims made by Bell , and the reader is expected to take Bell 's word for them . There is some scriptural references , but not enough to substantiate Bell 's claims . I liked the tone , cadence and style of the writing . The claims of empire building in the church are not new to me , and I agree . What I did not like was the misplaced guilt trip and the secular humanistic qualities of the book . Loving and caring for the poor in this world , is NOT the focus of Jesus ministry or the Gospel , as Bell claims . It is certainly important to show Jesus love and care for humanity in practical ways , as almost every one who names the name of Christ does . This message of the arrival of the spiritual kingdom of God is the Gospel . NOT attempting to end the poverty of spirit by a radical demonstration of who Jesus is , yet seeking to implement some form of socialism is a misguided humanist line of thinking .

Peachwood Lake . Peachwood Lake reminds me of those teenage horror movies you 'd see at the Drive - in where the creature terrorizes the people on the lake except without gore or sex . An armored - plated silverfish terrorizes a peaceful Connecticut Lake one summer . And no matter what the town and government could do to destroy it , they fail . Meanwhile , thirteen - year - old Kady is a lonely girl and an outcast among her peers . A journalist for a weekly supermarket tabloid befriends her and with the story of the century she begins to develop self - esteem . An enjoyable book and an easy read finished it one day , I got the impression that this was more of a YA book and would certainly satisfy that group of readers .

Sweet story , very easy to read . It is a sweet story , very easy to read . I was about to finish before I noticed . However , I ca nt say I was involved with it . I did n't connect with characters that easily . Besides , there are so many of them ! I had a hard time learning who was who since I had n't read the first book . Also , small details in the book sometimes took longer than they should . Meetings , for example . I felt like skipping paragraphs at moments . There are some great lessons and quotes throughout the book , though . That was good . I liked Jack more than Evie . I did not agree with certain decisions she made . Now , the last 3 chapters or so were a different thing . Maybe because they were all focused on the most important stuff . At that part I could connect . I was interested in what would happen . It was disappointing at the end because it was all solved in such a simple way . but I could enjoy it more . I hope this series keeps getting better . Old School Baseball . I came away from 3 NIGHTS IN AUGUST with more respect for Tony LaRussa . Here is an old school manager that anyone who loves the game of baseball can appreciate . LaRussa in action and philosophy is not the pure antithesis of MONEYBALL . A better description would be a heartfelt antagonist . MONEYBALL ca n't measure the heart , and that is what LaRussa is looking for in addition to talent . Some have talents , others have heart , but the special ones , the winning ones , have both . A enjoyable read , but Bizzinger continues to be a little out of his element when he collaborates with others . A PRAYER FOR THE CITY and FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS both had his distinctive voice ringing through them . This feels more like a book written and then showed to LaRussa , and then rewritten , which makes it a bit long in the tooth by the end . Still quite good , and Bizzinger is a talent with heart , even if sometimes a little hot headed .

More suited for web analysts'managers . This is a fast reading book about how to be an effective web analyst at a large company that can afford such . The author writes that the web analyst needs to analyze web stats with respect to company 's goals , and then to present to management and other company staff , goal - oriented action steps . With color illustrations , so very pleasant fast reading . Not really sure this book 's worth the money though . Though it talks about a web analyst job , its simplistic message is that a job any job - e. g. web analyst needs to be seen in relationship to the company 's goals and its other employees . So , the book is basically a Business 101 Career Guide - to understand what one 's job in a company really is . My opinion is that this book is more appropriate for the web analyst 's manager - so that the manager understands what the web analyst is suppose to be doing . It 's too basic for a web analyst careerist .

Full of errors including the title " Panjabi " . This book is a joke . Look at the title of the book in the picture . Panjabi . That is your first clue . The language is Punjabi not Panjabi . There are flash cards you can tear out in this book . I used 36 of them . I had a native speaker check these for me . 16 of the flash cards were correct and 20 were wrong . I did n't even bother tearing the rest out . I was told by the native speaker not to use this book at all because of all the errors and inaccuracies . I 'm so glad I had this book looked over before using it to learn . I ca n't imagine the embarrassment I would have experienced had I spoken some of these translations to people who speak Punjabi . I would have looked like an idiot . If you want to learn the language properly and learn the proper translation for words then do not purchase this book !

Beware ! This is not the book you read as a child . If you are looking for the story you were read as a child , this is not it . This book was written by Lynda Bulla not Ben Ross Berenberg and is based on the memories that her friend had of the original book as read to him when he was 5 years old . The illustrations are different , the writing is different , even the moral of the story is different . The only thing that is the same is the title . DO NOT GET THIS BOOK IF YOU ARE TRYING TO SHARE A PRECIOUS MEMORY OF YOUR CHILDHOOD WITH YOUR SON OR DAUGHTER , YOU WILL BE DISAPPOINTED . I feel that Amazon should not sell this book , as it seems like an effort to take advantage of the people searching for the original work which is now out of print .

Could n't put it down and did n't want too ! OK Holy Hotness Batman This book contains some hot and sexy scenes . Hopefully you have read the first book if you are reading this one ! Breathe out picks up exactly where Breathe In left off , the chemistry between Emma and Joe has reached its boiling point and Emma has broken her rules and let Joe in . It scares the hell out of her to feel what she feels for Joe but she ca nt help it . Joe is not giving up without a fight he wants Emma and he will have her even if it is on her terms . Its just sex and nothing more no feelings , no relationships and no one needs to know at least according to Emma . Breathe Out plays out the evolution of Joe and Emma 's relationship and delves deeper into why Emma is they way she is and why it is so hard for her to let people in . This book is heartfelt and sexy all at the same time . It is so well written and flows smoothly that you ca nt help but fall even more in love with the characters . I could n't get enough .

Every see one like this ? Stone 's heart finds its purpose in helping . Parker has made a career of selling offbeat characters . Good company . A charismatic and mischievous student finds himself entangled in a detective story regarding an alien artifact , which , in typical , bigger than life , Zelaznesque mode , comes with intergalactic repercussions . Doorways in the sand are not the Zelazny of Lord of Light , but a rather light Zelazny , except for a few scattered pages , especially at the end of the story . However , this should not avert any SF fanatic from reading it , because the writing is intelligent , fast - paced , pleasant , suspenseful , almost to the point of running out of adjectives to describe it . An excellent read , restoring faith to the maxim that a book is the best company .

I wish zero stars were an option .

. finished this book only because Faye Kellerman is a best selling author and I was hoping to find out . I finished this book only because Faye Kellerman is a best selling author and I was hoping to find out why . I did not . I enjoy historical fiction this book is certainly fiction , the historical part is more doubtful . Many reviewers mention that it strains credulity . No question . Most of the premises are ridiculous . My favorite historical mystery writer , Margaret Frazer , has died and I would love to find another of her caliber . Kellerman is not one . This book was plodding most of the time , with brief periods of frenetic action and graphic horror and gore that I had to skip over . I read pretty much all the reviews to find out if this book was representative of her work . It seems that it probably is not , but not for the reasons that would have me pick up another of her books .

Another low - carb snake oil book ? It is not always the case that people who act in immature manner are undereducated . However , it is often the case that " empty barrels make the most noise " . People who have credentials in the health field , who have done research , and who are thinkers have no need to act in a particular manner . Raymond Audette regularly posts to the usenet google group all . food . vegan for the sole purpose of disrupting conversations and angering people . In my opinion if Audette was a true researcher , had credentials that would qualify him for writing a book on nutrition and his diet was based on fact he would have better things to do with his time . Hitching his wagon late to a diet fad that every major scientific body condemn , his lack of credentials , and his behavior in all . food . vegan makes me seriously doubt the potential value of the content of this book .

This does n't cover anything more than standard self help books out there , but it somehow pretends to be a textbook for college classes . As for our case we had to buy this book for a class , and the student using it is not a native speaker . In fact , most people in the class are not native speakers . This book is almost useless for them as it 's very long winded . Most of the students being forced to read this book spend most of their time trying to understand the point of the author . Now for the website . Terrible . Does n't work well at all . In fact , it wo n't even work at all on some browsers . Worst part is you ca n't download anything to view offline . The automated quizzes are a pain to use . Feels like they 're forcing students to pay more for less . Also you can get this in PDF format for 75 if you do n't mind pretending to be from the UKIrelend without all the hassle and restrictions that their website has .

Inaccurate nutritional information . The book is basically laid out well but unfortunately , the nutritional information is computed incorrectly . If a reader is watching for lowfat recipes , the numbers given would be misleading . For example , the apple walnut salad is said to serve 6 people with each serving containing 4 . 6 grams of fat . However , with 66 to 70 grams of fat in the entire recipe , the fat grams per serving would be 10 to 11 grams . Quite a difference ! Also , the chicken grapefruit stir fry would have at least 6 grams of fat per serving rather than the 3 grams stated in the book . This problem would be significant for those with heart or coronary artery disease who are attempting to follow a very lowfat diet . I 'm surprised the authors did n't have a nutritionist check these computations before going to press .

A New York Snob Speaks . Nora Ephron is quite sure of herself and her friends , and laughs heartily at the yahoos in the Midwest who cook and love their husbands . While her writing is often amusing , her attitude of condescension and wearying self - glorification is grotesque . And to see her way back at the beginning of the Women 's Movement equally sure of how circumstances would improve for women is especially painful . She poo - poohs those who wonder if woman 's life will actually improve , and her own " Encounter Group " partners certainly cast doubt upon that and lives in a world where people such as herself need not be troubled by real life . As a historical document there is much to glean . For instance , the disgust with Watergate is palpable yet our disgust with far greater crimes today is much less apparent . A clever lady , with a few interesting observations , but annoying and smug without being especially insightful .

Grammar anyone ? I used this textbook for a late - start community college course . What bothers me the most about this textbook are the numerous grammatical mistakes and incomprehensible sentences that occur throughout the text . One in front of me right now pg 395 discusses " payments to Philippine customers officials " . I 'm guessing this should have been " custom officials " ? While I do n't pretend to have perfect grammar myself , I often find my concentration broken by syntax errors in the text . As other reviewers have also mentioned , the chapters seem overly - long and dry and the text is entirely black and white with no colors or pictures . What also stands out are certain organizational issues , which include certain topics popping up every chapter rather than just having one chapter address the subject . Another issue is the authors citing academic research without providing enough context such as not even providing the scholar 's first name . I also take issue with their over - reliance on the ethical models of Rest and Kohlberg while only giving token acknowledgement to criticisms of these models .

Pursuit . I picked up Daniel Handlers adult novel titled , We Are Pirates , since I knew him as the author of the children Lemony Snicket books . Handler explores the ways in which adolescents and adults pursue happiness . Set in and around San Francisco Bay , the two main characters are fourteen - year - old Gwen and her father , Phil . I found the sections of the novel in which Gwen dominates are energetic and exciting , while the parts featuring Phil are morose and dull . While both Gwen and Phil are pursuing what they think will make them happy , their differences are striking , and the plot never quite pulled them together in a way that satisfied me . Rating Three - star Its ok

Specialized and weak on application . I find little to say about this book . It addresses the macro trends of its title , at a fairly broad and repetitive level . It has much less to offer in terms of the second part strategies for gaining competitive advantage . Just a few weeks after reading it , I genuinely ca n't recall a single instance of an insight that goes much beyond the obvious of the macro trends . That obvious includes impacts of economic growth , strains of future logistics and widespread inadequacies in existing infrastructures . Yes , agreed . The data the book offers is useful in framing the problem , but rarely gets concrete about such issues as cold storage facilities , transportation industry scale and coordination , costs , telecommunications . It 's all like discussing airline policy without mentioning airplanes .

Compelling story of post - deployment readjustment . NOTE I received a free review copy of this book from the publisher . This was my first book from author Drusilla Campbell . I became easily engaged in the subject matter , the story of a woman 's readjustment to home life after her deployment in Iraq . Campbell 's writing is engaging , and the book was a quick read . The one issue I had is that early in the novel , it is somewhat difficult to have much empathy for main character Frankie , who comes off as quite abrasive . The reader might be more understanding with more insight into Frankie 's situation - namely , her post - traumatic stress disorder PTSD , but this does n't come until much later . Still , if the reader has patience for Frankie , her story is a compelling , worthwhile read .

Is this the rough copy ? I reviewed this a couple times but my reviews keep mysteriously getting deleted ? Do n't worry , seller , I wo n't let this unfortunate glitch sabotage the right of your potential customers to see unbiased honest reviews before they decide whether to buy , or the right of customers like me to express our opinions on what we bought . Not terribly useful . All in all , there 's not much to recommend about this book . It has two sections , one dedicated to using the Manga Studio EX software , and the other giving general tips about creating Manga comics . Both sections are terribly light , with basic instructions but lacking the kind of depth or detail that other art books often offer . This is especially true of the section about creating comics , which is generic in its content - it really repeats basic comic advice that can be had in a dozen other books , without offering anything new . The software itself a trial comes with the book seems an awful lot like Photoshop with a lot of preset custom brushes and such , but then lacking the versatility that PS offers to do more than Manga . Perhaps if the book had been dedicated solely to the program , and gone on from the basic - basics into highlighting tips , tricks , and tools more , I would see more value in it . As is , I could n't recommend it .

Mixed Metal Jewelry Workshop Combining Sheet , Clay , Mesh , Wire More from Lark Jewelry Books by Mary Hettmansperger . This book , Mixed Metal Jewelry Workshop Combining Sheet , Clay , Mesh , Wire More by Mary Hettmansperger contains some of the best pictures of the art of Mixed Metal Jewelry I have seen . There are so many examples of the output of the many talented artists in this medium , you will be enthralled by it 's contents . The use of metal clay is shown combined with other traditional metal forms to create some of the most impressive pieces jewelry making I have seen . She show you how with twenty development projects that combine great instruction and as they say , inspirational jewelry . Mary shows aspiring jewelers and jewelry craters how to combine these materials covered early in the book , with metal sheets , artists wire , beads , gems and other basic components of jewelry combined in stunning pieces , displayed with many pictures . I like it .

Identity . Check the five day weather forecast before you start reading Jo Nesbo 's novel , Phantom . There 's enough gloom and misery in this novel to spoil the sunniest day , so I ca n't imagine the experience of reading this on a gloomy or cloudy day . Protagonist Harry Hole is one of the most complex characters in modern fiction . He has the moral core of the policeman he has been , and the erratic behavior of the alcoholic he has also been . The extremes of love and hate are never distant from the daily life of Harry Hole . While each novel in this novel stands alone , there 's richness for readers who have followed the trajectory of Harry 's life . I wo n't even bother with reference to the plot here because the reason to pick up this novel is to enter into a complex life and watch the tension between good and evil play out , no matter what else is going on . Fans of crime fiction are those most likely to enjoy this novel and this series , provided one has a high tolerance for gloom . Rating Three - star Recommended

An exquisite teacher but a disappointing book . As a 35 - year yoga practitioner I have , of course , been aware of Seane since she was a silent class member in the original Bryan Kest videos . I have deep respect for her exquisite physical awareness and attention to detail as a teacher . I personally find her energy a bit strident in yoga classes but know she has passion and sincerity , along with ample experience so I was very curious and had high hopes for enjoying this book . That being said , I ended up returning the book , which is something I have done maybe once or twice in my life . I found it an odd combination of vulgar , repetitive , self - conscious and just not very interesting . I wanted to enjoy it and pressed on but decided not to finish the book . There are too many gems out there and life is too precious to slog through a book you find clumsy and adolescent . This reads like transcripts of a blog , not a polished and confident memoir , and that is solely the responsibility of the editor and publisher . I still have infinite respect for Seane as a teacher but just do not recommend this book .

Fun but Faulty Thesis on Psychopathy . This is honestly a very fun and engaging read , but I have fault it for a lack of scientific rigor and a rather lighthearted conclusion that whitewashes a lot of the realities of the'psychopath . 'I add scare quotes there because the psychopath is a loosely defined psychological category , not a formal diagnosis with a well - defined population . The author leverages this ambiguity to cherry pick the characteristics of certain psychopaths that make his conclusions more agreeable . The book is honestly persuasive and leaves the review confident that we can gain a lot of value from flipping the valence of research on psychopathy and considering the psychopath as a'dark saint . 'The author kind of views psychopaths as mutants i la X - men , and says that some are heroes and others are villains . This is all very engaging only if we ignore our general ignorance about the complexities of the relationship between brain activity and human behavior . -Ryan Mease

Almost logical but fundamentally flawed . There are good parts and not so good parts . At first it is so logical and middle of the road sounding that it almost sounds like he is actually approaching the subject from an intelligent standpoint , but then he drops typical ultra - left rhetoric implying that guns are the bad things , rather than the psychos using them for murder . Then there is the assertion that " high capacity clips " which is another way of saying higher than ten round magazines cause more death . I am not exactly sure what his point about that was supposed to be because he melded it with his distaste for arming teachers then pointed out that had Lanza had to take time less than a second by the way to reload then maybe , just maybe , principal Hochsprung would have been able to overpower the skinny murderer . but that the AR-15 acted as an equalizer and ended in her death . the point that makes to me is that if she had been similarly equalized with a firearm then 30round man or no she could have shot Lanza dead instead , but he abandons logic at that point in favor of anti - constitution and bill of rights legislation . good read , but poor conclusion .

Good enough to read . Beverly Lewis is the trailblazer for Amish fiction . I remember reading The Shunning years ago while discovering this new genre . She set the standard for all others who endeavored to write Amish fiction . In this latest book , Jodi Winfield visits a local Amish community and rediscovers her own faith while learning about the Amish culture . The story is also about Maryanna Esh , a young widow and mother of 4 , who learns that she can love again . The storyline is nice . The setting is charming . The people are delightful . Even the food sounds delicious . The middle of the book was tedious as the plot stagnated , but the ending was satisfying . Overall , this was a good book . Bethany House provided me a free copy of this book in exchange for my review which I freely give .

Mixed . First , I should mention that the title is misleading . This collection is a mix of science fiction and fantasy stories . That does n't bother me too much since I read both , but it surprised me and may well bother others . The quality is a uneven . Some stories are excellent and others were beyond boring and had to be skipped by this reader . Then there are stories that will be unintelligible to nonlocals - the story by Lauren Beukes , for example , uses many words only South Africans will understand . I happen to be South African , but I find extremely annoying this overuse of localisms in works intended to be read outside the country . It is in my opinion a bad technique to give a work a local flavor by peppering it with localism instead of doing it the hard way via good writing . Any technique that interferes with reader comprehension of the story is , in my opinion , a failure .
Too many stories . This book needed a good editor . Too much about stuff not pertinent to the main story . There is a good tale here if you can stick with it .

Agreed , not as gripping as the first , but still quite good . I did not laugh uncontrollably at this book , or feel as compelled to read it all in one sitting . I wish I 'd waited for the paperback - tradesize like the first one .

OK , not great Macdonald . I admire Ross Macdonald , generally , and found this book pretty satisfying , with a steady buildup of complexity and danger , fairly good character development , and one more twist than I had anticipated at the end . Bound To Be a Classic ! Islands of Ghosts is an excellent piece of YA writing ! I read the first book in the series , Islands of Stone , three times . I had high hopes for this second book , and they were totally surpassed . The protagonist , Ginny , is a regular teen who ends up in a position where she has to be someone she s not entirely comfortable being . She finds herself in intense situations with no apparent way out , yet her escapes are completely believable and cathartic . The love scenes are hot but totally YA appropriate I m definitely comfortable recommending this book to my high school students . Like with Islands of Stone , there is a poignant ending that left me aching for the next installation . I was totally invested in the story and stayed up until am reading it . I just had to know what was going to happen to Ginny next ! My new favorite book !

Almost Brothers who Grow Apart due to Life and Circumstances . Bittersweet is this story about Sandy and Rigley who grew up together in a rough and tumble neighborhood in Youngstown and then grew apart . Like Abamos Gift , this book tugged on my heartstrings , but in a totally different way . There 's a lot of rough language and tough circumstances , but it 's real - life in that neighborhood . The serene ending belies the broken road traveled by Sandy to get there , yet he acknowledges his fortune . The book could have been nearly 100 pages longer if Don had filled in some gaps that I discovered about two thirds through my reading . I think Don was merciful to exclude that part of their lives , though . I can identify with broken roads , however , which made me sympathetic to Sandy nearly throughout . Another good work by Don Greco . My favorite quote I knew I loved you the first time I saw you with him . Sandys wife .

Fresh . I opened Ron Chernow 's 900 page biography , Washington A Life , with the expectation that I would become bored quickly and put it aside . After all , is there anything new or fresh to add to the extensive books that have been written about the first President over the past two centuries ? I was pleasantly surprised that I found myself absorbed in a story that , while familiar , came across as fresh and alive . Before I knew it I was hooked , and I was happy to read through to the end , learning many new tidbits about Washington along the way . Any reader who enjoys American history will find something to appreciate in this finely written biography . Rating Three - star Recommended

The highs are high , but the lows are low . After hearing an interview with the author I immediately went out and bought this book , thinking the author might be the smartest man in the world . The book itself is a real mixed bag though . At the start it contains brilliant arguments about how people truly think about faith and religion . But then later on he makes positively goofy arguments like how affirmative action will eventually lead to government forced gay marriage as in the government will make you marry someone of the same sex against your will . Which ultimately made me wonder if I was stupid for being so impressed by the earlier arguments .
Overall i 'm pleased with the purchase . For the price and the book that came with it , it was okay . The checkers can always be upgraded later on . Overall i 'm pleased with the purchase .

stinky Sulks Is Far Superior . Pete 's A Pizza is a great title for a book . The story 's good too , but not up to the standard of Stieg 's best work . Pete is moping . It 's raining outside and he wants to play ball with his friends . Enter his Dad- " Pete 's father ca n't help noticing how miserable his son is " . The father leans on the armchair in which Pete is sprawling and thoughtfully scratches his chin . Steig 's genius has to do with seeing the mundane through surreal eyes . And so , " He thinks it might cheer Pete up to be made into a pizza " . The rest of the book describes the process , until , " It 's time to slice our pizza " . " But the pizza runs away and the pizza - maker chases him " . All is well the sun comes out and the pizza , having been captured and hugged , goes out to play . There 's nothing wrong with any of this . It 's a good kid 's story . But Steig 's done much better . Spinky Sulks , for example , deals with similar material with much greater depth , imagination and nuance . Enjoy this book and then go on to the real William Steig masterpieces , of which there are many .

Needs photos and an editor . It 's a breezy book that suffers from some glaring editing problems . Ronin describes Kirby 's Army service with some nice stories , but the author also mentions that Kirby returned to the USA in 1943 - even though Kirby landed at Normandy 10 days after D - Day , which places the King in Europe in June 1944 . Ronin 's description of the NationalFawcett lawsuit implies that settlement was reached in the mid-40s , but Fawcett actually settled in 1953 . Ronin does a good job of describing Kirby 's work habits , when well as Kirby 's later years as the King 's memory started to go . But the book really , really needs photos and illustrations . They 're essential parts of Kirby 's story , and there 's nothing inside the book . There are two drawings on the cover . The author spends a good chunk of the book discussing Jack and Roz Kirby 's marriage - but there is n't a single photograph of them in the book . It 's a shame .

EXCELLENT INTRO TO VIRUS EDUCATION ! After having read another Dale tale , I jumped at the opportunity to read this one too ! What a great educational resource and tool for young children ! My 3 or old son and I read this book before bedtime and I think the ideas along with the illustrations - especially the one that shows the virus monsters on the boys hand - really made his wheels turn in understanding what viruses and germs are . We love these little ball characters , so simple yet so expressive and full of emotion ! And their cute little round butts ! Haha ! My son maintained focus the entire story and paused in some places to explain things to me , like that we have to rinse the vegetables to send the germs down the drain Mama ! I am hopeful that the next time he touches something dirty and approaches his mouth , I can remind him of the virus story and hell finally understand why we do n't want him to do those things .

Felt a bit noisy by the end . Thanks Netgalley for an ARC to read and give my opinion . Tory Bradford is on the run from an ex fianc who turned violent when she tried to leave him . Now she is on the run and he has found her several times only for her to thwart his capture . She finds herself nearly broke , with her young daughter looking for work at a ranch . Josh was an ex military marine sniper who is building up a ranch with fellow ex marine buddies . One look at Tory and he knew she was trouble . Things start happening around the ranch that are unexplainable , and he starts to fall for Tory . I enjoyed this book but I felt the main plot was enough to satisfy a readers hunger , the author tied in other parts that I felt detracted from the story rather than add to it . But it does reference " PowerPoint " so I guess Microsoft can sue ? There were also some typos that should have been caught in copyediting . Overall , I rate it as decent easy reads on Kindle Unlimited .

Consistent . The estate of Robert B. Parker selected Ace Atkins to continue the franchise by writing Spenser novels . The first , Robert B. Parker 's Lullaby , provides great continuity for this legendary detective fiction . Atkins keeps dialogue and structure consistent with Parker 's model , and if anything he has fleshed out the novel more thoroughly than Parker did in his later novels . I decided to read this novel out of curiosity to see how true Atkins would be to the Parker model . I enjoyed reading this novel , and expect that most Parker and Spenser fans will be pleased to see more of this character in coming years . For me , I 'll probably move on to living authors developing their own characters . Rating Three - star Recommended

Interesting short story . This short story combines Karin Slaughter 's character Will Trent and Lee Child 's character Jack Reacher . The story is somewhat confusing as to how the two characters got together . It is partially cleared up at the end but there is a even bigger mystery as the climax of the story . The findings of the two men raised the prospect of the end of life in America as we know it , but there appears to be no follow up novel and the reader is left agonizing over whether or not this could be true . The story is predominantly sedate , with two men working in the gold storage area of Fort Knox . There is one episode that seems classic Jack Reacher when they shoot up a bar and capture some bad guys , but the action is relatively limited in the rest of the book . It was an interesting novel to read and if these two authors were to get together again I would certainly purchase that book .

Garden design for the wealthy . This is a strange book . It 's really only for someone who has property , money , time , but who has never grown food a day in their life . The first two thirds of the book are on picking your perfect large , not " small scale " like the title says garden area , and then designing and accessorizing a raised bed garden complex . There 's very little detail on actually building your raised beds so unless you 're already a contractor the author is obviously expecting you to hire one . When you do get to the actual planting and growing part there is some vague advice about finding out when to plant different crops in your area . Nothing you ca n't learn from typing your zip code into most seed websites . The most critical information , how to actually take care of your plants , is only a few pages in this book . The whole thing is pretty to look at , only vaguely interesting , and went right in my donation pile .

Not much new or interesting in here . This might be a good gift for a very young person who has never heard advice like " splurge on a pedicure " or " take a walk at sunset " as suggested treat for yourself and that kind of stereotypical and boring advice is about 40 of the book . It 's also not so much of a book offering a treat for every day since " go snorkeling " or " visit another country " is n't something you can just do without planning . However , if you can overlook some of the odd and awkward writing what on earth does the exhortation " Way on ! " mean ? and the lack of new ideas , there are a few sweet and thoughtful suggestions in here like " spend the day at an amusement park " or " volunteer at an animal shelter for a day " that might be just the tiny shake out of the typical that someone needs . That someone is not the friend I purchased this for , but I 'm sure someone will like it which is why this is headed to the used book store without ever becoming a gift

Keep on Hunting . Now here 's a book I was excited about . A good , old - fashioned retro - pulp adventure . Sounded like fun . It was n't . It 's your basic adventure plot Rugged adventurer accompanied by beautiful women travels to exotic locales to discover mystical mythical object place before the bad guys . Not that there 's anything wrong with that . But for a short book that 's basically nonstop action , the writing here is deadly dull . It 's not fun , not witty , not sexy , not exciting . The plot hits every expected beat with absolutely no surprises . The characters are as stock as the plot , the dialogue boring and clunky , and somehow the Indiana Jones - ish explorer adventurer seems less credible set in the twenty - first century than in the first half of the twentieth . I will stick with this series , though . This one was a dreadful disappointment , but I like several of the authors slated for forthcoming volumes and trust them to pen adventures more compelling than this one . Shame that this was the first , though , as its quality will probably turn readers off the likely - to - be - better subsequent volumes .

A Book that Goes Nowhere . Alan Dean Foster 's " Quofum " is a book that goes nowhere . Oh , technically , the writing 's very nice . But , there 's no point to the book . Outside of a whole lot of descriptive prose describing what the science team at the core of the book is doing , nothing happens . Worse , the mechanism used to leave that crew to their own devices about the middle of the book just comes out of the blue and is nonsensical it 's so silly that I almost stopped reading there I wish I had . For the coup de grace , the rest of the book consists of even more pointless descriptive prose followed by 10 pages or so of deus ex machine that fails to even tie anything up . If the writing were technically bad , I 'd be happy to rate this at an Awful 1 star out of 5 . But , in all honesty , I ca n't do that . So , I 'll bump it up to a Bad 2 stars out of 5 .

Not really believable . I recently read Pest by this author and enjoyed it for the most part although it felt like a dozen slices of different books rather then one cohesive story . That said , the writing was good so I was curious to see more . The story here is pretty solid - The author succeeds in portraying Amy as a likeable and sympathetic main character in a bad situation . She 's in an abusive relationship , lonely , scared , and looking for help . You ca n't help but root for her . The mysterious elderly neighbors form the core of the book as Amy develops a relationship with them . It begins quite realistically , but things soon get a little far fetched . Do n't want to give any major spoilers away so I wo n't go into details but I was shaking my head a lot during the last third of the book . There 's also some horrendous writing errors - my favorite being " there was a sudden wrap at the front door " when someone was knocking . Seriously ? Anyway , it 's an OK read . Took me about 4 days because I did n't really feel any special need to keep coming back , and I doubt much of it will stick with me .

. continued Parker 's series have successfully maintained what I have loved about them . The other writers who have continued Parker 's series have successfully maintained what I have loved about them . Coleman does n't . In his hands , Jesse Stone is not just a flawed human being but a tortured mess - a whole different character in ways that count . The hope that he can learn to control his drinking is gone . Instead of figuring out a relatively clean way to sort out the evil around him , this Jesse Stone buys into it , leaving him compromised and even more tortured . The ending , instead of providing the reader with a small island of satisfying closure , simply ups the horror . Coleman may be a good writer of his kind of stuff , but cramming a Parker novel into his recipe was not a good idea .

Do n't Pass Up Reading this Book ! Despite what many readers might think , a 10 - page kids book is a thousand times harder to write than an 80 , 000 - word novel . You have to boil your idea down into a few simple sentences that both enlighten and - let 's hope - DELIGHT young readers ! One thing we adults forget is the novelty of things we take , by long exposure , for granted . A writers of kids fiction has to dig deeply for that inner child that still recalls what a delightful place the world once was for him . A place where it might actually be possible to juggle bees - but infinitely unwise to do so . Kudos to Mr. Hawksley . I will look forward to many more adventures with him !

excluding the Nantucket trilogy which was superb they have become more and more boring as times goes on . I used to buy everything Stirling wrote in , in hardback no less , but about five books back I stopped . The Change series is now up to ten , excluding the Nantucket trilogy which was superb and they have become more and more boring as times goes on . I suspect that Stirling himself is bored with the series given the way in which he has begun to bulk out the books with songs , recipes , and turgid descriptions of how his characters look and how they dress . In the process he seems to have lost the plot , in more senses than one . The latest reads more like a young adult book . Perhaps that is his new target ? I wo n't be reading any more of his books .

Is this the rough copy ? I reviewed this a couple times but my reviews keep mysteriously getting deleted ? Do n't worry , seller , I wo n't let this unfortunate glitch sabotage the right of your potential customers to see unbiased honest reviews before they decide whether to buy , or the right of customers like me to express our opinions on what we bought . I will keep submitting my voice no matter how many times it gets mistakenly flagged . Anyway , the illustrations in this book truly look like they accidentally published the rough copy . Y'know how the fun of illustrations is looking closer and finding some cool detail like the expression on a character 's face or some activity in the background ? This has NOTHING like that . You glance at a page , you 've seen everything . There are no extra details to be found . And the pictures are unpleasant . The animals are not beautiful nor realistic nor cutely engaging , they are low - effort and bleak . There 's not one thing in this that could put a smile on one 's face or reward close inspection by a curious mind . I could n't give this to a kid , they 'd be so upset . It has the charm of a text book but a quarter the info .

Organized Simplicity . I found the book helpful in a number of ways . I found it a little long on philosophy and short on how to actually accomplish tasks . By this I mean that I expected a simplified approach to managing multitasking . What I found was a rather complicated , repetitive system of handwritten daily planning and scheduling . I do n't believe this approach is functional for many of the women who want to simplify . The concepts are great . The daily execution is too time - consuming and repetitive to be entirely useful . Perhaps someone can take these concepts and revise the daily execution into a streamlined version that makes more sense for all women .

I 'm sorry I read it . It 's rare for me to regret reading a novel if it is well - written and has sympathetic or at least interesting characters . I have to give it three stars for the quality of the writing . It is emotional , compelling , and mostly paced appropriately for the story . The sensory descriptions are well - rendered . But as the last chapter ended , I could not think of a single reason why I was glad I had read this . It is depressing and offers almost nothing I look for in a novel . Not even entertainment . It 's a story full of wounded people who get very little in the way of healing . Just . resignation . And while the religious bits are not prevalent enough to label this " christian fiction , " there is enough of it peppered in there to taint the content significantly . There are those who will love it and be very moved . And hey , sometimes we all need a good cry . But I was so frustrated and disappointed by the end , I could not even bring my usually - inspired tears to the surface . If there is n't enough in your life to depress you , by all means , read it and join the rest of us .

Theft . John Banville has filled his novel , The Blue Guitar , with beautifully written prose . I found myself reading several sentences multiple times to enjoy how perfectly crafted they were , and how word choices seemed perfect . Narrated by an unappealing and very introspective artist , the novel explores the creative process and the essence of art . The narrator is proud to have been a thief , and in many respects , most art involves minor theft of ideas and forms from others . Fans of finely written literary fiction are those most likely to enjoy reading this novel . Rating Four - star I like it

A disappointment . I picked up this book awhile ago but kept on placing it aside to read something else . I wish I would have kept doing that because I feel like I wasted a few hours of my life . The protagonist , Gaby , is unlikeable and boorish and her friend , Mort , is almost too whiny to be real . The only shining point in this book is Luther Cross , but by the time the book is done you want to smack him for chasing after Gaby , because he could do so much better . Basically Gaby is a Paladin , a warrior who answers to the calling of God . She destroys " demons " although I believe the author does n't describe them authentically enough to be demons . I almost feel like Gaby has mental problems and she 's chasing after bad humans who are n't necessarily demons . I wo n't be reading the second in this series .

Useful ideas , but . . . Many of the innovative approaches undertaken by the various agencies outlined in Osborne and Gaebler 's work do provide some inspiration for needed changes in how government operates . Nevertheless , it is important to note that some of the ballyhooed " innovations " described in this arguably important work failed subsequent to the publication date . As such , readers sorely deserve an update . We could learn as much from how some of these innovations have failed as we did from how many of them succeeded .

Great Premise , Good Writing . Great Premise , Good Writing . and yet the book did n't work for me . I got to page 101 and then I just had to start skimming the story was n't doing it for me . Sorry , I 'm old . I generally give books 50 pages to engage me . That I gave this one 100 says something of the book 's merits . What worked for me was the premise . Very interesting , though not entirely novel . What also worked was the author 's depiction of addiction and addictive thinking . Pretty much dead on . What did n't work was the pacing . I thought it was deadly slow , and really highlighted the fact that there was n't any sense of danger from the bombs . In fact I found myself more worried about how clean their needles were , than whether they 'd be munched to death . IF you are tired of the hackneyed zombie novels out there , do give this one a try . I found that the intoxication took over too much of the story , becoming the principle character - a character that stifled the action , but the characterization of the addicts never falters . And Peter Stenson is definitely an author worth getting to know . I 'll certainly be on the look out for his next book .

Bitter Blather . While the work is verbose and literary , it is annoyingly simple and repetitive . The juiciest parts of the book are the near - sci - fi bursts of Idiocracy , where social media has warped everyone into imbecilic attention - whore children . Eventually , this same set of jokes and satire grow stale by books end . The heart of the plot concerns a pair of unlikely lovers navigating their turbulent relationship with each other . The lack of imagination and odd circumstances to this meandering affair can be attributed to this story being largely modeled after the writers own love life in this semi autobiographical tale . The observations and humor simply grow tired by story end , offering nothing new by the end that had n't been ruthlessly flogged earlier in the book . Much like a nouveau Philip Roth , this book is filled with suppressed rage , pseudo - academia and sexual frustration which dominates the narrators black and bitter perspective .

Waste of a couple hours . The premise could be interesting and fully developed but the author fails to do that . This book was a waste of time thankfully it 's a short read and can be read in one extended period . The author attempts to use the " less is more " adage but fails at connecting the reader to the characters . A suspenseful drama does n't need to include such detail that nothing is left unexplained , and I do think the author made good choices in not revealing too much detail . The chapters were so sparse , and the book is already so thin it did n't allow for a more fully developed storyline . The end of the book left me feeling very unsatisfied , somehow cheated by the cheap ended . It was as if the author had no vision how to bring closure , watched some Hollywood movie and came up with the ending after that . To me , it was a waste of time spend more time reading books like Under a Thousand Splendid Suns or other similar books if you are interested in a suspenseful drama where the characters are more developed and it begs the reader for a reaction .

Neighbors . In so many ways Ed Andrews'personal story of mortgage disaster was both more and less than I expected . Busted Life Inside the Great Mortgage Meltdown presents the embarrassing story of a New York Times economic reporter 's personal financial and personal crises of the last few years . One would expect that an educated and informed person would have averted predatory loans and would not have spent so far beyond one 's means , but we humans are complicated , and Andrews'story is like that of many others . He divorced , and faced increased expenses by adding his own housing expenses . He remarried , and his costs increased further . Both he and his new wife were reckless with spending and never quite found a productive way of talking about money and spending . For readers who love schadenfreude , Busted will be very satisfying . For fans of reality television , this print version of Cribs might be entertaining . For any reader who wonders about what kind of people get themselves into financial muddles , Andrews and his wife offer some answers but little sympathy because of their selfishness , immaturity and overall recklessness . If these people are our neighbors , the neighborhood is in trouble . Rating Two - star Mildly Recommended

Great conclusion and first book of a series , but . elder 's Game is a great sci - fi in many ways . It is a much easier to read than many futuristic pieces and the settings are vivid although somewhat left to the imagination am I just saying I have a good imagination The novel follows Ender as he completes military training to defeat'The Buggers ' . In order to succeed Ender must survive his murderous brother , fellow students , the games that his superiors play , and eventually the enemy themselves . My problem with the book is that its main drawcard is the ending twist . The rest of the book lacks real tension . The main character is a child prodigy who never looses a battle , so one reads the book without any fear of the protagonist failing or the need for a resolution of tension . The character development is relatively basic , although there are a few satisfying revelations . There are also the occasional interesting philosophies on warfare throughout Ender 's lessons . Ultimately Ender 's Game is an excellent beginning to a series and a relatively easy read . Recommended to sci - fi fans and those who enjoy straightforward books .

What a letdown for the final book of the trilogy . " The Hunger Games , " in my opinion , is one of the best young adult novels written in the last several years . I thought " Catching Fire " setup some interesting ideas and was a solid continuation of the story . " Mockingjay,'however may be the most disappointed I 've been in a book in a long time . It 's almost like the author did n't know what type of story she wanted to tell or what she wanted to focus on throughout the novel . There are so many plot holes or nonsensical character actions that it actually turned me off of the story as I neared the ending . I get that Collins may have been setting up the whole idea that revolutions do n't end with a final blowout kind of battle , but a lot of times the novel just seems to be treading water . Characters change with very little insight given into what may have brought on those changes and the last few chapters of the book almost seem disconnected in the way everything haphazardly wraps up at the end . There are some interesting ideas to be found in Mockingjay , but none of them really ever come to a full realization .

STRANGE . The best way to describe this book is " STRANGE " . I never really understood it , I guess . The circus is a magic circus , one that is n't really there and yet you can see it in your mind . The author did a great job of describing the tents , the acts , and the smells but the characters were shallow leaving no connection between them and the reader . The last 100 pages are the best of the book but they still leave you asking " huh " ? I have read that we only use 20 of our brain capacity , so conceptually I 'm wondering if the author was thinking that these things could be possible if we used more of our brains than we do . I also wonder if this book is enjoyed by a much younger generation . I guess I 'll find out during our discussion at book club . As for me , I would n't recommend .

Flawed , although probably the best . My primary gripe is that the prompts in English are inconsistent and unnecessarily backwards , grammatically . For example , the announcer gives the following prompt in English " The coffee of that coffee shop is delicious " . Not only is that sentence grammatically awkward , it does n't match the grammar of the correct translation in Japanese . The correct response in Japanese is simply , " That coffee shop 's coffee is delicious " . There is no reason why the prompt can not match this . I really wish Pimsleur cleaned up these inconsistencies for a more productive and less frustrating learning experience .

Imogene the doormat female character . I tried to take into consideration that this book was originally published in 1954 and so the world and women were completely different especially concerning gender roles . But this book though slow moving - and I did n't mind that - was strange and pathetic especially with the women characters . Every step Blanche took to inching into their lives - Imogene did nothing . She did n't fight back - she did n't try to keep Evelyn she allows it to happen . And then when it finally did come to a show down - all she can do is yell " how dare you " a couple of times and that 's it . And the whole thing with Gavin - what a snot nosed little brat . He should have been spanked . The only redeeming thing about the story was her friends Cecil , Hunter , Paul and of course the adorable Tim . Her relationship with Tim - her surrogate son - made up for much . Evelyn was a thoroughly unlikeable character who seemed very self absorbed who needs a woman like Blanche to whip him into shape . And god forbid Imogene keeps the plates the way she wants them - so silly . But overall Imogene seemed like a fragile woman who let life trample over her .
